<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>a. Negative print. b. From 40˚ to 65˚ South and 100˚ West to
150˚ East. “The Russians gave us this track in the form of a book
with the profiles printed on 8x11 pages. These sheets had to be
copied and pasted together, then annotated in our customary style of
selected peaks and valleys, in the appropriate unit. Seven lat. and
long. were noted in order to plot the depths onto a map with the
appropriate lat. and long. These notebooks have been boxed up and
cruises have been indexed – see Foreign Data and Profile
Records.”</p>
</scopecontent>

100:1 and were 20 inches wide. These profiles have been correlated
peak for peak, lined up and shot down in size to this composite
worksheet. This is a negative of a worksheet (the original was much
larger). The finished, inked drawing for publication will probably
be in the Pacific ocean bin. Twenty five profiles lined up to work
with 170˚ East and 60˚ South across the Mid- Oceanic Ridge
in the southeast Pacific Ocean."</p>

<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>a. Paper. b. 00199, 18 July 1967. Covers 1706S. “1st attempt to
computerize soundings, published in our 8x11 book w/ positives and
scale depths given. In order to use these profiles, these sheets had
to be glued together to make a continuous profile of the area across
which the ship went. The profiles also had to have spot depths with
peaks and valleys read off in uncorrected fathoms. These depths were
then plotted on a map along the track, then they could be compared
with other ship’s profiles which had also been plotted at a vertical
exaggeration of 100:1. Many published volumes of this project went
on to Colorado.”</p>
</scopecontent>

<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>Consists of some 370 items related to Heezen and Tharp's mapping of the Arctic Ocean
floor.</p>
</scopecontent>

units."</p>

<p>Guide map and a street plan.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>4 items</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>1 item</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>This collection contains photocopies of original press releases released by the American
television networks ABC and CBS between June 11, 1962 and July 4, 1970. The original
press releases were collected by David A. Dunsford. The press releases pertain to news
programs, television specials, documentaries, movies of the week, religious programs,
variety shows, talk shows, soap operas, news programming, dramas, and situation comedies
broadcast by ABC and CBS.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The Jerry Lewis Papers consist of scripts and sketch material; memos and other
correspondence; itineraries; business and legal papers; photographic prints, proof
sheets, and negatives; press clippings and publicity; and other materials related to the
film and television career of comedian, actor, and filmmaker Jerry Lewis, primarily from
the period following the breakup of the act he formed with singer and comedian Dean
Martin. Also included are papers related to Lewis's work with the Muscular Dystrophy
Association's annual telethon, and his teaching work at the University of Southern
California.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Rundown.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Ernest D. Glucksman was producer or associate producer for multiple Jerry Lewis
television appearances and films from 1950-1964.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>George Smith Patton (1885-1945)</part>
</persname> span the years
1807-1979, with the bulk of the papers concentrated from 1904 to 1945. The
collection documents Patton's military career, including his attendance at the
<corpname>
<part>United States Military Academy</part>
</corpname> at
<geogname>
<part>West Point,</part>
</geogname> 1904-1909; his service on the Mexican
border as a member of
<persname>
<part>John J. Pershing's</part>
</persname>
<corpname>
<part>Mexican Punitive Expedition, 1916-1917</part>
</corpname>; his
service as an aide-de-camp to Pershing and later as a tank commander in World
War I, 1917-1919; and his military career from 1938 to 1945. The majority of
the papers chronicle Patton's World War II service and his success as one of
<geogname>
<part>America's</part>
</geogname> most skillful combat commanders of
armored troops. The papers consist of eleven series:
<ref target="diary" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Diaries,</ref>
<ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Chronological
File,</ref>
<ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Family
Papers,</ref>
<ref target="corr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence,</ref>
<ref target="milpap" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Military
Papers,</ref>
<ref target="millib" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Military
Library,</ref>
<ref target="maps" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Maps,</ref>
<ref target="photo" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Photographs,</ref>
<ref target="speech" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and
Writings File,</ref>
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Miscellany,</ref>
and
<ref target="oversz" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Oversize.</ref>
Most of the series relate to Patton's personal and military activities and his
leadership in the development and tactical use of the tank as a combat weapon.
Additional papers concerning Patton's service in World War I are in the
<corpname>
<part>Chester Fritz Library</part>
</corpname> of the
<corpname>
<part>University of North Dakota</part>
</corpname> located near
<geogname>
<part>Grand Forks, North Dakota.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="diary" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Diaries,</ref>
1910-1945, illustrate Patton's activities during the
<corpname>
<part>Mexican Punitive Expedition,</part>
</corpname> World War I, and
World War II. The volumes, particularly from 1942 to 1945, document Patton's
daily activities and observations and reveal his candor about himself,
personally and professionally. They include information about American ground
combat operations in the campaign for
<geogname>
<part>North Africa,</part>
</geogname> the invasion of
<geogname>
<part>Sicily,</part>
</geogname> the liberation of
<geogname>
<part>France,</part>
</geogname> and the final assault on
<geogname>
<part>Germany.</part>
</geogname> Annotated volumes covering World War II
often contain additional detail expanding on the original volume entries. The
original diaries are dated through 24 March 1945, while annotated transcripts
continue to 3 December 1945. The Library did not receive the latter portion of
the original diaries. Additional topics include Patton's honeymoon trip to
<geogname>
<part>Europe</part>
</geogname> in 1910 and his fox hunting activities,
1932-1935.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Chronological
File,</ref> 1901-1977, provides an overview of Patton's life, serving as a
combination diary-scrapbook consisting mainly of diary entries, correspondence,
memoranda, and reports. Approximately one half of the series is in transcript
form. The originals of these transcripts are located in other series. This
series also contains original items, primarily correspondence, that do not
appear in any other series.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Family
Papers,</ref> 1857-1979, consist mainly of Patton's letters to his wife,
<persname>
<part>Beatrice Banning Ayer Patton,</part>
</persname> and his father,
<persname>
<part>George S. Patton (1856-1927).</part>
</persname> Early letters
chronicle Patton's struggle as a student at
<corpname>
<part>West Point.</part>
</corpname> His letters to his wife are detailed
and, like the diaries, contain frank assessments of commanders, subordinates,
and military operations. Patton shared not only his achievements with his wife
but also some of the negative incidents that affected his career, such as the
reaction in November 1943 when the press reported that he had slapped two
soldiers suffering battle fatigue in
<geogname>
<part>Sicily</part>
</geogname> and his remarks in a speech in
<geogname>
<part>Knutsford, England,</part>
</geogname> in April 1944 omitting
inclusions of
<geogname>
<part>Russia</part>
</geogname> as one of the countries likely to rule the
postwar world with the
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Great Britain.</part>
</geogname> Both incidents threatened his
career and almost resulted in his removal from the war. Also in the Family
Papers are correspondence of
<persname>
<part>Beatrice Patton</part>
</persname> and an autobiographical account of
Patton's memories of his father. There is a significant amount of printed
matter of
<persname>
<part>George H. Smith,</part>
</persname> Patton's step-grandfather,
concerning the Civil War battle of
<geogname>
<part>New Market, Virginia.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>Papers in the
<ref target="corr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref> series, 1903-1945, include incoming
and outgoing correspondence between Patton and his staff, commanders,
government officials, friends, and the general public. Because many of Patton's
friends and colleagues were in the military, there is a significant amount of
material in the chronological correspondence that relates to military matters.
The official correspondence documents the planning of various combat
operations, particularly for the
<corpname>
<part>Allied</part>
</corpname> invasion of
<geogname>
<part>Sicily</part>
</geogname> and D-Day planning for
<geogname>
<part>France</part>
</geogname> and reflects Patton's varied duties as a
commander. The topical correspondence includes fan mail, inquiries on
casualties, furloughs and discharges, the slapping incidents in
<geogname>
<part>Sicily,</part>
</geogname> and Christmas and get-well letters sent to
Patton after his automobile accident in December 1945.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="milpap" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Military
Papers,</ref> 1903-1976, consist of administrative files, Patton's personnel
file, and a subject file. The bulk of the series illustrates Patton's duties
while a combat commander from 1942 to 1945. The files include orders,
citations, memoranda, speeches, training instructions, policy and procedural
material, and reports concerning units Patton commanded. Speeches made by
Patton to his troops during World War II were originally filed in the Military
Papers, and this order has been retained. Duplicates of some of these speeches
are filed in the
<ref target="speech">Speeches and Writings File.</ref> Documents
relating to Patton's personnel file include both personal and official papers.
The official papers are included in a microfilm copy of Patton's file in the
records of the
<corpname>
<part>Department of the Army.</part>
</corpname> Prominent topics featured
in the subject file are the cavalry, casualty information, denazification of
<geogname>
<part>Germany,</part>
</geogname> displaced persons, and tanks. Much of the
material relating to tanks concerns the development of that vehicle and the
tactics of armored warfare. The series also contains material relating to
Patton's death and funeral.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="millib" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Military
Library</ref> series, 1907-1947, includes class publications from
<corpname>
<part>West Point,</part>
</corpname> intelligence and campaign reports, and
other material relating to military tactics. The majority of the series
consists of campaign reports pertaining to
<geogname>
<part>France</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Germany.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>Items in the
<ref target="maps" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Maps</ref>
series, 1906-1945, reflect Patton's interest in cartography. Most of the items
are situation maps of the European theater and commemorative maps of the
<corpname>
<part>United States Third Army's</part>
</corpname> operations in
<geogname>
<part>Europe.</part>
</geogname> A map of
<geogname>
<part>Western Europe,</part>
</geogname> marked by Patton in March 1944
prior to the development of campaign plans, illustrates with remarkable
accuracy the projected route that the
<corpname>
<part>Third Army</part>
</corpname> would take in its advance across
<geogname>
<part>France</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Germany.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="photo" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Photographs</ref> series, 1864-1958, consist primarily of
items relating to Patton's military career, although there are a few family
photographs in the "Miscellaneous" folders. Locations featured in the World War
II pictures include
<geogname>
<part>North Africa,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>Sicily,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>England,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>France,</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Germany.</part>
</geogname> Also well represented are Patton's years
at the military academy at
<geogname>
<part>West Point,</part>
</geogname> his tenure at
<geogname>
<part>Fort Meade, Maryland,</part>
</geogname> and his service with the
<corpname>
<part>Mexican Punitive Expedition.</part>
</corpname> World War II
"Miscellaneous" folders include photographs, some autographed, of Patton's
superiors and fellow officers.</p>
<p>Papers in the
<ref target="speech" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and
Writings File,</ref> 1900-1947, consist chiefly of articles, speeches, reports,
lectures, book reviews, memoranda, poetry, and memoirs. A few writings of
others interfiled in this series with Patton's texts are listed in a partial
index compiled by Patton. Prominent topics featured in Patton's writings
include the saber, the cavalry, mechanization, tanks, and tank tactics.
Patton's writings illustrate his early interest in armored warfare and indicate
his belief in the tank as an important combat weapon long before its success in
World War II. A 1937 paper entitled "Surprise" includes Patton's prediction of
an attack by
<geogname>
<part>Japan</part>
</geogname> on
<geogname>
<part>Pearl Harbor.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Miscellany</ref>
series, 1911-1966, includes biographical information, certificates and
citations, reports, and printed matter relating chiefly to Patton's
participation in the pentathlon in the
<corpname>
<part>1912 Olympics</part>
</corpname> in
<geogname>
<part>Stockholm,</part>
</geogname> his interests in fencing and
swordsmanship, and his attendance at the
<corpname>
<part>Mounted Service School,</part>
</corpname>
<geogname>
<part>Fort Riley, Kansas.</part>
</geogname> Also documented in the series
are the various medals and honors awarded Patton during his lifetime and
posthumously. The
<ref target="oversz" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Oversize</ref>
series, 1807-1951, consists principally of maps, overlays, photograph albums,
and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings, correspondence, photographs, and other
printed matter.</p>
<p>Prominent among Patton's correspondents are
<persname>
<part>Harold Alexander (Earl Alexander of Tunis),</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Terry de la Mesa Allen,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Henry Harley Arnold,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Charles Fanning Ayer,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Frederick Ayer,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Omar Nelson Bradley,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Arvin H. Brown,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Mark W. Clark,</part>
</persname>

<part>Lucius D. Clay,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Charles R. Codman,</part>
</persname>

</persname>

</persname>

<part>James Harold Doolittle,</part>
</persname>

</persname>

</persname>

</persname>

</persname>

</persname>
<persname>

</persname>

</persname>

</persname> and

</persname>
</p>
<p> Throughout his papers, Patton used nicknames, abbreviations, and code
words to denote certain persons and operations. The following names and words
are found primarily in his World War II diaries and correspondence and the
chronological file for those years:</p>
<list>
<item>"Ike," "d," "D," "Destiny"--Dwight D. Eisenhower</item>
<item>"Brad," "tent maker"--Omar Nelson Bradley</item>
<item>"P"--John Shirley Wood</item>
<item>"Hap"--Henry Harley Arnold</item>
<item>"Critt"--Willis Dale Crittenberger</item>
<item>"Jake"--Jacob L. Devers</item>
<item>"Tody"--Charles P. George</item>
<item>"Van"--Alvan Cullom Gillem, Jr.</item>
<item>"Beadle"--Walter Bedell Smith</item>
<item>"Tooey"--Carl Spaatz</item>
<item>"Day"--Alexander D. Surles</item>
<item>"Paddy"--Harry Albert Flint</item>
<item>"Husky"--Allied invasion of Sicily, 10 July 1943</item>
<item>"Bigot"--D-Day planning, 1944</item>
</list>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph and typewritten diaries, bound and unbound. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>A collection of diary entries, correspondence, school papers,
memoranda, reports, photographs, articles, speeches, lectures, maps, notebooks,
orders, citations, newspaper clippings, printed matter, and other material.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence between Patton and family members with attachments
and enclosures, genealogical material, printed matter, and miscellaneous papers
relating to the family. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Chronological, official, and topical correspondence, with attached
and appended material, between Patton and his staff, army officials, friends,
acquaintances, and the general public. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, orders, citations, speeches,
photographs, training instructions, policy and procedural material, Patton's
personnel file, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Reports, printed matter, near-print material, and typed notes.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Maps from various phases of Patton's military career. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bound and unbound photographs. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph, typescript, near-print, and published copies of
articles, speeches, lectures, book reviews, memoranda, reports, field manuals,
instructional material, poetry, and memoirs. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Memoranda, reports, biographical information, citations,
certificates, photographs, near-print and printed matter, notes and notebooks,
postcards, and newspaper clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

other material retained after microfilming. Once the scrapbooks were
microfilmed, the volumes, OV 23-OV 49, were destroyed.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Oversize material consisting of maps, diagrams and blueprints,
overlays, photographs, charts, posters, a report, and scrapbooks. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>James Whitcomb Riley (1849-1916)</part>
</persname> span the years 1883-1915 and include correspondence, poems, and a drawing. Riley was born in <geogname>
<part>Greenfield, Indiana,</part>
</geogname> and is known as the "Hoosier poet." He was on the staff of the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Indianapolis Journal,</part>
</title> 1877-1885, and his contributions to that newspaper established his fame as a poet.
</p>
<p>The papers include letters from Riley to <persname>
<part>William C. Edgar,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>C. E. Farrell,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Samuel E. Kiser,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Clara E. Laughlin,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James Newton Matthews,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Cyrus F. McNutt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>DeWitt Miller,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James B. Pond,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Clark Ridpath,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>George Smith,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Louis Untermeyer,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Eugene Fitch Ware, </part>
</persname> and others. The papers also include a drawing by Riley of his friend, <persname>
<part>Bill Nye.</part>
</persname>

</p>
<p>Manuscript poems in the collection include "To Robert Burns Wilson," "The Poems Here at Home," "Say Farewell and Let Me Go!," "At 'The Literary,'" "A Pen-Pictur' of a Certin Frivvelus Old Man," and an untitled verse written for a <persname>
<part>Mr. Washington.</part>
</persname> Typescript poems
include "The Name of Old Glory," "The Lisper," "The Young Old Man," and "At 'The
Literary.'"</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>William Allen (1803-1879)</part>
</persname> span the years
1796-1879, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the period 1840-1876. The
collection focuses on his career in
<geogname>
<part>Ohio</part>
</geogname> politics, first as
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> representative and senator, then as
governor of
<geogname>
<part>Ohio.</part>
</geogname> Included are correspondence, speeches,
memoranda, financial records, printed matter, maps, and other material. The
papers are arranged in a bound
<ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Chronological
File
</ref> and a
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany.
</ref>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Chronological
File
</ref> consists primarily of correspondence, financial records, maps, and
other material concerning
<geogname>
<part>Ohio</part>
</geogname> and national politics during the 1840s and
the 1870s. Topics include support of the
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> annexation of
<geogname>
<part>Texas,</part>
</geogname> the Mexican War,
<geogname>
<part>Oregon</part>
</geogname> claims, land surveys, and the Greenback
movement. Correspondents include
<persname>
<part>James Faran</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>James Graham</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>John Hough</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Amos Layman</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>George Morgan</part>
</persname>, and
<persname>
<part>Henry A. Whitman.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany
</ref>
consists of an account book of the
<corpname>
<part>Stoney Mill Salt Works</part>
</corpname>,
<geogname>
<part>Chillicothe, Ohio</part>
</geogname>, dating from 1811 to 1823, which
Allen used partially as the backing for a scrapbook of clippings from 1825 to
1827. Also in the series are cancelled bank checks, an 1838 directory of the
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> government, memoranda books
containing jottings and accounting notes, newspaper clippings, a notebook, a
promissory note, political literature, a scrapbook, speeches by Allen and
others, and the records of the
<corpname>
<part>Chillicothe Independent Blues</part>
</corpname>, an Ohio militia
corps. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, speeches, memoranda, financial records, printed
matter, and other papers largely related to Allen's career as a
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> congressman (1833-1835) and
senator (1837-1848) and governor of
<geogname>
<part>Ohio</part>
</geogname> (1874-1876). </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Account book, scrapbooks, memorandum books, notebooks, political
literature, records of the
<corpname>
<part>Chillicothe Independent Blues Militia Corps</part>
</corpname>,
speeches, and other material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>Lorenzo Johnston Greene (1899-1988)</part>
</persname>, pioneer in
African-American historical studies and multiculturalism, editor, and civil
rights and social activist, span the years 1680-1988, with the bulk of the
material documenting Greene's thirty-nine year career (1933-1972) at
<corpname>
<part>Lincoln University</part>
</corpname>,
<geogname>
<part>Jefferson City, Missouri</part>
</geogname>, and as a professor
emeritus at that historically black institution from his retirement in 1972 to
his death in 1988. Before coming to
<corpname>
<part>Lincoln University</part>
</corpname>, Greene was a field
representative for the
<corpname>
<part>Association for the Study of Negro Life and History
(ASNLH)</part>
</corpname> and a close associate of
<persname>
<part>Carter G. Woodson</part>
</persname>, the founder of the organization
and the "father of Afro-American history." As an educator, Greene was an early
advocate of the introduction of multicultural content into grade school and
college texts nationwide. He wrote numerous monographs and articles, including
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Negro In Colonial New England, 1620-1776,</part>
</title> and edited
the
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Midwest Journal,</part>
</title> sponsored by
<corpname>
<part>Lincoln University.</part>
</corpname> Greene's community service, in
which he stressed open housing and school desegregation, included helping to
found the
<corpname>
<part>Missouri Commission on Human Rights</part>
</corpname> and chairing the

<corpname>
<part>human rights committee of the Missouri Association for Social
Welfare</part>
</corpname> and the
<corpname>
<part>education subcommittee of the Missouri Advisory Committee to
the United States Commission on Civil Rights.</part>
</corpname> His papers are
organized into seven series:
<ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Family</ref>,
<ref target="aca" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Academic</ref>,
<ref target="pro" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Professional
Organizations</ref>,
<ref target="pub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Public Interest
Organizations</ref>,
<ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and
Writings</ref>,
<ref target="add" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Addition</ref>, and
<ref target="ov" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Oversize</ref>.</p>
<p>Greene maintained a long-term correspondence with family members,
childhood friends, and friends cultivated in
<geogname>
<part>New York</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Washington, D.C.,</part>
</geogname> during graduate school at
<corpname>
<part>Columbia University</part>
</corpname> and field work with the
<corpname>
<part>Association for the Study of Negro Life and
History.</part>
</corpname> Correspondence, biographical material on Greene, and
subject files concerning family members are available in the
<ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Family</ref>
series. The largest file in the series concerns Greene's wife, concert pianist
<persname>
<part>Thomasina T. Greene</part>
</persname>, and includes Greene's
correspondence as her tour manager and material on her father,
<persname>
<part>Thomas W. Talley</part>
</persname>, a chemistry professor and
pioneering African-American folklorist who wrote
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Negro Folk Rhymes.</part>
</title>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="aca" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Academic</ref>
series documents Greene's career at
<corpname>
<part>Lincoln University</part>
</corpname> and is organized into
<ref target="adm" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Administrative</ref>,
<ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref>,
<ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General</ref>,
<ref target="mid" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
<emph render="italic">Midwest Journal</emph>
</ref>, and
<ref target="res" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Research</ref>
subseries. The
<ref target="adm" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Administrative</ref> subseries includes files related to
African-American studies courses and curricula, academic committees, and
student affairs. Large files in the subseries relate to the
<corpname>
<part>Institute for Drop-Out Prevention and Teacher
Orientation</part>
</corpname> and to the
<corpname>
<part>Institute to Facilitate Desegregation in Kansas City, Mo.,
Public Schools,</part>
</corpname> headed by Greene during 1971-1974. </p>
<p>Correspondents prominent in the
<ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref> subseries of the Academic File include

<persname>
<part>Herbert Aptheker</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Gerald L. Davis</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Herman Dreer</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>W. E. B. Du Bois</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>William L. Dunn</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Mervyn M. Dymally</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Merl R. Eppse</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>John E. Fleming</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Charles W. Florence</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>James Frank</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>H. Hadley Hartshorn</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>J. Noel Heermance</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>W. B. Jason</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Charles S. Johnson</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Harold J. Jonas</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part> Peter Kellogg</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Charles L. Klotzer</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Wilbur C. McAfee</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Mabel M. Smythe</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Arvarh E. Strickland</part>
</persname>, and
<persname>
<part>Marion Manola Wright.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>Documentation of Greene's study of the African-American experience in
his home region includes a substantial file in the
<ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General</ref>
subseries of the Academic series relating to his work as a consultant for the
<corpname>
<part>Parting Ways Museum of Afro-American Ethnohistory</part>
</corpname>
in
<geogname>
<part>Plymouth, Massachusetts,</part>
</geogname> an institution focusing
on black history in
<geogname>
<part>New England.</part>
</geogname> This file contains correspondence
with
<persname>
<part>Marjorie E. Anderson</part>
</persname>, founder and long-time
director of the museum. Also documented in the General subseries is Greene's
participation with his students in the sharecroppers' roadside demonstration
movement during 1939-1940 in
<geogname>
<part>southern Missouri,</part>
</geogname> a precursor to the activist
stage of the civil rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="mid" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
<emph render="italic">Midwest Journal</emph>
</ref> subseries relates to Greene's
editorship during 1947-1956. The
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Midwest Journal</part>
</title> under Greene was a magazine of research
and creative writing with an international reputation, emphasizing, but not
limited to, African-American writers and issues. Material on the journal
includes an editorial file containing biographical material on contributing
writers, draft articles, correspondence with publishers, and a general
correspondence file containing letters largely to and from contributing
writers. General correspondents of the
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Midwest Journal</part>
</title> subseries include
<persname>
<part>Herbert Aptheker</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Thomas Hart Benton</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Cecil A. Blue</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Lois M. Jones</part>
</persname>, and
<persname>
<part>George Shepperson.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="res" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Research</ref>
subseries of the Academic File contains files concerning public records on
African Americans in several
<geogname>
<part>New England</part>
</geogname> states, including copies of documents
related to the 1781 <emph render="italic">Jennison v. Walker</emph> case, a
major factor in the abolition of slavery in
<geogname>
<part>Massachusetts,</part>
</geogname> and copies of payrolls (1778-1779)
and invalid accounts (1790) of the black
<corpname>
<part>First Rhode Island Regiment of the Continental
Army.</part>
</corpname> Material on the African-American experience in
<geogname>
<part>Missouri</part>
</geogname> contained in the Research subseries of
the Academic series includes correspondence related to a county by county
survey conducted by Greene of black marriages in the state during 1865-1900, a
1936 interview with former slave
<persname>
<part>Dilcey Ann Patterson</part>
</persname>, a file on African-American
public schools during the era of segregation, and material on the
<corpname>
<part>Sixty-Fifth</part>
</corpname> and
<corpname>
<part>Sixty-Eighth regiments, United States Colored
Troops,</part>
</corpname> whose members founded
<corpname>
<part>Lincoln University</part>
</corpname> after the Civil War.</p>
<p>Historical material on black Americans in the
<ref target="res" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Research</ref>
subseries of the Academic series, however, is not limited to the
<corpname>
<part>New England</part>
</corpname> region and
<geogname>
<part>Missouri.</part>
</geogname> Greene conducted correspondence spanning
1934-1983 with libraries and archives throughout the
<geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> inquiring about manuscript resources
on African Americans. An example of the wealth of material he uncovered through
this process is correspondence from the
<corpname>
<part>Washington State Historical Society</part>
</corpname> on
<persname>
<part>George W. Bush</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>William O. Bush</part>
</persname>, father and son African-American
pioneers and civic leaders in the Pacific Northwest.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="res" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Research</ref>
subseries also documents Greene's efforts starting in the 1930s to introduce
African-American studies and multiculturalism into textbooks and curricula
nationwide. A project in 1964 to chart the representation of African Americans
in over 150 history and social science textbooks spanning 1941-1964 is
especially well documented.</p>
<p>Greene's commitment to the development of African-American history as
both a branch of the historical profession and as a means of black
consciousness-raising is reflected in the
<corpname>
<part>Association for the Study of Negro Life and History
(ASNLH)</part>
</corpname> file of the
<ref target="pro" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Professional
Organizations</ref> series. Greene was active in the
<corpname>
<part>ASNLH,</part>
</corpname> which in 1976 changed its name to the
<corpname>
<part>Association for the Study of Afro-American Life and History
(ASALH),</part>
</corpname> throughout his career, twice serving as program committee
chair for annual meetings and, during 1965-1966, as president of the
organization. Of special interest is correspondence with
<persname>
<part>Carter G. Woodson</part>
</persname>, long-time executive director of
the
<corpname>
<part>ASNLH,</part>
</corpname> and
<persname>
<part>Charles H. Wesley</part>
</persname>, president of
<corpname>
<part>Central State University</part>
</corpname>,
<geogname>
<part>Wilberforce, Ohio.</part>
</geogname> Other
<corpname>
<part>ASNLH</part>
</corpname> and
<corpname>
<part>ASALH</part>
</corpname> file correspondents include
<persname>
<part>Clarence Bacote</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Andrew F. Brimmer</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Herman Dreer</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Mervyn M. Dymally</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Merl R. Eppse</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>John Hope Franklin</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Jacqueline Goggin</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Adelaide C. Gulliver</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Harvey Jackson</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Luther P. Jackson</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Ulysses G. Lee</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Rayford W. Logan</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Paul McStallworth</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Louis R. Mehlinger</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>August Meier</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>M. Sammye Miller</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Benjamin Quarles</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Lawrence Dunbar Reddick</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>William P. Robinson</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Patricia W. Romero</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Charles W. Thomas</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Harcourt A. Tynes</part>
</persname>, and
<persname>
<part>Raleigh Wilson.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="pub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Public Interest
Organizations</ref> series documents Greene's civil rights and social activism
and includes files on the
<corpname>
<part>Missouri Advisory Committee to the United States Commission
on Civil Rights</part>
</corpname>,
<corpname>
<part>Missouri Association for Social Welfare (MASW),</part>
</corpname>
and the
<corpname>
<part>Missouri Commission on Human Rights.</part>
</corpname>
Correspondents represented in
<corpname>
<part>MASW</part>
</corpname> file of the series include
<persname>
<part>Mary E. Brooks</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Edward Parsons</part>
</persname>,
<persname>
<part>Richard E. Risk</part>
</persname>, and
<persname>
<part>Bert Shulimson.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>Developed from research at
<corpname>
<part>Columbia University,</part>
</corpname> Greene's
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Negro in Colonial New England 1620-1776,</part>
</title> first
published in 1941, is still considered a definitive work on the subject and has
been republished in several editions. His thesis and dissertation versions of
this work are filed with related correspondence spanning 1941-1980 in the
<ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and
Writings</ref> series. Als included in the series are drafts and correspondence
related to the unpublished "Abolition of Slavery in New England 1688-1776" and
speeches and articles by Greene on African Americans in
<geogname>
<part>New England,</part>
</geogname> including an especially strong file of
writings on black soldiers, sailors, and military units of Revolutionary War
era
<geogname>
<part>Connecticut</part>
</geogname>,
<geogname>
<part>Massachusetts</part>
</geogname>, and
<geogname>
<part>Rhode Island.</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>Missouri</part>
</geogname> material in the Speeches and Writings
series includes files on
<title localtype="simple">
<part> The Negro in the Making of Missouri and Missouri's Black
Heritage,</part>
</title> monographs cowritten by Greene. Greene's service between
1928-1933 as a research assistant and field representative to
<persname>
<part>Carter G. Woodson</part>
</persname> is documented in several versions
of Greene's transcribed diaries filed in the Speeches and Writings series.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">Addition</ref>
includes general correspondence and an exchange of letters between Greene and
his wife dating 1942-1954. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, address books, clippings, biographical material,
legal papers, printed matter, concert programs, and miscellaneous material.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Memoranda, minutes of meetings, announcements, vitae, reports,
grant proposals, correspondence, clippings, case files, constitutions, course
and curricula development material, and miscellaneous material relating largely
to Lincoln University. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence sent and received with attached and related
material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, bibliographies, fliers, reports, newsletters,
newspapers, news releases, clippings, publishers' catalogs and brochures,
student writings, yearbooks, printed matter, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, manuscript articles, short stories, poems,
transcriptions of archival documents, biographical material, galleys,
subscription and circulation lists, brochures, and miscellaneous material.
Later material relates to reprint permissions and microfilming projects.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Reports, correspondence, topical files, photostats of archival
documents, draft books, statistical material, legal documents, and
miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, minutes, reports, proposals, constitutions,
financial statements, printed matter, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, minutes, plans, newsletters, press releases,
reports, statements, membership lists, clippings, draft legislation,
directories, printed matter, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Interviews and panel discussions arranged chronologically; drafts
of speeches by Greene arranged alphabetically by title and those by others
organized chronologically; drafts and published versions of articles, books,
dissertations, diaries, poems, and song lyrics, mostly by Greene, with
correspondence, reviews, plans of work, and related material arranged
alphabetically by type of material and then by title.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, photostats of archival documents, topical files,
notes, printed matter, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Charts related to a project tracking references to
African-Americans in textbooks and United States Colored Troops muster roll
fragments.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Jefferson Patterson (1891-1977) span the years from 1824 to 1981, with the
bulk of the papers concentrated in the period from 1921 to 1977. The majority of the
items document Patterson's career in the foreign service on five continents, North
America, South America, Europe, Africa, and Asia, from 1921 to 1952 and 1956 to 1958.
One of Patterson's most notable achievements as a diplomat was his instrumental role in
arranging a ceasefire between Israel and Egypt in January 1949 during the Palestine War.
The papers consist of eight series: <ref target="dia" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Diaries </ref>, <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers
</ref>, <ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Correspondence </ref>,
<ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Subject File </ref>, <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Speeches and Writings </ref>, <ref target="mis" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Miscellany </ref>, <ref target="Add1">2018 Addition</ref>, and <ref target="ove" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Oversize </ref>.</p>
<p>Transcripts of Patterson's <ref target="dia" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> diaries
</ref>, 1928-1930, document his personal and professional activities during his last
three years as a junior embassy official in Ankara, Turkey. There are two copies of the
1928 diary.</p>
<p>The papers of Patterson's immediate family make up the bulk of the <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref> series, 1824-1978. The
majority of this series consists of family letters to and from Jefferson Patterson, the
papers of his parents, Julia Shaw Patterson Carnell and Frank Jefferson Patterson, and
his sister, Mary Patterson Davidson. Patterson's letters to his mother comprise over
half of her papers and provide a detailed account of his life as a foreign service
officer from 1921 through 1950. Much of Jefferson Patterson's family correspondence
relates to his social activities and obligations as a diplomat. Letters to his mother
describing Berlin, Germany, during the outbreak of World War II and his duties as head
of the Prisoner of War Section at the American embassy are especially noteworthy. He was
responsible for ensuring that the prisoners of war of France, Belgium, and Britain were
properly treated according to the rules of the Geneva Convention.</p>
<p>The papers of Frank Patterson include personal correspondence and financial and legal
papers relating to the National Cash Register Company, which he owned with his brother,
John. Letters written by Mary Davidson concern family matters and news about her travels
and the various military posts where she and her husband, Major General Howard C.
Davidson, were stationed, including Montgomery, Alabama; Fort Leavenworth, Kansas;
Riverside, California; Washington, D.C.; Honolulu, Hawaii; and London, England. Also
included in the papers of Julia Carnell and Mary Davidson are letters of condolence
regarding the death of Patterson's younger brother Stuart who was killed in 1918 at
Dayton, Ohio, while testing an airplane. The airstrip was subsequently named
Wright-Patterson Field in honor of Stuart Patterson and the Wright brothers. </p>
<p>The <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref> also
contain typescripts of letters written by Jefferson Patterson and his sister. The
typescripts were arranged previously in notebooks in chronological order. The original
order has been retained, and the typescripts are filed with Patterson and Davidson's
papers. The series also provides background on the family's early settlement in Dayton,
Ohio, and include letters of Patterson's grandfathers, George W. Shaw and Colonel
Jefferson Patterson. Noteworthy correspondence collected by the family, located in the
folder "Miscellaneous" (container 14), includes a letter of John C. Calhoun to a Major
Austin inviting him to assist in the evaluation of West Point cadets, 1824; a letter of
William H. Seward to the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee regarding the
application of treaties to foreign countries and United States ports, 1864; and a letter
by William T. Sherman concerning the importance of doing one's duty in "any phase in
which fortune may find you," 1878. The general scrapbooks in the <ref target="mis" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Miscellany </ref> series also include family
papers.</p>
<p>The <ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Correspondence </ref> series,
1909-1966, consists of incoming and outgoing letters pertaining to Patterson's personal
and professional interests, including typed excerpts, 1921-1949, of Patterson's letters
pertaining chiefly to his foreign service activities while stationed at various
embassies. The excerpts, arranged chronologically, provide no indication to whom
Patterson was writing. Probably used by Patterson to write his books about his
diplomatic career, these excerpts approximate diary entries and describe his daily life
in the various locations where he was stationed, such as Peking, China; Bogota,
Columbia; Ankara, Turkey; Washington, D.C.; Breslau, Poland; Oslo, Norway; Berlin,
Germany; Lima, Peru; Brussels, Belgium; and Cairo, Egypt. Among the more prominent and
frequent correspondents in this series are William H. Beck, Katharine Kennedy Brown,
George H. Chaney, J. Rives Childs, James Aloysius Farley, Stanton Griffis, James Hugh
Keeley, Jr., John L. King, Harry L. Munger, Maxwell M. Rabb, S. Pinkney Tuck, and Edward
D. Vance. </p>
<p>The <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Subject File, </ref>
1946-1978, consists primarily of correspondence, memoranda, invitations, and receipts
pertaining mainly to Patterson's life after his retirement. The series reflects his
interest in art and sports, his philanthropic contributions to various organizations and
causes, his active involvement with the Republican party, and the operation of his farm
in St. Leonard, Maryland, where he raised tobacco and Aberdeen/Angus cattle.</p>
<p>The <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and Writings File,
</ref> 1923-1971, contains speeches, book drafts, notes and related material, and other
writings. The majority of the series is made up of drafts and notes of Patterson's books
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Diplomatic Duty and Diversion</part>
</title> and <title localtype="simple">
<part>Diplomatic Terminus</part>
</title> and an unpublished work, "Flashbacks and Reflections."</p>
<p>The final series, <ref target="mis"> Miscellany, </ref> 1894-1977, contains
correspondence, financial and legal papers, notes and recollections, academic notebooks,
and scrapbooks. The academic file consists mainly of notebooks documenting Patterson's
business and law studies at Harvard University. The ambassador and diplomatic service
file, which overlaps with the <ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Correspondence </ref> and <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Subject File </ref> series, includes a wide variety of material, such as clippings,
correspondence, and printed matter documenting Patterson's personal and professional
activities. Much of the material in the ambassador file relates to Patterson's service
as United States representative to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans,
1950-1952. His notes and recollections provide a vivid account of the work of that
committee. Financial and legal papers document Patterson's personal business interests
and expenditures.</p>
<p>The <ref target="Add1">2018 Addition</ref> spans from 1909 to 1981 with the bulk of the
items concentrated from 1941 to 1977. Papers in the <ref target="Add1">2018
Addition</ref> complement the initial portion of the collection and consist mainly of
correspondence, family papers, and scrapbooks. The correspondence and scrapbooks pertain
chiefly to Patterson's personal and professional endeavors. The majority of the
correspondence, 1953-1955, relates to Patterson's career and his wish to be considered
for another diplomatic posting. The scrapbooks also include letters pertaining to the
books Patterson wrote about his diplomatic career. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Typescripts of diaries chronicling Patterson's activities as a foreign service
official in Ankara, Turkey. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, typescripts of letters, financial and legal papers, clippings, and
printed matter relating to various members of Patterson's family. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, and cablegrams, between Patterson and his colleagues,
friends, government officials, and the general public relating to his diplomatic
duties and his personal activities. Also included are typed excerpts of letters
written by Patterson. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, invitations, photographs, bills, receipts, itineraries,
photographs, newspaper clippings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, speeches, book drafts, poetry and miscellaneous writings, notes
and related material, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Correspondence, memoranda, financial and legal papers, notes and recollections,
student notebooks, appointment books, address books, passports and visas, medical
and military papers, certificates, calling cards, scrapbooks, and printed matter.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, family papers, invitations, notes and jottings, photographs,
poetry, scrapbooks, newspaper clippings, printed matter, and other material
relating to Patterson's personal and professional activities.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>Vincent Leonard Price, Jr., (1911-1993)</part>
</persname> span the years 1883-1992, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the
period 1932-1992. They document his life as an actor, art collector and critic, writer,
lecturer, and gourmet cook. The interconnectedness of his activities and interests is
evident in this collection. Price got his start as an actor on the <geogname>
<part>London</part>
</geogname> stage while he was studying art history at the <corpname>
<part>University of London.</part>
</corpname> Throughout his life, Price was a strong supporter of the arts and used his
celebrity as an actor as a tool to bring art into people's lives. He used the money
gained through acting to buy art. He lent works from his art collection and donated many
of them to galleries and museums. He served on arts councils and wrote on art and
cooking. He lectured on his life as an actor and on art. He narrated an academy award
winning film on <persname>
<part>Chagall.</part>
</persname> He appeared as an art expert on the television quiz show "The $64,000
Challenge" and hosted a cooking show. He exploited his fame as the star of horror films
to sell products ranging from credit cards to submarine sandwiches. Although Price
achieved fame by playing villains, early in his career he was considered a matinee
idol.</p>
<p>Price's papers are arranged into six series: <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref>; <ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> General Correspondence </ref>; <ref target="sea" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Sears, Roebuck and Company Files </ref>; <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Speeches and Writings Files </ref>; <ref target="sta" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Stage, Screen and Studio Files
</ref>; and a <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Subject File. </ref>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref> series,
1883-1992, consists of correspondence and other material grouped under the names of
family members. The correspondence is arranged chronologically and consists primarily of
letters received from members of <famname>
<part>Vincent Price's family</part>
</famname>: his wives, actress <persname>
<part>Edith Barrett</part>
</persname>, costume designer <persname>
<part>Mary Grant</part>
</persname>, and actress <persname>
<part>Coral Browne</part>
</persname>; his son <persname>
<part>Vincent Barrett ("Barrett")</part>
</persname>; his daughter <persname>
<part>Mary Victoria ("Toria")</part>
</persname>; his sisters <persname>
<part>Harriet Fenton ("Hat")</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Laura Louise Gay ("Lollie")</part>
</persname>, as well as other relatives. Also in this series are letters from Vincent
Price ("Bink") to his parents in the 1930s describing his European tour with the <corpname>
<part>Yale University Glee Club</part>
</corpname>, his art studies at the <corpname>
<part>University of London</part>
</corpname>, and his experiences in <geogname>
<part>Hollywood</part>
</geogname> working on his first film.</p>
<p>While correspondence relating to specific activities is filed by topic in the relevant
series, the <ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> General Correspondence
</ref> series, 1938-1992, is arranged in chronological order and documents Price's
friendships and the wide variety of his interests and activities. The major portion of
this series consists of letters received, although attached to much of the
correspondence from the 1960s are copies of Price's handwritten responses or the
responses typed by his secretary, <persname>
<part>Wawona Hartwig.</part>
</persname> This correspondence includes letters spanning fifty years from friends such
as college roommate <persname>
<part>Edmund Thomas ("Ted")</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Cecil Baldwin</part>
</persname>, whom he met while teaching at <corpname>
<part>Riverdale Country Day School;</part>
</corpname> official letters requesting appearances or proposing other activities; and
mail from the public relating to his acting, writings, and art expertise. Prominent
correspondents include <persname>
<part>Letitia Baldrige</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Charles Collingwood</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Joan Crawford</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Henry Dreyfuss</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Deanna Durbin</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Alec Guinness</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Helen Hayes</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Sam Jaffe</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Roddy McDowell</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Stanley Marcus</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Perry Rathbone</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Joan Rivers</part>
</persname>, and <persname>
<part>Mary Wickes.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="sea" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Sears, Roebuck and Company
</ref> series documents Price's activities as a consultant to this firm from 1962 to
1977. As part of his work with <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname>, he formed <corpname>
<part>Vincent Price Enterprises</part>
</corpname> along with <persname>
<part>Lester Salkow</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Harry Sundheim.</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Mary Grant Price</part>
</persname> was also active in <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> ventures. The major focus of his work involved the <corpname>
<part>Vincent Price Collection of Fine Art</part>
</corpname> which Price put together as original art for sale in <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> stores. Price saw this venture as a part of his efforts to bring art to
people in their daily lives. As part of this project he travelled throughout the world
buying original works of art. <persname>
<part>Mary Grant Price</part>
</persname> did the framing of the art work. Shows of selected pieces were sent to <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> stores throughout the country at prices ranging from as little as
twenty-five dollars to ten thousand dollars. Vincent Price made personal appearances at
many of the art shows. Other activities he undertook for <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> included the development of reproductions for a decorating line called
National Treasures and other merchandise such as a line of men's toiletries, chocolates,
and a Bible illustrated with the works of <persname>
<part>Michelangelo.</part>
</persname> He also made public appearances and advertising commercials promoting
various <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> products and ventures. Correspondence with <persname>
<part>Julius</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Lessing J. Rosenwald</part>
</persname>, artists such as <persname>
<part>Streeter Blair</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Peter Hurd</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Harold Towne</part>
</persname>, and <persname>
<part>Andrew Wyeth</part>
</persname>, and with the major figures involved in planning and administering these <corpname>
<part>Sears</part>
</corpname> activities is also included.</p>
<p>Price's writings on a wide range of subjects are contained in the <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Speeches and Writings Files, </ref> 1931-1991.
His books include a popular cookbook written with his wife, an autobiographical memoir
of his experiences with art, a tribute to his favorite dog, a book on American art, and
a discussion of monsters written with his son. The books file contains original drafts,
correspondence, research notes, and clippings, with the exception of <title localtype="simple">
<part>I Like What I Know,</part>
</title> which does not contain a draft of the text. The articles file covers topics
ranging from his acting career to art, travel, and cooking. Price also wrote forewords
and introductions to cookbooks, art books, and biographies. The columns file relates to
the newspaper column on art which Price wrote from 1966 to 1970 for the <corpname>
<part>Chicago Tribune-New York News syndicate;</part>
</corpname> it contains his drafts, notes, and related correspondence. The poetry file
contains poems Price wrote throughout his life, many jotted on scraps of paper, the back
of script pages, and airplane boarding passes. Poetry was a common form of expression
for several generations of the Price family. The <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref> series includes poems written by his father
and his son. The lectures and addresses file contains the texts of talks Price gave at
specific events as well as various versions of the lectures he performed on tour.</p>
<p>Encompassing many aspects of the entertainment business, the <ref target="sta" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Stage, Screen, and Studio Files, </ref>
1935-1992, chronicle Price's career as an actor and entertainer. Price performed on the
stage, in films, on radio, and on television. He served as narrator in live performances
and in the studio. He made commercials for a variety of products and public service
announcements for many organizations. He went on lecture tours and made numerous
additional public appearances, serving as master of ceremonies at awards functions and
fashion shows, as art judge and auctioneer, as celebrity chef, and as guest lecturer on
cruises. He attended a great variety of functions. This series is organized according to
type of activity and is then arranged either alphabetically by title of project or
chronologically. Files contain scripts, programs, correspondence, clippings, and other
documents.</p>
<p>Included in the films section of this series are files on the majority of Price's motion
pictures. Although Price was renowned for his roles in horror pictures, his film career
had many more dimensions. There are some gaps in coverage, primarily in films from the
1940s, including <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Laura</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Leave Her to Heaven</part>
</title>, and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Shock.</part>
</title> Contained in the files, however, are materials relating to his first movie,
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Service de Luxe</part>
</title>; his films for <corpname>
<part>American International Pictures</part>
</corpname>; <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Theatre of Blood</part>
</title>, the project in which he met and acted with his future wife, <persname>
<part>Coral Browne</part>
</persname>; <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Vincent</part>
</title>, in which he narrated a film short by <persname>
<part>Tim Burton</part>
</persname> about a boy who idolized Vincent Price; and Disney's <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Great Mouse Detective</part>
</title>, in which he provided the voice of the villain, <persname>
<part>Professor Ratigan.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The lectures section of the <ref target="sta" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Stage,
Screen, and Studio Files </ref> provides a chronological record of the presentations
Price conducted several months each year, such as "Three American Voices," "Dear Theo",
"The Enjoyment of Great Art," and "The Villains Still Pursue Me." He lectured primarily
at colleges, women's clubs, and in town lecture series. As a lecturer he often attended
dinners, visited art galleries, and met with students. For a time he was the highest
paid lecturer in the <geogname>
<part>United States.</part>
</geogname>
</p>
<p>Price's extensive work in the theater, on the <geogname>
<part>London</part>
</geogname> stage, on <geogname>
<part>Broadway</part>
</geogname>, and in summer stock is recorded in the plays section of this series. The
files primarily contain programs, correspondence, and clippings. Included is <persname>
<part>Orson Welles's</part>
</persname>
<corpname>
<part>Mercury Theatre</part>
</corpname> production of <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Shoemaker's Holiday</part>
</title>. Price married his costar <persname>
<part>Edith Barrett</part>
</persname>. There are extensive files on the musical, <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Darling of the Day</part>
</title>, which played on <geogname>
<part>Broadway</part>
</geogname> in 1968, and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Diversions and Delights</part>
</title>, the one-man play in which Price portrayed <persname>
<part>Oscar Wilde</part>
</persname> from 1977 to 1982.</p>
<p>The radio section covers much of Price's radio work, including appearances on programs
in the <geogname>
<part>United States</part>
</geogname> and <geogname>
<part>England</part>
</geogname> and on voice tracks for <corpname>
<part>Voice of America</part>
</corpname> programs. Missing, however, are materials from early dramatic broadcasts on
which Price performed, such as "Escape," "Suspense," and "The Saint." </p>
<p>Starting in the early days of the medium, Vincent Price made over a thousand appearances
on television in all types of programming. As the television section of this series
illustrates, he performed in dramas, situation comedies, variety shows, game shows, talk
shows, and programs for children. He played serious roles as well as humorous
characterizations of his film persona on British as well as American television.
Documents contained in this section include his official statements regarding his
activities on "The $64,000 Challenge" made during the quiz show scandal investigations,
the transcript of <persname>
<part>Edward R. Murrow's</part>
</persname> interview with him in his art-filled home for the "Person to Person"
program, and the discussion topics for his many appearances on the <corpname>
<part>NBC</part>
</corpname> program "The Tonight Show" from the 1960s through the 1980s.</p>
<p>The miscellaneous files section of the <ref target="sta" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Stage, Screen, and Studio files </ref> contains general material
relating to Price's career as a performer. While publicity relating to a specific
project is filed with that project, the publicity file in this section contains more
general and personal publicity. Similarly, contracts and correspondence from agents
relating to a specific project are filed with that project, but general material from
agents is filed here under business materials. </p>
<p>The <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Subject File, </ref>
1920-1992, is arranged alphabetically by topic and contains files relating to Price's
personal art collection and his involvement with various organizations, museums, and
academic institutions. There are files on the schools he attended in <geogname>
<part>St. Louis</part>
</geogname> and on <corpname>
<part>Yale University</part>
</corpname> and the <corpname>
<part>Courtauld Institute of Art</part>
</corpname> at the <corpname>
<part>University of London</part>
</corpname>. There are also files on his work to support and promote the art of Native
Americans. Price served on the <corpname>
<part>Indian Arts and Crafts Board of the Interior Department</part>
</corpname> for over a decade and sponsored the Vincent Price awards in creative writing
through the <corpname>
<part>Institute of American Indian Arts.</part>
</corpname> A few appointment books and calendars provide insight into his busy life for
the years covered. In addition, under the heading "Staff" are memoranda and reports from
office staff to Price to keep him apprised of news and activities relating to his
projects and schedule while he was filming, on art buying trips, or on lecture
tours.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Personal correspondence, fan mail, requests, proposals, and other correspondence
of a general nature. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, charts, critiques, planning and research
notes, purchasing records, scheduling and shipping records, promotional materials,
clippings, exhibit brochures and catalogs, and other printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph and typewritten manuscripts, notes and jottings, research notes, related
correspondence, and clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Scripts, programs, playbills, correspondence, telegrams, schedules and
itineraries, contracts, clippings, storyboards, publicity and promotional
materials, and other records relating to Price's acting roles and other
performances and appearances as an entertainer and celebrity. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, financial records, receipts, brochures,
appointment books and calendars, certificates, notes, clippings, printed matter,
and miscellaneous materials. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Oversize material consisting of large illustrated letters, posters, programs,
scrapbooks, and a computer printout. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>Theodore Roosevelt Jr. (1887-1944)</part>
</persname>, which include correspondence and other papers of his wife <persname>
<part>Eleanor Butler Roosevelt</part>
</persname>, cover the period 1780-1962, bulking largest between 1920 and 1944. The
collection consists of <ref target="dia" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Diaries</ref>, <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Family
Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General
Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Special
Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="let" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Letters of
Condolence and Congratulation</ref>, <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Subject File</ref>, <ref target="spee" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speech, Article, and Book File</ref>, <ref target="pri" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Printed Matter</ref>, and <ref target="pap" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Papers of Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919)</ref>.
The last segment of the papers contains correspondence of <persname>
<part>President Theodore Roosevelt</part>
</persname>, including nine letters addressed to <persname>
<part>Marcus Alonzo (Mark) Hanna.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., was not a consistent diarist. However, the <ref target="dia" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">diaries</ref> he did maintain, written primarily
during the 1920s, are significant for their observations on important events and
individuals. There are numerous entries concerning his activities as assistant secretary
of the navy and his relationships with <persname>
<part>Secretary of the Navy Edwin Denby</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>President Warren G. Harding</part>
</persname>, and others. The diaries, which are handwritten as well as in typescript,
contain notations and deletions made by <persname>
<part>Eleanor Roosevelt </part>
</persname>after her husband's death.</p>
<p>Roosevelt maintained a large correspondence with family members, often writing
diary-like letters. Other significant <ref target="fam" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">family correspondence</ref> includes the letters he exchanged
with his father concerning political events, particularly after 1903.</p>
<p>Correspondence of Theodore and <persname>
<part>Eleanor Butler Roosevelt</part>
</persname> with prominent associates and friends is contained chiefly in the <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Special Correspondence</ref> series.
Among their numerous correspondents are <persname>
<part>Joseph</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Stewart Alsop</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>William Edgar Borah</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Pearl S. Buck</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Chiang Kai-shek</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Calvin Coolidge</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Dwight D. Eisenhower</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Felix Frankfurter</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Robert Frost</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Edward Grey</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Warren G. Harding</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Charles Dewey Hilles</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Herbert Hoover</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Frank Knox</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Vachel Lindsay</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Walter Lippmann</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Douglas MacArthur</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>George C. Marshall</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>W. Somerset Maugham</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>John J. Pershing</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Gifford Pinchot</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Manuel Luis Quezon</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Eleanor Roosevelt</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Franklin D. Roosevelt</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Elihu Root</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Henry Lewis Stimson</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Arthur H. Vandenberg</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>Walter Francis White</part>
</persname>, <persname>
<part>William Allen White</part>
</persname>, and <persname>
<part>Alexander Woollcott.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="gen" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General Correspondence</ref>
and the <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Subject File</ref> contain
much information about social, political, and intellectual currents in the 1920s and
1930s. Prohibition, military preparedness, "Cousin Franklin" <persname>
<part>(Franklin D. Roosevelt)</part>
</persname>, political campaigns, socialism, and veterans' benefits are among the topics
discussed. As a government official, military officer, and son of a former president,
Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., received letters from ordinary citizens as well as prominent
individuals. These letters and Roosevelt's replies constitute a rich source of
information about the period.</p>
<p>Among the major facets of Roosevelt's career that are documented in the <ref target="sub" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Subject File</ref> are his activities
in organizing the <corpname>
<part>American Legion</part>
</corpname> in 1919; his role in the presidential election campaign of <persname>
<part>Leonard Wood</part>
</persname>, 1919-1920; his participation in the <corpname>
<part>Washington Conference on the Limitation of Armament</part>
</corpname>, 1921-1922; his race against <persname>
<part>Alfred Emanuel Smith</part>
</persname> for the governorship of New York, 1924; his expeditions to <geogname>
<part>Africa</part>
</geogname> and the <geogname>
<part>Far East</part>
</geogname>, 1924-1939; and his military participation in both world wars, which led to
numerous medals and decorations, including the Croix de Guerre and (posthumously) the
Congressional Medal of Honor.</p>
<p>Roosevelt was in much demand as a speaker and appeared before many veterans groups and
political gatherings. During the period between the world wars, he regularly campaigned
throughout the nation for Republican presidential nominees. The <ref target="spee" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speech, Article, and Book File</ref> contains the
texts of many such speeches, as well as speech requests and comments. It also contains
speeches and other material relating to his role as governor of <geogname>
<part>Puerto Rico</part>
</geogname>, 1929-1932, and governor general of the <geogname>
<part>Philippines</part>
</geogname>, 1932-1933. Roosevelt's many magazine articles of the 1920s and 1930s
usually concerned travel, the out-of-doors, or World War I and are preserved in
typescript form in the <ref target="spee" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Speech,
Article, and Book File</ref>. On the other hand, there is little more than
correspondence to represent the many books he wrote, although there are drafts, reviews,
clippings, legal papers, and research material relating to <persname>
<part>Eleanor Butler Roosevelt's</part>
</persname> book, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Day Before Yesterday</part>
</title> (1959).</p>
<p>The <ref target="mis" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Miscellany</ref> file contains
a variety of papers, including an autograph collection, items relating to the <famname>
<part>Roosevelt family,</part>
</famname> and typewritten transcripts of many letters from <persname>
<part>Theodore Roosevelt, Sr.</part>
</persname> and Jr., and <persname>
<part>Eleanor Butler Roosevelt.</part>
</persname> A fairly complete file of clippings on the activities of the two Theodore
Roosevelts is located among the <ref target="pri" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Printed Matter</ref>. Since the clippings are unmounted and in poor condition,
photocopies are available for reader use.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Handwritten diaries and typescripts of diaries. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received, with enclosures, and copies of letters sent. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence of Theodore Roosevelt Jr., and Eleanor Butler Roosevelt with
prominent individuals and friends. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters of congratulation to Theodore and Eleanor Butler Roosevelt on the marriage
of their daughter, Grace, to William McMillan, and condolence letters to Eleanor
Butler Roosevelt on the death of her husband, and her son Quentin. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, supplemented by reports, transcriptions, copies of speeches, and
printed material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph, typewritten, and bound volumes of speeches, with related
correspondence, followed by articles and material relating to <title localtype="simple">
<part>Day Before Yesterday</part>
</title> by Eleanor Butler Roosevelt. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph, typewritten, and printed material including guest lists, financial and
household records, awards, certificates, and correspondence. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Newspaper clippings, photocopies of clippings, books, and monographs. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters to and from Theodore Roosevelt and one speech. Arranged by type of
material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>John J. Sirica (1904-1992)</part>
</persname> span the years 1932-1986 with the majority of the papers concentrated
between 1957 and 1986. The bulk of the papers documents Sirica's career as judge of the <corpname>
<part>United States District Court for the District of Columbia</part>
</corpname>, 1957-1986. The papers consist of six series: <ref target="cor" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Correspondence </ref>, <ref target="usd" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> United States District Court File</ref>, <ref target="spe" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Speeches and Writings File </ref>,
