<p>Photographs. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of William Edgar Borah (1865-1940) span the period 1905-1940, with the bulk
of the material from 1912-1940. The collection constitutes the record of his career in
the Senate, which began in 1907 and ended with his death in 1940, at the midpoint of his
sixth consecutive term. The papers cover virtually every aspect of Borah's political
life and include extensive files on antitrust legislation, constitutional
interpretation, and foreign policy. There is little in the collection about his youth or
his career as an attorney in Idaho, and most of his Senate office files for the years
from 1907 to 1912 were destroyed when his office was moved from the basement of the
Capitol to the Senate office building. A collection of Borah papers at the Idaho State
Historical Society treats his law practice and political activities from 1890 to 1907,
and a collection of scrapbooks at the University of Idaho Library covers the period
1904-1940. A microfilm copy of the scrapbooks is held by the Library of Congress.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="genofffile"> General Office File
</ref>, the largest series, is organized by subject and correspondent within
twelve-month increments. Files on politics, Russia, disarmament, and agriculture reveal
the range of Borah's interests, although files that appear to be commonplace, such as
invitations and requests for speeches, often contain significant correspondence on
substantive issues. Significant topical categories include files titled "documents,"
containing correspondence with constituents concerning government publications;
"newspapers," referring to articles in newspapers and periodicals on Borah; and
"manuscripts," relating to papers sent to Borah by authors seeking assistance in
publishing their work.</p>
<p>The World Court, the League of Nations, military activities in Latin America, routine
army matters, legislation, politics, the Red Scare, universal military training, and
Russia are topics that dominate the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="genofffile"> General Office File </ref> from the World War I era to the
Depression. Among the principal themes in the papers from the 1920s are Borah's attempts
to secure American recognition of the Soviet Union, his support of measures that would
outlaw war, and his reactions to domestic political and economical unrest. Material
relating to Franklin D. Roosevelt, the New Deal, and the National Recovery
Administration take up an increasingly larger portion of the files during the 1930s, as
do subjects such as China's war with Japan, the Lausanne Settlement, and neutrality
legislation.</p>
<p>Correspondents upon whom Borah relied for advice on state and local political issues
include Evan Evans, James H. Gipson, Frank Robert Gooding, John W. Hart, James H.
Hawley, Ray McKaig, and Irvin E. Rockwell. Files on topics such as politics,
antilynching, Russia, the Justice Department, treaties, and the World Court include
correspondence with Jane Addams, Edwin Borchard, Henry M. Dawes, Leonidas Carstarphen
Dyer, Hamilton Fish, Samuel Gompers, Norman Hapgood, Will H. Hays, John Haynes Holmes,
James Weldon Johnson, Frank B. Kellogg, Frank Knox, Henry Cabot Lodge, Amos Pinchot,
Gifford Pinchot, Raymond Robins, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Thomas Joseph Walsh, William
Allen White, and Woodrow Wilson.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>
contains material on a wide variety of topics, although most of it relates to Borah's
specific legislative and political interests. Included are important files pertaining to
treaties, appointments, Department of State budgets, and the major problems of American
foreign policy in the era between the two world wars. The Subject File complements the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="pubopinfile"> Public Opinion File
</ref>, which contains letters from the public on matters such as neutrality
legislation, the World Court, the embargo of Spain, and New Deal reform efforts.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speestatartfile"> Speeches,
Statements, and Articles File </ref> is perhaps the most comprehensive series for
exploring Borah's positions on public issues, for his attitudes are documented more
thoroughly in his speeches and public statements than in his characteristically terse
correspondence. Borah regarded public speaking and debate as a critical ingredient of
public life. His speeches, press releases, and public statements were prepared with
meticulous care, and many of the research materials that formed the basis of his
speeches are organized in subject files within this series.</p>
<p>Borah's activities in behalf of Idaho constituents are documented throughout the
collection, but four series representing major aspects of constituent casework are
particularly salient for understanding this feature of his career. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="penfile"> Pension File </ref> and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="vetclaifile"> Veterans Claims File </ref>
deal exclusively with the problem of individual constituents; the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="patrofile"> Patronage File </ref> and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="landutilfile"> Land Utilization File </ref> contain
materials relating to broad social and political matters as well as assistance to
individuals. The Land Utilization File ranges from applications for homesteads to
research materials for legislation pertaining to the public domain. Many of the
constituent requests in these files were merely routed to the appropriate executive
agency for attention, but Borah occasionally noted his recommendations and policy
judgements when transmitting a request.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="borapres"> Borah for President
Committee </ref> series illustrates the steps taken by a small coterie of loyal
admirers to obtain the 1936 Republican presidential nomination for Borah. Much of the
correspondence consists of exchanges between Carl G. Bachmann, chairman of the
committee, and various contributors to the campaign. Rounding out the collection is a
small group of correspondence and other <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corresGrac"> papers of Grace Hileman </ref>, Borah's secretary. The
correspondence, largely personal in nature, touches on matters of interest to Borah.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and carbons of letters sent, memoranda, reports, newspaper
clippings, legislative bills, and miscellaneous material. </p>

Borah containing quotations from the founding fathers, facts concerning their
lives from contemporary biographies, and data Borah extracted from newspapers,
periodicals, and books.</p>

<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Irving Robert Kaufman (1910-1992) span the years 1934-1992 with the vast
bulk of material dating after 1949, when Kaufman was appointed to the federal judiciary.
The papers document his professional activities while serving for over forty years as a
federal judge, first as a district judge and then as an appellate judge for the second
circuit. Included are speeches and writings, correspondence, scrapbooks, material from
American Bar Association committees that Kaufman chaired or served on, items from the
Juvenile Justice Standards Project which he chaired, conference materials, court papers,
and subject files. Personal and family papers are few.</p>
<p>The first two series are comprised of papers from Kaufman's two judgeships: the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="southdisNY"> Southern District of New York
</ref> (1949-1961) and the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="seccircourtapp"> Second Circuit Court of Appeals </ref> (1961-1992). Each
series is divided into two subseries: Court Papers and Office Files. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="southdisNYcourtpap"> Court Papers </ref>
from the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="southdisNY"> Southern District
of New York </ref> include transcripts of testimony, charges to juries, opinions,
sentences, and appeals. Fourteen of Kaufman's district court cases appear in the Case
Files, including two of his most famous and controversial cases: <emph render="italic">United States v. Rosenberg</emph> (1951 espionage trial of Julius and Ethel
Rosenberg) and <emph render="italic">United States v. Bonanno</emph> (1959 trial of
reputed gangsters who had met in Apalachin, New York). Materials related to these and
other cases are also in the scrapbooks, the final series in the papers. Additional
material concerning <title localtype="simple">
<part>United States v. Rosenberg</part>
</title> is under the case name in a <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="southdisNYofffile"> Office Files </ref> for the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="southdisNY"> Southern District of New York </ref> are
quite small and consist of material from professional organizations, committees,
conferences, and seminars. A collection of speeches, mostly written by others and used
as a reference file by Kaufman, relate in large part to communism.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="seccircourtappcourpap"> Court Papers
</ref> of the second series, the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="seccircourtapp"> Second Circuit Court of Appeals </ref>, are very few. The
two case files present are composed primarily of memoranda between the judges. Also
included are affirmances, dockets, and opinions. The extensive <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="seccircourtappoffiles"> Office Files </ref> subseries for
the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="seccircourtapp"> Court of Appeals
</ref> is comprised of Kaufman's papers from American Bar Association committees, the
Juvenile Justice Standards Program, professional organizations, conferences and
seminars, materials concerning the operation of the courthouse and the courts of the
second circuit, reference papers, and correspondence with other judges. There is
substantial correspondence between Kaufman and Supreme Court Chief Justice Warren E.
Burger and Justice Tom C. Clark. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>
contains most of Kaufman's correspondence with various individuals. Substantial
correspondence is present between Kaufman and his longtime friend Simon H. Rifkind.
There are also files on the Harvard Law School fellowship named in Kaufman's honor, the
Presidential Medal of Freedom bestowed on Kaufman, several law schools, news clippings,
nonprofessional organizations, and topics of interest to Kaufman, such as drug abuse and
cameras in the courtroom.</p>
<p>Kaufman's prolific writing was aided by his law clerks, as memoranda to them indicate.
He published widely and delivered many speeches. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref> series has been
split into several chronologically arranged sections: articles, book reviews, letters to
the editor, research material, and speeches. Correspondence with publishers, readers, or
event organizers is often included.</p>
<p>The final series is a set of three <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="scrapb"> scrapbooks </ref> dating from 1951 to 1970. The books are filled
with news clippings, most dating from Kaufman's service on the district court. The first
volume and part of the second are devoted to the Rosenbergs' trial, appeals, and
execution. With the help of a clipping service, Kaufman assembled items from many
diverse sources. Other cases highlighted in the scrapbooks are <emph render="italic">United States v. Bonanno</emph> and <emph render="italic">Taylor v. Board of
Education</emph>, the 1961 school desegregation case from New Rochelle, New York.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Robert Alphonso Taft (1889-1953) span the years
1885-1980, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the period 1938-1953. The
papers have been organized in the following series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="fampap">
Family
Papers
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="persfile">
Personal
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencorresp">
General
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="lettsent">
Letters
Sent
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="politfile">
Political
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="legisfile">
Legislative
Papers
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="specfile">
Special
Files
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speecwrit">
Speeches and
Writings File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="buspap">
Business
Papers
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="miscella">
Miscellany
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addit">
Addition
</ref>,

<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="overs">
Oversize
</ref>,
and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="topsecr">
Top
Secret
</ref>.</p>
<p>
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="fampap">
Family
Papers
</ref> consist of correspondence and other material documenting the lives
of four generations of Tafts. Major correspondents include Robert A. Taft's
parents, Helen Herron Taft and William Howard Taft, his sister, Helen Taft
Manning, his wife, Martha Wheaton Bowers Taft, and his son, Robert Taft
(1917-1993). There is a sizable amount of biographical material on William H.
Taft, twenty-seventh president of the United States, including printed matter
and correspondence with numerous individuals, among them Henry Pringle, author
of <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Life and Work of William Howard Taft.</part>
</title> The series also contains letters of condolence on the death of both
parents.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="persfile">
Personal
File
</ref> reflects Taft's early law career and civic engagements in
Cincinnati, Ohio; his service during World War I, which included a close
association with Herbert Hoover in Washington, D.C., and Paris; and his postwar
occupational and political activities in Ohio until 1927.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencorresp">
General
Correspondence
</ref> series contains letters and other material related to
Taft's numerous business enterprises and associates, his colleagues in the
United States Senate, and other friends and acquaintances. This series, as a
separate filing unit, was terminated in 1945; thereafter correspondence was
filed as political, legislative, or general, with political and legislative
correspondence filed chronologically and general correspondence filed
alphabetically by subject.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="lettsent">
Letters
Sent
</ref> series consists of Taft's replies to professional correspondence
received. The series serves as a locator for incoming correspondence filed
under
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="politfile">
Political
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="legisfile">
Legislative
Papers
</ref>, or
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject
File
</ref>. Typed in the top margin of each page are cross references to the
original item, subject matter, and often Taft's reason for responding.</p>
<p>The most significant series within the collection are
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="politfile">
Political
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="legisfile">
Legislative
Papers
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject
File
</ref>. They reflect the development of Taft's political career at both the
state and national levels as well as his rise to leadership within the
Republican party. The bulk of the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="politfile">
Political
File
</ref> concerns Taft's campaigns for the United States Senate (1938-1950)
and for the Republican presidential nomination (1940-1952), with over one-third
of the series relating to his bid in 1952. Also notable are files concerning
his years in the Ohio state legislature, organized labor's opposition to his
Senate campaign of 1950, and its consequent investigation by Congress.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="legisfile">
Legislative
Papers
</ref> relate to matters of policy and legislation either proposed or
enacted into law. They include correspondence, petitions, suggestions, and
inquiries concerning programs and positions taken by Taft and the Republican
party on local, state, and national issues not found in the more general
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject
File
</ref>. There are also published committee hearings and reports, files
relating to individuals, and letters containing praise, criticism, or
suggestions from political leaders and the public. Subjects of note include
economics, labor, defense, foreign policy, finance and taxation, and
veterans.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject
File
</ref> represents a broad spectrum of topics concerning public affairs. The
series was organized in Taft's senatorial office in 1946 and was used until his
death in 1953. The papers, filed chronologically and thereunder alphabetically
by subject, illustrate Taft's belief that a politician should not only work for
the good of his constituents and the nation as a whole, but also provide moral
leadership. On the whole, Taft was a staunch believer in party unity, but at
times he was also capable of taking very independent positions on political
issues. This paradoxical nature is reflected on the one hand by his intense
opposition to certain policies of presidents Roosevelt, Truman, and Eisenhower
and on the other hand by his wholehearted support for different policies by the
same presidents.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="specfile">
Special
File
</ref> consists of material on political figures. These include Thomas E.
Dewey, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Herbert Hoover, Harold E. Stassen, Adlai E.
Stevenson (1900-1965), and Harry S. Truman.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speecwrit">
Speeches and
Writings File
</ref> represents a comprehensive collection of Taft's addresses,
public statements, radio broadcasts, news releases, and published articles.
They are arranged chronologically and thereunder alphabetically by type of
material.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="buspap">
Business
Papers
</ref> document Taft's financial investments, properties in Ohio and in
Washington, D.C., philanthropic support for artistic and cultural institutions,
personal finances, as well as estate papers of several Taft family members.
</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="miscella">
Miscellany
</ref> series contains appointment books,
clippings, galley proofs and correspondence relating to Taft's 1951 publication
<title localtype="simple">
<part>A Foreign Policy for Americans,</part>
</title> honorary degrees and citations for service, letters of condolence,
material concerning both the Taft family summer home and a fish and game club
in Canada, and also material documenting Taft's long relationship with his alma
mater Yale University.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addit">
Addition
</ref>
consists of family papers, general correspondence, political material, speeches
and writings, business papers, and miscellaneous material. Of note are Martha
Bowers Taft's political correspondence and speeches, illustrating her skill as
campaigner and speaker in her own right as well as her more traditional role as
politician's wife. There are letters from William H. Taft while chief justice
of the Supreme Court to his son Robert Alphonso in which he discusses
contemporary judicial topics. Also of interest is the file detailing the
establishment of a memorial to the twenty-seventh president in Arlington
National Cemetery. Robert A. Taft's life is chronicled by the files containing
his speeches, records concerning the settling of his personal estate, clippings
and other biographical material, as well as numerous letter of condolence
written to both his wife and son Robert, Jr. The public's appreciation of
Taft's life and achievements are evident in files documenting memorials to Taft
in Cincinnati and Washington, D.C.</p>
<p>
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="overs">
Oversize
</ref>
material consists of an architectural sketch, memorial resolutions in honor of
Robert A. Taft, photostatic copies, and scrapbooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received by family members. Includes posthumous
correspondence and biographical and photographic material relating to William
H. Taft.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

civic activities in Cincinnati, Ohio, the selective service, United States Food
Administration in Washington, D.C., and American Relief Administration in
Paris, France.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received and miscellaneous material related to
Taft's business enterprises, Senate colleagues, and other friends. Also
included is a container of general correspondence related to Martha Bowers
Taft. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Copies of replies to professional correspondence.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and sent, Republican party activities,
statements, news releases, clippings, and texts of radio broadcasts, campaign
literature, petitions, primary and general election materials, states subject
files, minorities activities, patronage matters, and voter lists. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Legislative correspondence, position statements, local, state, and
national Republican programs, and congressional committee hearings and reports.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and sent, memoranda, notes, research material,
printed matter, and publications by Taft.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, statements, press releases, campaign literature,
and election material concerning political activities and presidential
nominations of Thomas E. Dewey, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Herbert Hoover, Harold E.
Stassen, Adlai E. Stevenson (1900-1965), and Harry S. Truman.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Holograph and typewritten drafts, corrected proofs, and
mimeographed copies relating to speeches, articles, books, and miscellaneous
writings, including some by Martha Bowers Taft.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, business and property records, legal papers,
certificates, statements, receipts, profit-loss trial balances, estate matters,
check stub books, bank statements and canceled checks, and investment
records.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Appointment books, secretaries' notebooks, Christmas cards,
property records in Canada, letters of condolence, material pertaining to
Taft's association with Yale University, and miscellaneous material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Family papers, general correspondence, political material,
speeches and writings, business papers, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Awards, certificates, memorial resolutions, photostatic copies,
and scrapbooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Material containing security classified information.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The correspondence of Joseph Brodsky (1940-1996) spans the years
1965-1972 and consists of twenty holograph, signed letters, cards, and
telegrams, some containing unpublished verses and drawings, from the former
poet laureate. This early correspondence is addressed to Kira Fedorovna
Samosiuk, an intimate friend of the poet, and while written largely in Russian,
also contains an early attempt at verse in English and an unpublished poem in
Polish. The letters reflect on a close and important relationship from the
poet's early years as well as document broader aspects of Soviet life.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Ernest Joseph King (1878-1956) extend chiefly from 1908 to his death in
1956, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1936-1952. The collection
consists of correspondence, subject files, memoranda, reports, orders, notes, and
associated material organized in six series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="orders"> Orders to Duty </ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencoresp"> General Correspondence </ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speech"> Speech, Article, and Book File </ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="miscella"> Miscellany </ref>; and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addition">2023 Addition</ref>.</p>
<p>In the early years of his career, King was a submarine officer and from 1923 to 1926 he
was commander of the Submarine Base in New London, Connecticut. There are several
folders of material for this tour of duty, the most important of which documents the
salvaging of the <title localtype="simple">
<part>S-51</part>
</title> sunk off Block Island in September 1925. King was in charge of the successful
raising of the <title localtype="simple">
<part>S-51</part>
</title>, considered an outstanding accomplishment as it was generally thought that a
submarine could not be raised from a depth of 125-130 feet of water. For this he was
awarded the Distinguished Service Medal.</p>
<p>From submarines, King moved into aviation, qualifying as a naval pilot in 1927. In 1933
he was appointed chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, serving in that post until 1936,
when he assumed command of the Aircraft Base and Aircraft Scouting Force in San Diego.
King was promoted to vice admiral in 1938 and given command of all the aircraft carriers
of the fleet. Files for this period of his life are a valuable source for studying the
growth and development of military aviation.</p>
<p>King's papers for the World War II period and beyond are particularly significant. As
commander in chief of the United States Fleet and chief of Naval Operations, Admiral
King attended the Atlantic Charter Meeting (1941), the Quebec Conference (1943), the
Cairo and Teheran Conferences (1943), and the Yalta Conference (1945). After the war,
various individuals frequently sought information from him concerning these conferences
and also about particular aspects of United States military and naval operations.
Wherever possible, King was ready to cooperate and supply essential information. For
example, he explained to Quentin James Reynolds and Robert E. Sherwood the origins of
General James Harold Doolittle's 1942 air raid on Tokyo. Marine Corps General Merritt
Austin Edson was interested in learning the story behind the Guadalcanal campaign. King
responded with a letter of four pages that detailed his determined efforts, over strong
opposition, to strike the Japanese in the Solomon Islands immediately after the Battle
of Midway (June 1942). The letter also reveals the evolution of King's philosophy of
Pacific strategy, beginning with his personal experiences at the Asiatic station during
the early years of the century. Other correspondence in this vein is that of Walter Muir
Whitehill, coauthor of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Fleet Admiral King: A Naval Record </part>
</title>(1952); Merritt Austin Edson for Pacific Island strategy; Bernard M. Baruch, on
international control of atomic weapons; Ferdinand Eberstadt, on national security
organization; and Richard S. Edwards, on matters relating to the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Material in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File
</ref> supplements much of this correspondence.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speech"> Speech, Article, and Book
File </ref> contain manuscript drafts of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Fleet Admiral King</part>
</title> and the rough notes for the book. Also in the file drafts and final copies of
King's speeches and lectures. Material from his teaching days at Annapolis and items
such as his thesis written at the Naval War College (1932) on “The Influence of the
National Policy on the Strategy of a War” show the development of his thought in the
field of world politics.</p>
<p>Important correspondents include Henry Harley Arnold, C. R. Atlee, Bernard M. Baruch,
Omar Nelson Bradley, Oliver Lyttleton, Viscount Chandos, Mark W. Clark, Charles A.
Edison, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Douglas Southall Freeman, William Frederick Halsey,
Cordell Hull, Frank Knox, P. W. Litchfield, George C. Marshall, Louis Mountbatten, Earl
Mountbatten of Burma, Chester W. Nimitz, Charles Frederick Algernon Portal, Viscount
Portal of Hungerford, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dorothy Thompson, Harry S. Truman, and
Orville Wright.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addition">2023 Addition</ref>
includes a 1991 issue of <emph render="italic">Pull Together</emph>, a newsletter of the
Naval Historical Foundation and the Naval History Center, with the article “Admiral King
talks about Allied Strategy, July 1943,” and a declassified copy of King's 1947 speech
“Some Aspects of the High Command in World War II.”</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Orders to duty. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, telegrams, invitations, memoranda,
and miscellaneous attachments. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, notes, photographs, and printed material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Handwritten drafts, typescripts, printed copies, and other material including
related correspondence.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Printed matter, memorabilia, photographs, newspaper clippings, and other
material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Newsletter article and speech.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Robert Strange McNamara (1916-2009) span the years 1934-2009, with the
bulk concentrated between 1968 and 2005. McNamara was a business executive with Ford
Motor Company before his appointment as United States secretary of defense in 1961. In
1968, McNamara resigned as defense secretary to become president of the World Bank. The
collection is composed of two supplementary parts. Part I documents McNamara's private
and public life primarily following his departure as secretary of defense, including his
terms as president of the World Bank, his role as counselor and adviser to various
private corporations and nonprofit organizations and foundations, and his role as public
statesman advocating solutions for the critical domestic and foreign policy issues of
the times. The series in Parts I and II are similar, and while their proportions vary,
the content of respective series remains largely the same with the notable exception of
files in Part II dedicated to the analysis of the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Vietnam
War and the publication of his books <title localtype="simple">
<part>In Retrospect</part>
</title> and <title localtype="simple">
<part>Argument without End</part>
</title>. Further descriptions of each part follow.</p>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Part I</emph>
</p>
<p>Part I of the McNamara Papers spans the years 1958-2003, with most of the material dated
between 1968 and 2000. The papers in Part I highlight his position as president of the
World Bank and a member on the boards of directors and advisory councils of numerous
private corporations and nongovernmental institutions. While the papers include some
material concerning his tenure as secretary of defense, Part I contains limited
documentation for the years prior to his service at the World Bank. Part I is organized
into the following series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="icorres">
Correspondence </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iworbank">
World Bank </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iorgan">
Organizations </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="isubfile">
Subject File </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="ispewrit">
Speeches and Writings </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="imiscella"> Miscellany </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iclassi"> Classified </ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iovers"> Oversize </ref>.</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="icorres"> Correspondence </ref>
series contains letters received and copies of replies. It was McNamara's practice to
handwrite many of his replies in the upper right-hand corner of the incoming letters
that were then photocopied for later transcription. Although his handwriting is
sometimes difficult to decipher, the photocopy is often the only copy of his
correspondence that remains in the collection. The series informs on a broad scope of
McNamara's personal friendships, professional connections, and advocacy issues providing
an overview of his relationships and interests that are more fully developed in other
series of the collection. Prominent topics include defense and foreign policy issues,
arms control and nuclear policy, the World Bank, foreign and domestic politics, economic
policy, and international development as well as letters from the public that reflect
the variation of popular opinion regarding McNamara's legacy as a leading strategist of
the Vietnam War and director of the World Bank. Included among McNamara's friends,
colleagues, and media representatives noted in the series are Graham T. Allison, James
G. Blight, McGeorge Bundy, William P. Bundy, Lloyd N. Cutler, Alain C. Enthoven, Orville
L. Freeman, Kurt Gottfried, Pamela Digby Churchill Hayward Harriman, W. Averell
Harriman, Paul Hendrickson, Henry Kissinger, Frans M. Lurvink, Helmut Schmidt, Sargent
Shriver, Gerard C. Smith, Carl E. Taylor, Stewart L. Udall, Cyrus R. Vance, and Barbara
Ward.</p>
<p>Following his resignation as secretary of defense, McNamara served as president of the
World Bank from 1968 to 1981. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iworbank"> World Bank </ref> series provides insight into the policies and
operations of the bank and its affiliated institutions during McNamara's terms as
president. The series is a study of the organizational reforms introduced by McNamara as
the bank changed from a project-oriented investment bank to a development institution at
the service of its member states while simultaneously increasing the amount of capital
financing needed to accomplish its goals. Under his leadership, the bank targeted
poverty reduction, increased funding for health, food, and education programs, and
instituted new methods of accountability for budgeted projects. The series contains
memoranda, reports, program and policy papers, and other material documenting the bank's
administrative structure and strategic planning projects as well as personnel and public
relations issues.</p>
<p>Organizational restructuring was constant during McNamara's presidency, and several
files contain material related to staff grievances and other commentary concerning
institutional reorganization. Of particular interest are a set of notes and notebooks
kept by McNamara of his conversations and field visits. The notes of conversations
record McNamara's exchanges with and reactions to various officials and directors of the
World Bank and world leaders in meetings concerning the operations of the bank. The
notes of his field visits are filed alphabetically by country and record meetings with
representatives of member countries and other entities, exclusive of the United States.
Memoranda for the record were prepared along with briefing memoranda and background
material, some with handwritten notations by McNamara. Items marked “impressions” are
personal notes written by McNamara for his own reference and were not distributed to
bank staff. The series also includes technical notes containing background papers and
reports and a country file of correspondence, memoranda, reports, and policy papers
providing financial analysis of the bank's development policies.</p>
<p>Upon his retirement from the World Bank in 1981, McNamara served on the boards of
directors and advisory councils of a variety of private corporations and nonprofit
organizations and foundations principally focusing on issues of the environment,
East-West relations, arms control and nuclear weapons, population and development,
especially as it affected the Third World, and world hunger. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iorgan"> Organization </ref> series contains the records
of McNamara's transactions with these institutions and is arranged alphabetically by
name of organization. Prominent organizations include the African Development Bank,
Aspen Institute, Atlantic Council of the United States, Battelle Memorial Institute,
Brookings Institution, Council on Foreign Relations, Enterprise Foundation, Global
Coalition for Africa, Indira Gandhi Memorial Trust, InterAction Council, International
Irrigation Management Institute, Kettering Foundation, National Committee on U.S.-China
Relations, Overseas Development Council, and the Pugwash Conference on Science and World
Affairs. The records illuminate the internal operations and policy disputes within many
of the organizations with which McNamara was associated. The series contains
correspondence, notes and notebooks, policy papers, studies and reports, agenda and
briefing books, background material, and other items that chronicle McNamara's travel
arrangements and attendance at various conferences, meetings, symposia, and workshops in
his capacity as corporate adviser on behalf of the organizations. Drafts and typescripts
from speaking engagements and other presentations supplement similar material arranged
in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="ispewrit"> Speeches and Writings
</ref> series.</p>
<p>McNamara worked independently on many of the same issues he supported at the World Bank
and as an organizational representative. Among these the most urgent for him was the
threat of nuclear weapons. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="isubfile"> Subject File </ref> contains material on arms control and nuclear weapons that
chronicle McNamara's efforts on behalf of treaties and strategies designed to reduce the
risk of nuclear war. The series also includes material commemorating the twenty-fifth
anniversary in 1987 of the Cuban Missile Crisis, with reflections on the decisions that
prevented an exchange of nuclear missiles between the United States and the Soviet
Union. Other material associated with McNamara's tenure as secretary of defense include
both defense department records and papers relating to post-defense issues. The latter
includes briefs, depositions, and other court records relating to McNamara's testimony
in the 1984 trial of <emph render="italic">Westmoreland v. CBS, Inc.</emph> Though he
had consistently refused to respond to questions concerning the Vietnam War, McNamara,
by agreeing to testify on Westmoreland's behalf and submitting an affidavit at the
trial, compelled the need for deposition and invited cross-examination. Under oath and
for the public record, McNamara, for the first time since he left office as defense
secretary, was forced to defend his role in the formulation of the government's Vietnam
strategy. In a letter written to newly elected President Bill Clinton, November 23,
1992, located within the “presidential administrations and campaigns” files, McNamara
provides a hopeful coda to the controversy stating, “For me–and I believe for the nation
as well–the Vietnam War finally ended the day you were elected president.”</p>
<p>In addition to his efforts towards eliminating nuclear weapons, McNamara also sought to
alleviate global poverty by supporting economic development in Third World countries.
While president of the World Bank, McNamara became committed to fostering programs
designed to break the cycle of poverty afflicting many of the world's developing
nations, particularly food, health, and population problems in Africa. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="isubfile"> Subject File </ref> contains
material relating to these issues under the “geopolitical file” heading. The series also
includes material referencing attempts to eliminate the cause of the parasitic disease
onchocerciasis or river blindness in Africa, a program originated by the World Bank
during McNamara's presidency. In pursuit of his “visions” for a better world, McNamara
became a frequent traveler on a circuit of conferences and meetings that defined his
agenda as outlined above, which papers are located in the Subject File.</p>
<p>McNamara addressed the issues of war and peace most directly in his articles, books, and
speeches. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="ispewrit"> Speeches and
Writings </ref> series contains correspondence, drafts and typescripts, background
and research material, and editorial comments largely relating to these public
statements and writings. Articles written by McNamara explore themes such as the
imbalance of population growth and economic development and the threat of nuclear arms
in the modern world. The series contains limited documentation regarding the publication
of McNamara's books with the exception of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Blundering into Disaster</part>
</title>, a plea for nuclear reduction and arms control. Files related to his speeches,
lectures, and participation in symposia contain correspondence concerning booking and
travel arrangements, drafts and typescripts, and printed copies. A file titled “printed
and typescript copies,” labeled “statement file” by McNamara, serves as a partially
indexed selective compilation of his speeches and writings.</p>
<p>In addition to McNamara's speeches and writings, the series also includes papers
concerning his radio and television appearances and interviews as well as the speeches
and writings of others. In November 1983, following the ABC television broadcast of
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Day After</part>
</title>, a fictional portrayal of the effects of nuclear war on an American town,
McNamara joined a studio panel in reviewing the film and discussing the consequences of
such a war. Public comments and reactions to McNamara's performance, contained in the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="ispewrit"> Speeches and Writings
</ref> series, reflect the political debate that the film and commentary provoked. After
many years removed from the defense department, McNamara became less reluctant to grant
interviews and agreed to participate in a number of official oral history interviews
conducted by the Office of the Secretary of Defense Historical Office, which
transcripts, as well as those of other interviews, are located in Speeches and Writings.
The series also includes material gathered for Deborah Shapley's 1993 biography of
McNamara, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Promise and Power</part>
</title>, reflecting the controversy it generated.</p>
<p>In addition to containing McNamara's appointment books and files on recreation, travel,
and real estate, among other topics, the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="imiscella"> Miscellany </ref>series includes material concerning McNamara's
first wife, Margaret, founder of the nonprofit children's literacy organization Reading
Is Fundamental. The series includes condolence letters and other memorial items
occasioned by her death in 1981 as well as a set of interviews conducted by Suzan Ruth
Travis-Cline.</p>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Part II</emph>
</p>
<p>Part II of the McNamara Papers spans the years 1934-2009, with the bulk of the material
concentrated between 1968 and 2005. Part II supplements Part I and is organized
similarly. The few correspondence files that exist are arranged in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iimiscella"> Miscellany </ref> series.
Compared with Part I, the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiworbank">
World Bank </ref> series in Part II is limited in scope, but the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref> file is greatly
expanded. Part II is organized into the following series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiworbank"> World Bank </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiorgan"> Organizations </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iisubfile"> Subject File </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iimiscella"> Miscellany </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiclassi"> Classified </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iitops"> Top Secret </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiformrestrdata"> Formerly Restricted Data
</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iisencominfo"> Sensitive
Compartmented Information </ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiovers"> Oversize </ref>.</p>
<p>Although not as extensive as the records in Part I, the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiworbank"> World Bank </ref> series in Part II contains
inclusive sets of memoranda for the record and minutes of President's Council meetings.
The material provides a record of bank meetings with a memoranda for the record prepared
by the personal assistant to the president or by McNamara himself. The memoranda
chronicles the bank's operations and decision-making procedures revealing the internal
policy debates that often led to the development of international financial aid
programs. The series also contains a set of historical reports that track the evolution
of the bank's policy agenda over the decades.</p>
<p>The organizations listed in Part II mirror those in Part I and reflect McNamara's wide
range of interests. Papers in Part II of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iiorgan"> Organizations </ref> series overlap and add continuity to
corresponding material in Part I. Organizations with whom McNamara became newly
affiliated or whose records have been significantly expanded or supplemented from Part I
include the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Corning Inc., Drug Strategies,
East African Development Bank, Eminent Persons Group on Curbing Illicit Trafficking in
Small Arms and Light Weapons, Henry L. Stimson Center, Honorary Presidential Advisory
Council on Investment in Nigeria, Rockefeller Foundation, Trilateral Commission, Urban
Institute, World Food Prize Foundation, and World Resources Institute.</p>
<p>Beginning in the late 1980s, McNamara embraced an historical methodology called
“critical oral history” that provided a framework within which he could publicly analyze
his actions as defense secretary, addressing the questions that had long surrounded his
public service. Unlike conventional oral history, critical oral history subjects
dialogue and memory to documentary analysis and scholarly review. The Cuban Missile
Crisis of October 1962 was the first event McNamara analyzed using this method. In a
series of six major conferences from 1987 to 2002, referred to as the Cuban Missile
Crisis Project, McNamara and other former Kennedy administration officials, along with
their Soviet and Cuban counterparts, including Cuban President Fidel Castro, were
questioned about the crisis. Part II of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iisubfile"> Subject File </ref> contains a full range of documents gathered
and produced by the project, spotlighting the dangers and behind-the-scenes negotiations
that brought the nations to the brink of nuclear war.</p>
<p>While writing his memoir <title localtype="simple">
<part>In Retrospect</part>
</title>, McNamara offered a proposal to initiate a joint American-Vietnamese project on
the Vietnam War based on the principles of critical oral history and modeled after the
Cuban Missile Crisis Project. Principally organized by James G. Blight of Brown
University, and sponsored by Brown's Thomas J. Watson, Jr. Institute for International
Studies, the project consisted of many preliminary meetings and full conferences from
1995 to 1999 that convened under the general title “Missed Opportunities: Revisiting the
Decisions of the Vietnam War.” McNamara's exploratory trip to Hanoi in November 1995 on
behalf of the project, his first trip to Vietnam since the 1960s, generated considerable
domestic controversy and subsequent criticism. Material in Part II of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iisubfile"> Subject File </ref> documents
all aspects of the project whose data provided the basis for McNamara's book <title localtype="simple">
<part>Argument without End</part>
</title>.</p>
<p>Many of the same subjects and topics explored in Part I of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="isubfile"> Subject File </ref> are continued in Part II,
including files on arms control and nuclear weapons, commissions, conferences and
meetings, geopolitical issues, and onchocerciasis (river blindness). Upon his departure
from the Defense Department, McNamara was presented with a multivolume bound compilation
of his background briefings and public statements. These volumes along with several
files of declassified memoranda, position papers, and reports and other related material
provide further insights to McNamara's years as defense secretary.</p>
<p>In 1995, McNamara, in collaboration with Brian VanDeMark, published <title localtype="simple">
<part>In Retrospect</part>
</title>. Described in the preface as “. . . the book I planned never to publish,”
McNamara proceeded to set forth his account and analysis of the Vietnam War with
emphasis on the mistakes made and lessons learned from America's involvement in the
conflict. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and
Writings </ref> series contains extensive research files, drafts, editing and
production material, public response and reaction, interview transcripts, promotion and
publicity material, and related items concerning the writing and publication of
McNamara's long-awaited memoir.</p>
<p>Planned as a sequel to his Vietnam memoir and originally drafted as “In Retrospect II,”
McNamara published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Argument without End</part>
</title> in 1999. Based on conversations between Americans and Vietnamese who were
active participants during the war, the book, cowritten with James G. Blight and Robert
K. Brigham, was the product of the Vietnam War Project described above. Proposals and
outlines for the book are contained in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref> series, in addition to
correspondence, editing, publicity and publication material, and drafts from various
stages of the book's progress. These files, along with those for the Vietnam War
Project, provide an extensive record of the project and the book that grew from it.</p>
<p>In <title localtype="simple">
<part>Wilson's Ghost</part>
</title>, James G. Blight and McNamara collaborated again to publish an analysis of
American foreign policy in the post-Cold War world. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref> series documents
the research and publication of McNamara's last major book, including correspondence
exchanged with Blight, drafts, and editing and publicity material.</p>
<p>Other subjects and topics featured in <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="iispewrit"> Speeches and Writings </ref> include the documentary film <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Fog of War</part>
</title>; Deborah Shapley's biography, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Promise and Power</part>
</title>; and continuing files from Part I concerning interviews, printed and typescript
copies of public statements, and radio and television appearances. <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Fog of War</part>
</title>, winner of the Academy Award for documentary feature in 2003, was produced and
directed by Errol Morris and consists of interviews with McNamara and archival footage.
The film considers McNamara's personal and public life and examines the eleven lessons
of war posited in his memoir <title localtype="simple">
<part>In Retrospect</part>
</title>. Speeches and Writings contains reaction to and commentary on the film as well
as correspondence, interview transcripts, and research material from the film's
production. Files on <title localtype="simple">
<part>Promise and Power</part>
</title>, include transcripts from a set of interviews conducted by Shapley with
McNamara in preparation for the book that complement related files in Part I.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, memoranda, notes, cards, and letters
exchanged between correspondents other than McNamara, as well as enclosures
containing speeches, printed matter, reports, typescripts, transcripts, and other
miscellaneous attachments. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, cables, interviews, reports and studies, policy and
research papers, notes and notebooks, drafts and typescripts, agenda and records
of meetings, financial and legal records, statements, speeches and writings, press
releases, photographs, printed matter, and miscellaneous material relating to the
operations and policies of the World Bank.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports and studies, policy and research papers,
organizational records, notes, drafts and typescripts, agenda and records of
meetings, transcripts, project proposals, briefing books, financial records,
statements, speeches and writings, working papers, itineraries, press releases,
photographs, printed matter, and miscellaneous material concerning McNamara's
service as a member on the boards and advisory councils of various private
corporations and nongovernmental institutions.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, conferences and meetings, policy and research papers,
reports and studies, drafts and typescripts, background material, briefing books,
notes, transcripts, statements and testimony, speeches and writings, financial and
legal records, press releases, printed matter, and miscellaneous material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, drafts and typescripts, notes, background and research material,
transcripts, proofs, publication and production material, copyright releases and
permissions, blurbs and endorsements, royalty statements, printed matter, and
miscellaneous material concerning McNamara's articles, books, commentary,
editorials, interviews, radio and television appearances, and speeches as well as
speeches and writings by others. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, family papers, appointment books, awards, financial and legal
papers, press clippings and releases, real estate records, notes, reports, land
plans and surveys, recreational and travel records, printed mater, and other
items, including condolence letters and memorial tributes on the occasion of the
death of McNamara's wife, Margaret. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, telegrams, policy papers, reports, and related
items.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Real estate land surveys and lot plans.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
