<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Victor Selden Clark (1868-1946) span the years
1827-1944. The papers are organized into the following series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="personal">
Personal
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="family">
Family
Papers
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="special">
Special
Files
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="special">
Research and
Writings File
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="over">
Oversize
</ref>.
</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="personal">
Personal
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="special">
Special
Files
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="research">
Research and
Writings File
</ref> series relate to Clark's career as an economist and author.
The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="special">
Special
Files
</ref> are largely comprised of records kept by Clark during his
trusteeship of the Institute of Current World Affairs, and include such
correspondents as Thomas L. Blakemore, Jr., Hallie Flanagan, John N. Hazard,
Walter S. Rogers, and Phillips Talbot. Other papers reflect his membership on
the Board of Research Associates in American Economic History of the Carnegie
Institution of Washington, his work as an arbitrator on railroad cases for the
United States Bureau of Mediation, and his service on the Insular Board of
Education in Puerto Rico shortly after the territory was acquired by the United
States in 1898.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="family">
Family
Papers
</ref> contain farm diaries, business and land records, account books,
daybooks, and financial records and legal papers relating to the firm of Green
and Davis, Levi Davis, LeRoy Davis, and the Davis and Clark families especially
in the Genesse Valley of New York. The Davis records were probably inherited by
Clark through his mother Helen, who was a Davis before marriage.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Correspondence, notebooks, account books, travel documents, legal
papers, photographs, certificates and diplomas, memorabilia, newspaper
clippings, and miscellaneous papers. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, business and land records, financial records and
legal papers, miscellaneous papers, and bound volumes of account books, farm
diaries, and other records.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Reports, administrative records, correspondence, case files,
financial records, orders and regulations, and miscellaneous documents. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Articles, essays, reports, student papers, short stories, book
reviews, speeches, poems, travelogues, research notes, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Diploma, resolution, and farm diaries. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The collection of Floridiana of Jeannette Thurber Connor (1872-1927)
spans the years 1570-1927. The collection is in English, Spanish, and French
and is organized into the following series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">Correspondence</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="writ">Writings</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="spee">Speeches</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="tran">Transcripts</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="over">Oversize</ref>.</p>
<p>The Connor collection contains correspondence, research material,
reports, writings, speeches, notes, photographs, printed matter, and
transcripts and photocopies of documents in repositories relating to the early
history of Florida and represents a selective assemblage of material concerning
Spanish Florida gathered by Connor on subjects of interest to her. The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">Correspondence</ref> series primarily concerns Connor's research
and transcription efforts at the Archivo General de Indias, Seville, Spain,
while
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="writ">Writings</ref>
contains her research notes, drafts, and source material for miscellaneous
writings and research projects, including files relating to Jean Ribaut, author
of Connor's commemorative edition of <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Whole and True Discouerye of Terra Florida. </part>
</title> The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="spee">Speeches</ref>
series consists of a report addressed to the annual meeting of the Florida
State Historical Society by Connor and a brief talk given by her to a history
class at John B. Stetson University, De Land, Fla. The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="tran">Transcripts</ref>
series contains the transcript and photocopied reproductions of primary
documents collected by Connor for her research at the Archivo General de
Indias, Seville, Spain, as well as other repositories.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Correspondence and miscellaneous material primarily relating to
the Archivo General de Indias, Seville, Spain</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts, research material, photocopies, photographs, reports,
notes, printed matter, proofs, and miscellaneous items relating to Connor's
articles, books, and other writings concerning her research into Florida's
early history.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Typescripts of two addresses by Connor.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Transcript and photocopied reproductions of original documents
collected by Connor for her research at the Archivo General de Indias, Seville,
Spain, as well as other repositories.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Maps, surveys, illustrations, and narratives.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Rebekah Crawford (1845-1934) and Linda Clarke-Smith span
the years 1715-1929, with the bulk of the material dating from 1890 to 1929.
The papers are organized into the following series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="scrap">
Scrapbooks
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="fampap">
Family
Papers
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="mis">
Miscellany
</ref>.
Although the majority of the papers belonged to Rebekah Crawford, she asked
that the collection be referred to as the "Rebekah Crawford and Linda
Clarke-Smith Collection" to honor the relief work of Linda Clarke-Smith, her
niece.</p>
<p> The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="scrap">
Scrapbooks
</ref>
document Crawford's relief work during and after World War I in Italy and
France with the Duryea Relief Agency and the American Red Cross. The series
also includes collected material concerning Edgar Allan Poe, Emma Trapper, Mary
Alethea and the Spanish-American War.</p>
<p> The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="fampap">
Family
Papers
</ref> contain correspondence, genealogical material, Crawford family
documents, ancestral tablets, printed articles, an essay on Crawford genealogy,
scrapbooks, indentures of transfers of land, account and ledger books of
Richard Crawford, wills, drafts of wills, unidentifiable financial records, and
miscellaneous pieces of old documents.and writings. </p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="mis">
Miscellany
</ref>
series includes photographs, postcards, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Scrapbooks including correspondence, photographs, financial
records, postcards, printed material, and memorabilia. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Correspondence, writings, genealogical material, indentures of
transfers of land, account and ledger books of Richard Crawford, and
miscellaneous documents including wills, financial records, and other family
documents. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Magazine clippings, notes, photographs, postcards, and printed
material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Scrapbooks and awards. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p id="Gen">The papers of William Augustus Croffut (1835-1915) contain correspondence,
journals, scrapbooks, autographs, reference material, printed matter, and drafts of
articles, books, and poems, including a significant portion relating to Ethan Allan
Hitchcock. The collection spans the period 1774-1933, with the bulk of the material
concentrated between 1880 and 1915. The papers are organized into five series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">
General Correspondence
</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Bus">
Business Papers
</ref>,<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Hitch">
Ethan Allen Hitchcock
File
</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Anti">
Anti-Imperialist League
</ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Misc">
Miscellany
</ref>. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">
General Correspondence
</ref> ranges from 1862 to 1933, with the largest part from
the period 1880-1915. Correspondence after 1915 is largely that of Croffut's second
wife, Bessie B. Croffut. Topics include Croffut's various publications, his activities
with the Anti-Imperialist League, and the presidential campaign of 1900. Correspondents
include George S. Boutwell, Elwood S. Corser, John William Hayes, John B. Henderson,
Patrick O'Farrell, Bertrand Shadwell, Charles A. Towne, George W. Van Siclen, and Erving
Winslow, as well prominent figures such as William Jennings Bryan, Samuel Gompers, and
Carl Schurz. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Hitch">
Ethan Allen Hitchcock File
</ref> contains drafts and copies of
Croffut's writings as well as a copy of Hitchcock's memoir that Croffut used for
<title>
<part>Fifty Years in Field and Camp.</part>
</title> This memoir, based on diaries, is not
in the Ethan Allen Hitchcock collection in the Manuscript Division. Bessie B. Croffutt,
niece of Hitchcock, also made copies of other Hitchcock materials, including
correspondence with Sophie Peabody (Mrs. Nathaniel Hawthorne). Also in the collection
are an undated letter of John Quincy Adams, a note of Jefferson Davis, numerous
autographs, including of James Monroe, copies of George Washington material, and items
relating to Joseph Smith Fowler. </p>
<p>Included in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Anti">
Anti-Imperialist League
</ref> file are minutes and records of the
Washington, D.C., branch, along with other branch and league literature, additional
printed matter, and drafts of articles advocating the cause of the Philippines and of
the Boers in South Africa. The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Misc">
Miscellany
</ref> series includes journals of
Henry Alfred Robbins containing accounts of his travels in Europe that describe
practices on the Continent during the 1870s. Scrapbooks contain newspaper columns and an
account of the World's Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, including correspondence of Croffut's second wife, Bessie B. Croffut. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bills and receipts.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Mainly copies of Hitchcock's memoir and related notes and correspondence relating
to its publication by Croffut. Also other writings by Croffut and Croffut family
members, including drafts, galleys, printed articles and verse, and books of
poetry by Croffut. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Official minutes and other records of the league's Washington, D.C., branch,
drafts of articles on the Philippines and imperialism, and printed matter relating
to the league and to imperialism, South Africa, and the Boers.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Autographs and copies of letters of historical figures, address books, notebooks,
journals of Henry Alfred Robbins, scrapbooks, maps, bibliographic data, printed
matter, and miscellaneous items.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Amos Pinchot (1873-1944) span the years 1856-1945, with the bulk of the
collection dating from 1909 to 1942. The collection chiefly reflects Pinchot's career as
a lawyer and reformer and consists of six series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="famcorre"> Family Correspondence </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencorres"> General Correspondence </ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speech"> Speeches and Writings </ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="print"> Printed Matter </ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="overs"> Oversize </ref>.</p>
<p>Topics of importance in the papers include civil liberties, labor problems, the Sherman
Antitrust Act, opposition to militarism and war, the League of Nations, the Progressive
Party, oil scandals, government ownership of railroads, the National Industrial Recovery
Act and New Deal legislation, reorganization of the Supreme Court, cooperative housing,
America First Committee, and presidential campaigns from 1916 to 1940. Prominent
correspondents include William Edgar Borah, Louise Bryant, James Rudolph Garfield,
Harold L. Ickes, William Kent, John Adams Kingsbury, Fiorello H. La Guardia, John L.
Lewis, Gifford Pinchot, Ezra Pound, John Reed (1887-1920), Franklin D. Roosevelt,
Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919), and Henry L. Stimson.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received by Amos Pinchot and Pinchot family members.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Memoranda, notes, reports, printed matter, and other material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts and printed versions of articles, addresses, speeches, and other writings,
and related letters, notes and notebooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Newspaper clippings, articles, and other printed material. Organized in four
sets.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>A broadside and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The radio scripts of Paul Rhymer (1905-1964) span the years 1934-1944
and consist of playscripts of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Vic and Sade</part>
</title> submitted to the Library of Congress for copyright deposit during that
period. The <title localtype="simple">
<part>Vic and Sade</part>
</title> radio series, sponsored by Proctor and Gamble, aired as a daytime
comedy on the National Broadcasting Company from November 1934 to December 1945
and won many awards, including for best written program on the radio in
1936.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of the P. Phillips family span the period 1832 1914. The
papers include the writings of Eugenia Levy Phillips and her parents, Jacob
Clavius Levy and Fanny Yates Levy, but the bulk of the material relates to the
law practice of her husband, P. Phillips (1807-1884), and his son, W. Hallett
Phillips, prominent lawyers before the United States Supreme Court. Material
concerning their practice is found primarily in the letterbooks, in the
dockets, and in the legal record books. The collection is organized in eight
series:
<ref target="journal">Journal</ref>;
<ref target="gencorr">General Correspondence</ref>,
<ref target="letterbooks">Letterbooks</ref>;
<ref target="subject">Subject File</ref>;
<ref target="autobiog">Autobiography, Speeches, and Writings</ref>;
<ref target="legal">Legal File</ref>;
<ref target="financial">Financial Papers</ref>; and
<ref target="misc">Miscellany</ref>.</p>
<p>Although Eugenia Levy Phillips was an ardent Southerner, as shown in her journal written during
her internment, P. Phillips apparently played an inactive role in the Civil War.
There is a gap in the otherwise inclusive series of <ref target="letterbooks">letterbooks</ref> for the period 1862 to 1867, but the period is scanned in his
<ref target="autobiog">autobiography</ref>. Both P. Phillips and his son were
champions of the disadvantaged. The elder Phillips was interested in California and
the United States and Mexican Claims Commission, Key West and the slave trade,
judicial reform, and in securing the repeal of the Missouri Compromise with the
passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act.</p>
<p>There is little biographical material on W. Hallett Phillips, but something of his character
can be gleaned from his notebooks, translations and miscellaneous writings. His
idealism is shown in material on the preservation of Yellowstone National Park,
support of the Cuban revolution, investigation of a lynching at Hahnville,
Louisiana, and the defense of the rights of the Moki (Hopi) Indians of Arizona.</p>
<p>
<ref target="gencorr">Correspondence</ref> is generally on legal matters and
includes James B. Campbell, Edmund Strother Dargan, John Forsyth, George Wilkins
Guthrie, John Marshall Harlan, William R. King, William A. Maury, Medill McCormick, Moses Cohen
Mordecai, Richard Olney, Hoke Smith, Edwin McMasters Stanton, A. B. Stickney, and
William Yerger.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Holograph transcript and typed transcript of the journal of
Eugenia Levy Phillips.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Letters sent and received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Washington, D. C. law office letterbooks of Philip Phillips;
Phillips, Maury, &amp; Phillips; W. Hallett Phillips; and Phillips &amp;
Phillips. There is some overlapping between volumes and a gap in the records of
Philip Phillips for the period 1862-1867.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Correspondence, reports, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Autobiography, printed speeches and statements, and "In Memoriam," of P. Phillips, and
miscellaneous writings and translations of W. Hallett Phillips. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Deeds, will, Supreme Court brief, dockets, legal notebooks, and
record books of Philip Phillips; Phillips, Maury, &amp; Phillips; and W.
Hallett Phillips.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Ledger, account books, receipt books, cancelled checks, and fee
memorandum.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Commonplace books, receipt books, scrapbooks and notebooks, a
copy of "Vindiciae Judaeorum," a book of quotations, notes and invitations,
memorabilia, photographs, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The Puerto Rican Collection spans the years 1591-1900, with the bulk
of the material dating from 1750 to 1898. The papers are in Spanish with some
English. The papers contain documents from the Spanish colonial government of
Puerto Rico including financial material reflecting budgets, data on imports
and exports, and taxation, military papers from the War Ministry, and orders
and decrees from the Spanish government. A wide variety of other papers
document other aspects of Spanish colonial Puerto Rico including items
concerning slavery, political prisoners, registration of foreigners, the
fortifications of “El Morro” in San Juan, baptismal records, and politics.
Many of these items had belonged to the Puerto Rican writer, historian, and
government official Cayetano Coll y Toste and relate to his research interests.
A very few items, mostly concerning education, date from after the
Spanish-American War and the subsequent American occupation of Puerto Rico.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Marcia Davenport (1903-1996) span the years 1929-1970,
with the bulk of the material dating from 1932 to 1960. The papers are mostly
in English with a typescript in Czech and are organized into the following
series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="lit">
Literary
Manuscripts
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">
Addition
</ref>.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">
Correspondence
</ref> largely relates to the preparation and
publication of her books and novels and there are numerous drafts and copies of
Davenport's outgoing letters. A significant group of correspondence consists of
letters from Maxwell E. Perkins, editor-in-chief at Charles Scribner's Sons,
from 1931 until his death in 1947. Included among the more than thirty letters
from Perkins is a ten-page letter, dated April 28, 1947, concerning revisions
of Davenport's novel <title localtype="simple">
<part>East Side, West Side</part>
</title>. Other correspondents include Carol Brandt, Davenport's literary
agent, Charles Scribner, Jr., and Wallace Meyer who succeeded Perkins as
Davenport's editor at the Scribner publishing house. There are also individual
letters from Willa Cather, Irving Kolodin, and Montrose Jonas Moses. Further
correspondence is in the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">
Addition
</ref>.</p>
<p> The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="lit">
Literary
Manuscripts
</ref> relate to her works published from 1929 to 1960 including <title localtype="simple">
<part>Mozart</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Of Lena Geyer</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Valley of Decision</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>East Side, West Side</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>My Brother's Keeper</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part> Garibaldi: Father of Modern Italy</part>
</title>, and <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Constant Image</part>
</title>. Notes and early material relating to her 1967 autobiography <title localtype="simple">
<part>Too Strong for Fantasy</part>
</title> and the original typescript for <title localtype="simple">
<part>My Brother's Keeper</part>
</title> are in the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">
Addition
</ref>.
Included with the manuscripts are notes, typescripts, press clippings,
typescripts, galley proofs, page proofs, drafts, and fragments.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Incoming and outgoing letters relating to Davenport's
publications.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts, notes, typescripts, galley proofs, page proofs, and press
clippings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, literary manuscripts, clippings, notes,
typescripts, and fragments.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Herbert Bain Knowles (1894-1976) cover the years
1941-1945 and describe Knowles’s service in the United States Navy’s
amphibious forces in the Pacific during World War II. The collection traces the
American advance across the Pacific Ocean to Japan via the Solomon Islands,
Attu, Kiska, Tarawa, Kawajalein, Saipan, Guam, Leyte, Lingayen, and Nagasaki,
Japan, during 1942-1945.</p>
<p> Included are mimeographs and carbon copies of after action reports of
Knowles and others, conference notes, service communications, operation plans
and orders for assault landings and training exercises, marine division field
reports, Knowles’s unpublished “History of U.S.S. <emph render="italic">Heywood</emph>,” and his war diaries or monthly logs of
Transport Division 18 and Transport Squadron 12. Also included are photographs
of the Leyte beachhead and a military intelligence bulletin. Personal materials
consist of a few items of correspondence, health reports, orders, response to
orders, vouchers, and similar documents depicting Knowles’s naval life while
not in combat or engaged in ship and troop deployment.</p>
<p> Knowles was a pioneer and innovator in the art of assault troop
landings. His ideas and innovations, as found in his operational plans and
orders and in his after action reports, were to become widely adopted for
amphibious landings by United States forces.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Montgomery Sicard (1836-1900) span the years 1800-1948,
with the bulk of the material falling in the years 1870 to 1898. The collection
consists of official and general correspondence, a subject file, and
miscellaneous items. </p>
<p> Sicard’s achievements in the field of ordnance are documented with
his diagrams and memoranda for breech-loading howitzers and his plans for steel
armor plate for ships. In his plans for steel plates are holograph and
typescript notes, memoranda, letters, blueprints , and a corrected galley for <title localtype="simple">
<part>Specifications for Armor for the United States Navy</part>
</title>. </p>
<p>The official correspondence includes a few letters, but the majority
of items are orders to duty. Correspondents include William E. Chandler,
William Mayhew Folger, William H. Hunt, Charles O’Neil, and David D. Porter.
The general correspondence consists largely of letters exchanged between Sicard
and his wife, Elizabeth Floyd Sicard, and between the Sicards and their
children, William F. Sicard, Montgomery Sicard, Jr., and Eleanor L. Sicard.
Other correspondents are Ward Hunt, Jr., Kossuth Niles, and Asa Walker.</p>
<p> Sicard’s financial affairs are documented with letters of advice on
investments; papers of profits, management of property, and purchase of
household goods, and tax receipts. There are letters from his brothers, Stephen
Sicard and George J. Sicard, and his brother-in-law, William Floyd. </p>
<p>Of interest in the miscellany are trade papers of Sicard’s father,
Stephen Sicard, and papers on the management of the Floyds’ property in New
York.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Robert W. Shufeldt (1822-1895) span the years 1836-1910,
with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1860-1880.
Shufeldt’s forty-five year naval career was interrupted by a nine-year period
in the merchant marine service and in surveying for a proposed isthmian canal
route. The correspondence for his broken-service years, however, includes many
papers of interest on naval affairs.</p>
<p> The Shufeldt collection consists primarily of correspondence,
letterbooks, and subject files, supplemented by diaries, notebooks, journals,
logbooks, newspaper clippings, printed matter, and a small file of material
concerning explorations in Africa by Shufeldt’s youngest son, Mason. The
topics of interest are the nineteenth-century navy, its growth and development;
Civil War naval and diplomatic activities; foreign relations in the 1870s and
1880s, especially with Africa and Asia; and the Tehuantepec, Mexico, surveying
expeditions. The collection is organized into nine series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="diary">Diaries,
Notebooks, Logbooks, and Journals</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="letter">Letterbooks,
Letterpress Books, and Letter Index Books</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="offcorresp"> Official
Correspondence</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencorresp">General
Correspondence</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">Subject
File</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="newclip">Newspaper
Clippings</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="printmat">Printed
Matter</ref>;
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="miscella">Miscellany</ref>; and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="masonfile">Mason A.
Shufeldt File</ref>. </p>
<p>Shufeldt resigned his commission in the navy in 1854 and entered the
merchant marine to command the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Quaker City</part>
</title>. Later, he became interested in the construction of a canal across the
Isthmus of Tehuantepec in Mexico and in 1860 led an expedition through that
region. In 1861, Shufeldt was appointed consul general to serve in Cuba.
Correspondents for the years 1839-1861 include A. D. Bach, George Bancroft,
Charles Stuart Boggs, Benjamin F. Butler, John Adolphus Dahlgren, Samuel
Ffrancis Du Pont, David Glasgow Farragut, John Pendleton Kennedy, James Murray
Mason, Matthew Calbraith Perry, David D. Porter, and Gideon Welles. </p>
<p>Shufeldt returned to active duty in the navy in 1863 with the rank of
commander. During the Civil War, her served both ashore and afloat. After the
Civil War, Shufeldt served at sea in the Far East and in 1868 he returned to
the United States and was assigned ordnance duty ashore in New York.</p>
<p> In 1870, Shufeldt was promoted to the rank of captain and was
assigned special duty in command of a survey expedition to Tehuantepec, Mexico.
After the exploration, Shufeldt recommended that this territory be considered
as a likely site for a transisthmus canal.</p>
<p> In 1878, Shufeldt was given command of the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Ticonderoga</part>
</title> that was to sail on a round-the-world cruise. The documentation for
the cruise fills about one-third of the containers in this collection. After
returning to the United States in 1881, he was reassigned to Peking, China, as
the naval attaché. </p>
<p>Shufeldt was appointed president of the Naval Advisory Board, for
which he served two years before retiring in 1884. It was during this last tour
of duty that he helped formulate the plans for a new navy incorporating the
technological advance from sail to steam propulsion and from wood to iron and
steel hulls.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Diaries, notebooks, log abstracts, logbooks, navigational data,
journals, and other writings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Copies of correspondence and reports sent by Shufeldt as commander
of various ships. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and a few drafts of letters sent.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and a few drafts of letters sent, mostly of a
personal and family nature, but some material relating to Shufeldt’s
activities in Cuba, Mexico, and elsewhere. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, reports, memoranda, manuscripts, maps, printed
matter, newspaper clippings, drafts of writings, bills and receipts, and
miscellaneous items pertaining to Cuba, the Tehuantepec Survey Expedition, and
the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Ticonderoga</part>
</title> world cruise. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Clippings chiefly concerned with naval incidents. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Aticles, pamphlets, speeches, general orders, and other writings.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> An account book, calling cards and invitations, notes and
fragments, inventories, quartermaster reports, ship descriptions, officer
register, ship specifications and blueprints, admiralty board arguments, bills,
receipts, inventories, copies of treaties, certificates and awards, poetry,
songs, and essays. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, reports, writings, and miscellaneous material.
This file is mostly concerned with Mason A. Shufeldt’s explorations of
Africa.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Jean Joseph Maurice Dartigue (1903-1983) span the years 1941-1945 and
consist of records relating to the Société haitiano-américaine de développement
agricole. Together with President Elie Lescot and Minister of Finance M. Abel Lacroix of
Haiti, Dartigue established the Haitian corporation in 1941 and became its vice
president. Included in the collection are correspondence, minutes, agreements, financial
reports, and studies concerning the organization’s founding and mission as an effort
during World War II in cooperation with the United States to produce cryptostegia, a
fast growing rubber plant. Lands were cleared and several hundred peasant families were
displaced in implementing a contract with the Rubber Reserve Company, a subsidiary of
the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. </p>
<p>The records, in French and English, were the personal papers of
Dartigue and are organized by type of material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Elmer Holmes Davis (1890-1958) span the years 1865-1957,
with the bulk of the material dating from 1946 to 1955. The papers are
organized into the following series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">
General
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="per">
Personal and
Literary File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subj">
Subject
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="radio">
Radio
Scripts
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">
Addition
</ref>.</p>
<p> The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="corr">
General
Correspondence
</ref> contains mostly letters relating to Davis's career. He
kept little of his personal incoming and outgoing letters. Davis did, however,
retain some early correspondence written by his parents, his wife, and a few
others. Notable are the 1917 letters from Carolyn A. Wilson who reported from
France during World War I for the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Chicago Tribune</part>
</title> and corresponded with Davis about what she observed. Later
correspondence reflects Davis's involvement in the political and literary
fields. Correspondents include Bernard Augustine De Voto, Edward R. Murrow,
Harold Wallace Ross, James Thurber, Harry S. Truman, Hendrik Willem van Loon,
Sumner Welles, and William Allen White. </p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="per">
Personal and
Literary File
</ref> contains biographical material, lectures and speeches,
photographs, and printed copies of many of Davis's articles and early pieces of
fiction as well as the typescript of <title localtype="simple">
<part>But We Were Born Free</part>
</title>. Of interest are photographs taken during a visit to Pearl Harbor,
Hawaii, in 1944, and currency produced by the First National Bank of Aurora,
Indiana, in 1865, where Davis's father worked.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subj">
Subject
File
</ref>, devoted mainly to world events, contains correspondence, newspaper
clippings, magazine articles, government publications, notes, and press
releases issued by news bureaus and government agencies. Of interest are the
files on the Office of War Information that include a report to the president
for the years 1942-1945 and items relating to Davis's service as director
including his file card from the Nazi Propaganda Ministry, memoranda of
conversations with government officials, and correspondence and clippings
relating to the dispute between the Office of War Information and its overseas
branch. Further correspondence relating to the Office of War Information is in
the General Correspondence.</p>
<p>
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="radio">
Radio
Scripts
</ref> contains Davis's original scripts of broadcasts for the Columbia
Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company. For 1946, there is
also a set of approved scripts. The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="add">
Addition
</ref> is
comprised of a radio script dated 16 February 1942.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Letters sent and received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Biographical and family material, clippings, speeches and
lectures, memorabilia, photographs, articles, typescript of his book <title localtype="simple">
<part>But We Were Born Free</part>
</title>, booklets, a novel, and short stories.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, clippings, congressional reports, notes, press
releases, printed matter, research papers, and other material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Original radio scripts.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Radio script.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of James J. Davis (1873-1947) span the years 1895-1946,
with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1931-1946. The
collection consists of thirteen series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="diary">
Diaries
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="moose">
Loyal Order of
Moose Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="posit">
Patronage
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="polit">
Political
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="person">
Family
Correspondence
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="spec">
Special
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="finance">
Financial
File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="book">
Book File
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speech">
Speeches and
Articles
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="scrap">
Scrapbooks and
Personal Miscellany
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="print">
Printed
Matter
</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="photog">
Photographs and
Cartoons
</ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="over">
Oversize
</ref>.
</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="diary">
Diaries
</ref>
include desk diaries and a register of constituents. The three correspondence
series and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="spec">
Special
File
</ref> relate to political matters, constituent services, job seekers, and
to his activities as a founder, organizer, and director general of the Loyal
Order of Moose. Correspondents include Rhys J. Davies, Homer L. Ferguson,
Herbert Hoover, and Andrew W. Mellon.</p>
<p>The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="spec">
Special
File
</ref> includes files on Davis's senatorial campaign in 1931; the United
States Congress Senate Select Committee on Senatorial Campaign Expenditures
investigation, headed by Gerald P. Nye, of his campaign expenses; and a legal
case where he was the defendant, <emph render="italic">United States v.
Davis</emph>, the Loyal Order of Moose lottery trial. The
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speech">
Speeches and
Articles
</ref> includes Davis's writings and speeches about labor relations,
unemployment, social security, various political campaigns, and a draft of his
unpublished book, "The History of Strikes." </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p> Scheduling desk diaries and a constituents register. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

Pennsylvania with persons seeking employment in government and private
industry.</p>

campaigns. </p>

<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters between Davis and his son, James J. Davis, Jr.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Legal papers, voting records, clippings, and correspondence.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Personal and professional financial records.</p>
</scopecontent>

<p>Draft of Davis's unpublished book, "History of Strikes," with
related correspondence. </p>

appreciation, a gavel, and miscellaneous material.</p>

<date>1895-1946 </date>
