<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Emanuel Alexander Goldenweiser (1883-1953) span the years 1911-1952, with
the bulk of the material concentrated in the period from 1930 to 1945. The collection
relates almost wholly to financial and economic affairs with major emphasis on Federal
Reserve Board matters. Correspondents include Dean Acheson, Louis D. Brandeis, Paul H.
Douglas, Marriner Eccles, Ralph A. Young, Carter Glass, John Maynard Keynes, Charles
Rist, and Fred M. Vinson. </p>
<p>The papers are organized into <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">
General Correspondence </ref> and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Subj"> Subject File </ref> series.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, notes, speeches, congressional testimony,
writings, and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Ruth Gordon (1896-1985) span the years 1924-1969, with the bulk of the
material concentrated between 1940 and 1969. Included in the collection are
correspondence, scripts, financial records, and other material relating mainly to the
plays and motion pictures in which Gordon appeared. The papers are organized into four
series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">General Correspondence</ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Drama">Articles, Drama, and
Motion Picture File</ref>; <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Finance">Financial Records</ref>; and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Misc">Miscellany</ref>.
</p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">General Correspondence</ref> consists mainly of letters received by Gordon, with only a
scattered number of her replies. The correspondence relates primarily to her career as
an actress and author and includes a substantial number of letters of particular
interest from Edna Ferber, Alex Guinness, Vivien Leigh, Anita Loos, and Robert Morse. </p>
<p>Included in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Drama">Articles, Drama, and
Motion Picture File</ref> are scripts and screenplays
(many in sequential drafts that show the evolution of the work into its final form),
financial records, publicity material, and reviews of the works. There is also
correspondence relating to specific plays and motion pictures. A group of financial
records contain Gordon's bank statements and cancelled checks for the years
1937-1957.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Mainly letters received with a few replies. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Articles, outlines, scripts, correspondence and other production material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bank statements and cancelled checks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Printed biographical material and a miscellaneous item. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Peter Marshall (1902-1949) and Catherine Marshall (1914-1983), husband and
wife, span the years 1927-1964, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period
1933-1956. Personal materials of Peter Marshall comprise about a fourth of the
collection, including a small amount of correspondence and a large file of notes for his
sermons. The sermons, about 850 in number, cover the period 1933 through January 1948
and include such well-known sermons as “Singing in the Rain,” “Go Down Death,” “Under
Sealed Orders,” “The King is in the Audience,” and “Rendezvous in Samarra.” There are
also synopses of many of the sermons and various indexes that list the sermons by title,
date, location, subject matter, and quotations used. The collection is organized into
seven series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Ser"> Peter Marshall:
Sermons </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Corr"> Peter
Marshall: Correspondence </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="CatCor"> Catherine Marshall: Correspondence </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Book"> Catherine Marshall: Book and Article File </ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Scrap"> Scrapbooks </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Add"> Addition I </ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="AddII"> Addition II </ref>.</p>
<p>Catherine Marshall's papers, in addition to treating her own career as an author and
lecturer following the death of her husband, are mainly oriented to the life of Peter
Marshall and to her biography of him, <title>
<part>A Man Called Peter.</part>
</title> Most of her correspondence consists of mail from persons who read her numerous
books and saw the motion picture based on the biography. </p>
<p>A significant portion of the papers concerns the production by Twentieth Century-Fox
Film Corporation of <title>
<part>A Man Called Peter.</part>
</title> There are verbatim records of the conferences attended by Catherine Marshall
and representatives of Twentieth Century-Fox during planning of the film. In addition to
many versions of the film script, these records present the metamorphosis of the work
from printed page to celluloid. Important correspondents include screenwriter Eleanor
Griffin, producer Samuel G. Engel, and the film's principal performers, Richard Todd,
Jean Peters, and Marjorie Rambeau. </p>
<p>Also in the collection are other manuscripts of Catherine Marshall's published works,
some of which include both original drafts and corrected copies of proofs. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Scrap"> Scrapbooks </ref> series is
composed mainly of printed material including some correspondence relating to Peter
Marshall's election as chaplain of the United States Senate, his death, and Catherine
Marshall's subsequent career as an author. <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Add"> Addition I </ref> and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="AddII"> Addition II </ref> contain miscellaneous sermons and ideas for
sermon, written prayers, seminary papers of Peter Marshall, and other material. </p>
<p>An <ref target="index01"> appendix </ref> to this finding aid lists the names and dates
of correspondents in the Peter Marshall: Correspondence series of the collection. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Texts of sermons by Peter Marshall and related material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Family letters and general correspondence of letters sent and received by Peter
Marshall. Names and dates of correspondents are listed in an <ref target="index01">
<emph render="italic">appendix</emph>
</ref>. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received by Catherine Marshall.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts and production material of Mrs. Marshall's published books and articles and
an unpublished work. The manuscript of <title>
<part>A Man Called Peter</part>
</title> also contains papers concerning the movie version of the work.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Mainly biographical material about Peter Marshall and publicity relating to the
books and movie about him.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Miscellaneous sermons, prayers, articles, and seminary papers of Peter
Marshall.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Material for sermon ideas, typescripts of sermons and prayers, and miscellany
relating to Peter Marshall.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Louis Theodore Michener (1848-1928) span the years 1880-1927. The
collection consists of correspondence, reports, memoranda, newspaper clippings, an
autograph album, and printed matter relating chiefly to Indiana and Republican Party
politics and to Michener's role in Benjamin Harrison's senate campaign of 1886 and
presidential campaigns of 1888 and, 1892. Correspondents include Albert Jeremiah
Beveridge, Chauncey M. Depew, Frederick Douglass, Stephen B. Elkins, Joseph Benson
Foraker, Walter Quintin Gresham, Marcus Alonzo Hanna, Benjamin Harrison, Eugene Gano
Hay, William McKinley, Joseph Homan Manley, John W. Noble, Henry C. Payne, Thomas
Collier Platt, Albert G. Porter, Robert Robertson, Theodore Roosevelt, Jeremiah McLain
Rusk, John Sherman, William H. Taft, Lew Wallace, and John Wanamaker.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Lawrence Quincy Mumford (1903-1982) cover the years 1939-1982, with the
bulk of the collection dating from 1954 to 1974, including correspondence, writings,
bibliographical material, invitations, schedules, programs, committee reports,
congressional bills, reports, newspaper clippings, and photographs.</p>
<p>Mumford’s correspondence chiefly reflects the personal aspects of his career, beginning
with his special appointment as director of the Processing Department at the Library of
Congress while on leave of absence from New York Public Library, 1940-1942. His
nomination as Librarian of Congress by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 is
documented by letters of support and congratulations from Library colleagues. His
correspondence as librarian consists primarily of letters of thanks and recommendation
and reflects the social and cultural duties of his office. </p>
<p>The writings consist of articles by Mumford and publications by others on topics of
interest to him.</p>
<p> A miscellany file includes appointment schedules, invitations, and programs;
biographical file; committee reports; conference file; congressional bills, reports, and
hearings; newspaper clippings; and photographs.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Otto Sternoff Beyer (1886-1948) consist of personal and professional
correspondence, memoranda, reports, speeches and articles, charts, and other papers, as
well as scrapbooks of clippings relating mainly to his professional career. The papers
span the years 1905-1951, but bulk largest from 1929 to 1941. The collection is
organized into eleven series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="gencorresp">General Correspondence</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">Subject File</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="genrailfile">General Railroad File</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="canrailfile">Canadian National
Railways</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="borailco">Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad Company</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="tenvalauth">Tennessee Valley Authority</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="poweradmin">Bonneville Power Administration</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="speewrit">Speech and Article File</ref>,
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="scrapb">Scrapbooks</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addit">Addition</ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="overs">Oversize</ref>.</p>
<p>During Beyer's military service in World War I, he developed a program of
union-management cooperation in army arsenals. Thereafter, he served as consulting
engineer to unions and management in various industrial concerns and in railway systems
such as the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company and the Canadian National Railways,
acquiring a reputation as a leader in the improvement of labor-management relations.
From 1933 to 1948, Beyer held a number of posts in the federal government. His papers
document his widespread activities in considerable detail, including labor-management
cooperation in the field of railway transportation, his connection with federal
agencies, and work in the area of labor relations, unions, wages, strikes, and
unemployment.</p>
<p>An <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addit">Addition</ref> series contains
biographical material and letters of condolence from Harry S. Truman, James Tobin, and
others government officials. The article file in the Addition contains Beyer's notes on
a projected history of railroad personnel, in which he was encouraged by Professor
Sumner Slichter of Harvard. The subject file contains background material on his various
positions with railroads, the Tennessee Valley Authority, and the National Mediation
Board during World War II. There is also material pertaining to Clara M. Beyer
consisting of family correspondence and photographs, White House invitations, and
material pertaining to her own position in the Labor Department.</p>
<p>Correspondents in the Addition include Franklin D. Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, Harry
S. Truman, David E. Lilienthal, Frances Perkins and William Green of the American
Federation of Labor.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received with attached and related matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, minutes, notes, reports, charts, articles, printed
matter, and miscellaneous material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, notes, charts, articles, printed
matter and miscellaneous material relating to Beyer's work regarding railroads.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, notes, charts, articles, printed
matter, and miscellaneous material relating to the Canadian National Railways.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, notes, charts, articles, printed
matter, and miscellaneous material relating to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad
Co.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, notes, charts, articles, printed
matter, and miscellaneous material relating to the Tennessee Valley Authority.</p>
</scopecontent>

matter, and miscellaneous material relating to the Bonneville Power
Administration. </p>
</scopecontent>

personnel located at the end of the series.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bound volumes of printed matter and miscellaneous material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, reports, notes, articles, memorabilia, and miscellaneous material.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Certificates and scrapbooks. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Jabez Lamar Munroe Curry (1825-1903) consist of diaries, correspondence,
an autograph collection, printed matter, clippings, memorabilia, notes and memoranda,
legal papers, accounts, lectures and sermons, essays, scrapbooks, a manuscript of an
autobiography, speeches and articles, and miscellaneous material. The collection spans
the years 1637-1939, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1866-1903.
The papers are organized into two parts. Part I is composed of a <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen"> Correspondence and General File. </ref> Part II
consists of four series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Corr">
Correspondence </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Auto">
Autographs </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Diary"> Diaries
</ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Misc"> Miscellany </ref>. </p>
<p>Included in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Auto"> Autographs </ref>
series are correspondence and letters (many to Curry himself) from United States
presidents; Confederate statesmen; Spanish noblemen, royalty, and writers; and American
and European artists, clergyman, diplomats, educators, historians, jurists, literary
figures, military men, reformers, scientists, and statesmen. Among the signatories are
John Quincy Adams, Henry Clay, Benjamin Franklin, Albert Gallatin, Washington Irving,
Thomas Jefferson, Andrew Johnson, James Madison, Luis de Onís, James K. Polk, Richard
Rush, Daniel Webster, Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, and Roger Williams. </p>
<p>Reports, journals, writings, printed matter, and other material in the Miscellany series
are organized mainly in bound volumes designated as Record Books A to G compiled by
Curry. Subjects in the collection concern topics such as the Peabody Education Fund, the
John F. Slater Fund for the Education of Freedmen, the Southern Education Board, Curry’s
studies on Civil War history and the civil government of the Confederacy, and diplomatic
matters in Spain. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Diary"> Diaries </ref> and much of
the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Corr"> correspondence </ref> relate
to Curry’s career as an educator, diplomat, and Baptist minister. Correspondents include
William Aiken, James Burrill Angel, Thomas F. Bayard, William Ashmead Courtenay, William
Maxwell Evarts, Hamilton Fish (1808-1893), Melville Weston Fuller, Moses Coit Gilman,
Rutherford Birchard Hayes, Samuel A. Green, Henry R Jackson, Theodore Lyman, James D.
Porter, Eben S. Stearns, Alexander H. H. Stuart, Moses Waddel, and Robert C.
Winthrop.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bound volumes of letters received by Curry and his wife. Includes reports,
writings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bound volumes of letters received by Curry and by others after his death. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters of prominent Americans and Europeans, many to Curry, but also predating
him, compiled as an autograph collection. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Pocket diaries.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Juliana Knoepfmacher (1899-1974), known primarily as “Lia” during the
American period of her career after the 1940s, span the years 1929-1980, with the bulk
of the material concentrated in the years 1940-1960. The collection consists of
professional files relating to her work as a child therapist and her writings on the
treatment of children. The papers contain lectures, speeches, writings, notes, minutes,
agenda, correspondence, memoranda, biographical material, and printed matter arranged
alphabetically by topic or type of material. Patient case files and notes are closed. </p>
<p>Much of the collection relates to Knoepfmacher’s professional associations and her work
as a training supervisor with the Jewish Board of Guardians in New York City. Minutes,
memoranda, and reports from the Jewish Board of Guardians and other organizations
explore such topics as supervision and teaching methods, time in treatment, treatment
goals, diagnostic criteria, private practice, and fee structures. Files from the Paul
Federn Study Group feature meeting notes and discussion material, including a paper by
August Aichhorn on transference in child guidance dated 1936. Writings by Knoepfmacher
include her account of a Montessori school she directed in Vienna from 1927 to 1937 and
articles and papers principally relating to her work in the field of child therapy. The
balance of the professional files include speeches, lectures, and writings of
others.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Joseph Anthony Lewis (1927-2013) span the years 1941-2007, with the bulk
of material dating from 1963 to 2001. The papers document primarily Lewis’s career as a
newspaper reporter and columnist for the <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> and his work as an author of several books about legal issues. In 1963 Lewis
won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting about the Supreme Court and is credited with
changing the field of legal journalism. Although not a lawyer, Lewis had a grasp of the
complexities of the law and a clear writing style that made legal issues more
understandable to the public. The collection consists of two parts with some topics and
time periods common to both parts. Part I consists chiefly of drafts and research files
for two of Lewis’s books, <title>
<part>Gideon’s Trumpet</part>
</title> (1964) and <title>
<part>Portrait of a Decade</part>
</title> (1964), and letters from readers of Lewis’s <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> column between 1969 and 1975. Part II makes up the bulk of the collection and
pertains chiefly to Lewis’s tenure while a reporter and columnist with the <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> from 1955 to 2001. Also included in Part II are files relating to his endeavors
as a university lecturer and his writings, including drafts of articles, book drafts,
and research files. The papers contain only a few items relating to Lewis’s career
before 1955. The collection is in English.</p>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Part I</emph>
</p>
<p>Part I of the Lewis Papers spans the years 1941-1975, with the bulk of material produced
from 1963 to 1974. Drafts, research files, and letters from readers of Lewis's <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> column between 1969 and 1975 are organized into three series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Subj">Subject File</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Lett">Letters from Readers</ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Write">Writings</ref>. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Lett">Letters from Readers</ref>
series comprises the largest part of Part I. Lewis's staff organized most of the letters
he received between 1969 and July 1973 into a topical file and those received after July
1973 into a chronological file. The series provides insight into public opinion during a
politically and socially turbulent era. Most of the letters were written by the general
public and concern issues such as busing for racial integration of schools, medicine and
health care, student protests, the Vietnam War, and Watergate. Prominent correspondents
include Hubert H. Humphrey on busing; Allen Ginsberg on crime and drugs; general
comments by David Halberstam and Daniel P. Moynihan; and Alfred M. Landon, John Le
Carré, Lewis Mumford, and Benjamin Spock on Vietnam. Lewis's replies to these letters
are included in the series. </p>
<p>The <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Write">Writings</ref> series
contains drafts and research files for two of Lewis's books. In <title>
<part>Gideon's Trumpet,</part>
</title> he explored the Supreme Court ruling in <title>
<part>Gideon v. Wainwright</part>
</title> that required states to provide indigent criminal defendants with free counsel.
Research for the book includes copies of letters between Clarence Earl Gideon, Abe
Fortas, and the court; correspondence and documents concerning amicus curiae briefs
filed by various states; correspondence with lawyers representing Gideon in his second
trial; and a survey of state public defender programs. In <title>
<part>Portrait of a Decade,</part>
</title> Lewis traced the civil rights movement from 1954 to 1964 largely through the<title>
<part> New York Times</part>
</title> reporting of these events. Although the research files consist primarily of
clippings, they also contain correspondence and an unsigned letter from Harris Wofford
concerning his role in arranging John F. Kennedy's phone call to Coretta Scott King in
November 1960. </p>
<p>The collection also contains a small <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Subj">Subject File</ref> comprising research material for some of Lewis's
articles.</p>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Part II</emph>
</p>
<p>Part II of the Lewis Papers spans from 1944-2007, with the bulk of material dating from
1964 to 2001. Papers in this addition supplement Part I of the collection. The majority
of the papers in Part II document Lewis’s career with the <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> from 1955 to 2001. Lewis reported and commented for over five decades on many
prominent issues relating to national and international affairs, including civil rights,
the press, the Supreme Court and various legal issues, the Vietnam War, the Watergate
scandal, the Iran-Contra Affair, the Middle East, the apartheid regime in South Africa,
immigration, and terrorism. Also represented in Part II are teaching files pertaining to
university classes that Lewis taught about legal issues and journalism, book files, and
a few family papers. The papers of Part II are arranged into the following series: <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref>, <ref target="letters">Letters from Readers</ref>,
<ref target="writ">Writings</ref>, <ref target="note">Notebooks</ref>, <ref target="miscell">Miscellany</ref>, and <ref target="class">Classified</ref>. </p>
<p>The <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> in Part II, 1949-2007, includes
correspondence, subject files, interviews, notes, reports, newspaper clippings, and
speeches and writings by Lewis. It is the largest series and focuses mainly on his
tenure as a reporter and columnist for the <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> from 1955 until his retirement in 2001. Papers in the <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref>, dating from 1955 to 1964, document Lewis’s reporting for the
Washington, D.C., bureau where he covered the Department of Justice and the Supreme
Court and includes files about various justices and Lewis’s notes for the October 1963
and 1964 terms. Other topics treated during his time in Washington are civil rights,
reapportionment, and habeas corpus. Also chronicled in the <ref target="annual">Annual
File</ref> is Lewis’s tenure as chief of the London, England, bureau from 1965 to
1972. Lewis’s reporting from London varied widely with coverage of politicians such as
Harold Wilson and Baron George Alfred Brown and topics such as architecture, Anthony
Burgess (writer), the Concorde, and the royal family. The London files also include
topics that featured prominently in later columns by Lewis such as, Africa, the Vietnam
War, the press, and race relations. Drafts of his “London weekender articles” are filed
in Part II of the <ref target="writ">Writings</ref> series. </p>
<p>In 1969 while still in London, Lewis began a column for the <title>
<part>New York Times</part>
</title> that would later be entitled “At Home Abroad” or “Abroad at Home” (depending on
his location) about national and international affairs. In 1973 Lewis returned to the
United States, writing the column from his home in Boston. Many of the columns reflected
Lewis’s interest in the law and his belief in its importance to a diverse country such
as the United States. Lewis brought a liberal perspective to his column on a wide-range
of issues such as the energy crisis in the 1970s, immigration, courts, the Supreme
Court, the environment (filed as surroundings), capital punishment, the press
(especially libel issues), free speech, civil liberties, human rights, terrorism,
presidential administrations and elections, the Iran-Contra Affair, Watergate, Latin
America, the Middle East, the Vietnam War, Africa, the struggle against apartheid in
South Africa, and the unrest in Yugoslavia during the 1990s. Files from 2001 to 2007
reflect Lewis’s interest and thoughts about the reaction of government leaders to the
September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the ensuing wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the
War on Terrorism. </p>
<p>The <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> is arranged by year except for the first
group of files from 1949 to 1965 which were filed together as a group by Lewis. <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> topics "A-L" for 1966 were not received by the
Library. Items from a prior <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> year are occasionally
carried over to the next year. Also some years of the <ref target="annual">Annual
File</ref> contain background information items that are dated earlier than the year
in which they are filed. The majority of the papers in the <ref target="annual">Annual
File</ref> were used by Lewis as background research for his reporting and columns.
Lewis, however, also traveled to gather information for his articles and columns. The
<ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> is replete with trip files, particularly for
Africa, the Middle East, and Vietnam, documenting Lewis’s insights. Information relating
to his trips is also chronicled in Part II of the <ref target="note">Notebooks</ref>
series.</p>
<p> The <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> also documents Lewis’s correspondence with
an array of individuals including colleagues, Supreme Court justices, judges, lawyers,
members of Congress, government officials, academics, entertainers, friends, and the
public. The bulk of the correspondence, usually including both incoming and outgoing,
features praise by Lewis relating to an achievement by a correspondent or vice-versa.
Most of the letters are filed in the miscellaneous folders located after topics in the
<ref target="annual">Annual File</ref>. Also documented in the <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> are invitations and arrangements for social engagements.
Correspondents include Russell Baker, Felix Frankfurter, Anna Freud, Henry Kissinger,
James Reston, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger. </p>
<p>The <ref target="letters">Letters from Readers series</ref> in Part II complements the
<ref target="Lett">Letters from Readers</ref> in Part I. This series includes
incoming letters, usually accompanied by Lewis’s outgoing replies. The incoming letters
are usually a one-time response to Lewis’s articles and commentary, although the letters
do feature recurring correspondents. Topics represented are the Middle East, Cambodia,
the Vietnam War, South Africa, abortion, race, immigration, the environment (filed under
surroundings by Lewis and his staff), Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, George
W. Bush, and political conflict in Yugoslavia during the 1990s. </p>
<p>The <ref target="writ">Writings</ref> in Part II are comprised chiefly of drafts of
Lewis’s “London weekender articles,” and files relating to several of Lewis’s books.
Most of the book files pertain to <title>
<part>Make No Law: The Sullivan Case and the First Amendment</part>
</title> in which Lewis examines the issues of freedom of speech, libel, and the press
in the Supreme Court case <emph>New York Times v. Sullivan</emph>. Other writings by
Lewis are located in Part II of the <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref>, especially
the byline folders and topical files. Some proposed books and a few books authored by
Lewis were also filed in the <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> by Lewis’s staff.
Files pertaining to <title>
<part>Gideon’s Trumpet</part>
</title> occur throughout the <ref target="annual">Annual File</ref>. Years after its
publication, Lewis still received correspondence about the book. Papers in 1979 and 1980
<ref target="annual">Annual File</ref> contain files relating to a movie based on <title>
<part>Gideon’s Trumpet</part>
</title>. </p>
<p>The <ref target="note">Notebooks</ref> series documents many of Lewis’s endeavors as a
reporter and columnist from 1974 to 1999. The Notebooks from his London bureau tenure,
1965-1972, cover a wide range of topics such as the beginning of the political violence
in Northern Ireland, the British entry into the European Economic Community (EEC), the
withdrawal of British forces abroad, and the relationship between the United States and
Great Britain. The Notebooks include Lewis’s interviews of people from Northern Ireland
regarding the Irish Republican Army bombings and the policies of the Democratic
Unionists Party. Also represented in the series are the British Parliament’s discussions
on withdrawing forces from territories east of Suez and military forces which were a
part of the British Army of the Rhine. Other notebooks chronicle the parliamentary
discussions about the involvement of the United States in the Vietnam War and the
bombing of Cambodia. Notebooks from 1973 to 1999 document mainly Lewis’s many trips to
London, Africa, and the Middle East. One 1973 notebook contains notes relating to
Watergate. </p>
<p>The <ref target="miscell">Miscellany</ref> series consists chiefly of files pertaining
to Lewis’s teaching files about legal issues and journalism. The majority of the
teaching files document Lewis’s lectures at Harvard Law School, Columbia University, and
Yale University. This series also includes appointment books, photographs, and a few
family papers.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Clippings, correspondence, speeches, reports, press releases, notes, and
photographs used in research for Lewis's newspaper columns. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters from readers of Lewis's columns, accompanied in most cases by copies of
his replies.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts, correspondence, and research files for <title>
<part>Gideon's Trumpet</part>
</title> and <title>
<part>Portrait of a Decade</part>
</title>. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, notebooks and notes, articles and columns by Lewis,
reports, interviews, speeches, newsletters, photographs, press releases, newspaper
clippings, printed matter, and other material documenting Lewis's professional
activities. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters from readers of Lewis's columns, usually accompanied by his replies. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, drafts of "London weekender" articles, book drafts, notes, letters
to the editor, and research material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Notebooks relating to Lewis's professional activities. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Appointment books and calendars, address files, family papers, notes and jottings,
photographs, teaching files, telephone messages, and press credentials. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Transcript of telephone call and a portion of an off-the-record talk. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The collection of Woodbury Lowery (1853-1906) relating to Spanish settlements in the
United States spans the years 1517-1803 and consists of bound volumes of material
gathered and organized by Woodbury for the preparation of his unfinished history of
“Spanish Settlements within the Present Limits of the United States,” containing catalog
records and handwritten transcripts of documents concerning California, Florida,
Louisiana, New Mexico, and Texas. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of George Kleine (1863-1931) span the years 1886-1946, with the bulk of the
material dated between 1900 and 1930. The collection consists primarily of business
records including correspondence, financial and legal papers, newspaper clippings,
printed matter, and miscellaneous material generated by Kleine's various financial
ventures in the motion picture industry. The papers are organized into three series:
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="list"> Inventories and Lists </ref>, and
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="distrifile"> Distribution File
</ref>.</p>
<p>A variety of material in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile">
Subject File </ref> documents the early history of the motion picture industry. There
are patent papers for some of the first projection equipment, legal documents from court
suits, and correspondence of major producers, distributors, and exhibitors.</p>
<p>The extent of Kleine's involvement in the industry is evident from files on corporations
that comprise a large portion of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>. In addition to papers relating to companies
that Kleine either owned or was associated with, such as Kleine Optical Company, Kalem
Company, and United Theatre Equipment Corporation, there are papers for Eastman Kodak
Company, Biograph Company, Essanay Film Manufacturing Co., and Famous Players-Lasky
Corporation.</p>
<p>Kleine's relationship with the Thomas A. Edison enterprises is documented in a file on
Edison and in correspondence with Thomas A. Edison, Inc. Kleine made extensive use of
Edison's “Conquest Film” series, which was especially designed for use in schools,
churches, and civic organizations. Kleine was also a member with Thomas A. Edison, Inc.,
and other firms in the first motion picture trust, the Motion Picture Patents Company,
and its distributing arm, the General Film Company, in which Kleine served as vice
president and later president. There are substantial files for this venture. The papers
also document the trust's fall from power following a suit against it by the Greater New
York Film Rental Company. The particulars of this suit and other legal entanglements are
detailed in files on litigation and Motion Picture Patents Company litigation.</p>
<p>Both the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref>
and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="distrifile"> Distribution File
</ref> series document Kleine's efforts to establish a non-theatrical film distribution
system. His aim to provide wholesome and instructional films is evident in the titles of
subject files: “better and highbrow film movements,” non-theatrical films,” “educational
films,” “educational distribution to universities,” and “educational institutions.” In
correspondence with William H. Dudley, chief of the Bureau of Visual Instruction of the
University of Wisconsin and organizer of the National Academy of Visual Instruction,
Kleine discusses his proposals for ensuring the moral content of film subjects. In the
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="distrifile"> Distribution File </ref>
series is evidence of his system for distributing films to schools, churches, and
community organizations through state universities.</p>
<p>The importation of foreign films consumed a significant part of Kleine's professional
interests beginning in 1903. Kleine eventually became the largest importer of foreign
films in the United States and Canada. In the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="subfile"> Subject File </ref> is correspondence with foreign film companies
such as Ambrosio (Societá Anonima Ambrosio), Cines (Societá Italiana Cines), and Eclipse
(Société Générale des Cinématographers). Among the foreign films featured are <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Last Days of Pompeii, Julius Caesar</part>
</title>, and the spectacular motion picture, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Quo Vadis?</part>
</title> Kleine discontinued importing films after the start of World War I, but
correspondence in the 1920s with Alfred Bourget, his representative in France, reveals a
continuing interest in the subject.</p>
<p>Other topics in the collection that reflect on the early history of the film trade
include files on censorship, copyright, prize fights, and World War I.</p>
<p>Though brief in size, the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="list">
Inventories and Lists </ref> series and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="distrifile"> Distribution File </ref> series provide an overview of the most
popular or sought-after film releases for the periods covered. Together with subject
files on banks, branches, distribution, finances, and historical material, they give a
detailed picture of the film distribution system for which Kleine is best known.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, financial and legal papers, clippings, printed matter, and
miscellaneous material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Lists and inventories of film titles, release schedules, prints, negatives, and
other material with related correspondence. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, financial records, and other items relating to the distribution of
motion pictures. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Elizabeth Severn (1879-1959) and Margaret Severn (1901-1997) span the
years 1880-1994, with the bulk of the material dating from 1910 to 1992. The collection
is in two parts. The part processed in 2013 is focused on Elizabeth Severn's activities
as a psychotherapist. The 2018 addition consists primarily of material related to dancer
Margaret Severn, Elizabeth Severn's daughter. The collection contains correspondence,
writings, photographs, printed matter, sketches, and digital files consisting of two
video documentaries, edited correspondence, and draft writings. The digital files are
related to Margaret Severn.</p>
<p>In the first part of the collection, focused on Elizabeth Severn, the correspondence is
almost entirely incoming letters, mostly from patients of Severn. There are also some
carbon copy letters written by World War II American Field Service volunteers giving
descriptions of wartime activities and postwar Germany. Other correspondents include
William Beebe and H. Halliday Sparling. Also of interest are the notes made during
lectures and seminars by Paul Federn and Robert Waelder. Although Elizabeth Severn and
her daughter Margaret maintained a long correspondence, Elizabeth Severn's portion is
not represented. Margaret, reportedly, in accordance with her mother's wishes, burned
her mother's letters in 1986. Elizabeth Severn's speeches and writings files include
drafts of three unpublished books as well as a set of typescript essays and speeches.
The printed matter includes publicity material for Elizabeth Severn's psychotherapist
career. The leaflets and cards advertise her lectures or her availability for therapy
sessions and document her travels. Newspaper clippings concern Severn lecture
appearances, news about psychoanalysis, and clippings of people who were close
acquaintances or patients of Severn. Reference copies of some photographs transferred to
the Prints and Photographs Division, including those with substantial writing on the
back, have been kept with the papers. Photographs include travel pictures, snapshots,
and portraits of Elizabeth Severn, as well as photographs of friends, family, and
patients, including a group of photographs of Severn with her analyst Sándor Ferenczi
and his wife, Gizella Ferenczi.</p>
<p>The 2018 addition is substantially larger than the original collection. Material
concerning Elizabeth Severn in the addition includes addressed envelopes tracking her
travels and residency changes from 1907 to 1935, received correspondence, writings, and
miscellaneous documents and printed matter. The bulk of the 2018 addition consists of
family correspondence: Margaret Severn's letters to her mother and grandmother (Amma).
In her responses to her mother's letters, information can be gleaned about Elizabeth
Severn's activities, travels, opinions, and her ongoing psychoanalytic relationship with
Sándor Ferenczi.</p>
<p>Margaret's letters to her mother and grandmother provide a detailed description of her
dance career and her personal life from 1919 to 1939. She often wrote daily letters and
was surprisingly frank with her mother concerning all aspects of her life including
sexual activity. Margaret Severn performed at the highest professional level of the
dance world in the United States and Europe. Trained as a ballet dancer when there were
no ballet companies in the United States, she spent years performing in vaudeville,
cabarets, and in the New York theater. In 1932 she moved to Paris and danced ballet in a
professional world dominated by Russian émigrés. Over the years, she danced with many of
the top dancers and choreographers of her time, and her letters provide an inside view
of the world of dance from 1920 to 1939. Dancers, choreographers, musicians, and
impresarios who worked with Margaret Severn, often appearing multiple times over the
years, and who figure in her letters are many but include the following: Luigi
Albertieri, Agnes De Mille, Michel Fokine, Ota Gygi, Eugene Iskoldoff, Kurt Jooss,
Bronislava Nijinska, Ida Rubinstein, Ruth St. Denis, and Alexander Steinert. An abortion
in April 1925, fully described in the letters, was the result of her 1924-1925 affair
with Hungarian violinist and fellow vaudeville performer, Ota Gygi. </p>
<p>Margaret Severn had her first major critical acclaim in 1920 when she performed in the
Greenwich Village Follies using masks created by artist Wladyslaw T. Benda. After the
success this performance, Benda taught Severn how to make her own masks for dance
performances. Her mask dances remained a signature performance piece throughout her
dance career. Two small masks of Margaret Severn are in the collection. In addition to
an active performance schedule, Severn opened the Dancers' Club at 347 W. 56th Street in
Manhattan (1930-1932). The club provided living accommodations, mail and laundry
services, practice facilities, an employment register, and social activities for
professional dancers, teachers, and students. Margaret sometimes included newsletters
from the club with her correspondence to her mother. In 1932, Margaret traveled to
Budapest to visit her mother and subsequently settled in Paris. She danced with
Bronislava Nijinska's ballet company in 1932 and with Ida Rubinstein's company for the
1934 Paris Opera House production that included the premiere of Stravinsky's <title render="italic">
<part>Perséphone</part>
</title>. Her letters to her mother provide lively
backstage descriptions of rehearsals and performances. Margaret Severn performed as
principal dancer and ballet master for a traveling company called the Ballet Russes de
Paris, 1935-1937. The company participated, with Margaret Severn as lead dancer, in the
July 1936 outdoor spectacle in Nymphenburg Park, Munich, Germany, called "Nacht der
Amazonen" (Night of the Amazons). For the performance, Severn was kidnapped by
horseback-riding Cossacks and later saved by Amazons (played by German women) on
horseback. "Nacht der Amazonen" was an annual event, 1936-1939. </p>
<p>The letters have many editorial marks, usually in green ink, that were made years later
when Margaret Severn was working on her memoir. Envelopes have been inscribed with notes
about the contents of the letter. The original writing in the letters and on the
envelopes, however, is still legible even with the edits. Although she never completed
her memoir, she did publish three articles in <title render="italic">
<part>Dance
Chronicle</part>
</title> based on parts of her correspondence. The articles are in the
autobiographical writings file. The digital files include her draft memoir and typed and
edited transcriptions of many of the letters, including early letters for which the
original paper copy is not in the collection. Presumably, the transcriptions of these
early letters are edited versions. Margaret Severn was also an artist. In addition to a
folder of her sketches, many of her letters are illustrated.</p>
<p>Peter Lipski's two film documentaries on Margaret Severn, <title render="italic">
<part>Dance
Masks: The World of Margaret Severn</part>
</title> (1980) and <title render="italic">
<part>Portrait of an Artist as a Young Woman </part>
</title>(1992) are both available as digital
files.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Norman Podhoretz cover the period 1950-1986 and consist of correspondence,
subject material, speeches and writings, printed matter, and miscellaneous material. The
collection is organized into five series: <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">General Correspondence</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Subj">Subject File</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Speech">Speeches and Writings File</ref>, <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Misc">Miscellany</ref>, and <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Add">Addition</ref>. </p>
<p>Norman Podhoretz was educated as a literary critic under such teachers as Lionel
Trilling at Columbia University and F. R. Leavis at Cambridge University. Early in his
career, Podhoretz was an advocate of left-wing ideology. He was later to break from the
predominantly leftist and liberal New York intellectual community and become a leading
spokesman for a conservative philosophy, using <title>
<part>Commentary </part>
</title>as a vehicle for discussing neoconservative ideas. His papers document the
development of his career as a writer, editor, and social and political thinker.</p>
<p> Podhoretz throughout his career corresponded with many prominent writers, critics,
editors, politicians and other public figures. The bulk of the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Gen">General Correspondence</ref> series is formed from
letters in Podhoretz's correspondence files at <title>
<part>Commentary</part>
</title> that were deemed inappropriate for the magazine's archive maintained by the
American Jewish Committee. Letters within the General Correspondence document
Podhoretz's involvement in literary and political activities. Among the correspondents
are Eldridge Cleaver, Allen Ginsburg, Lillian Hellman, Daniel P.Moynihan, Susan Sontag,
Terry Southern, Diana Trilling, and Kurt Vonnegut. There are also letters concerning
Podhoretz that were sent as enclosures to him, for example, a letter from Lionel
Trilling to Eliot Cohen, then editor-in-chief of <title>
<part>Commentary.</part>
</title> Although most of the correspondents are represented by only one or two letters,
the issues and ambiance of the time are chronicled in these communications.</p>
<p> Topics discussed in the General Correspondence series include censorship of Podhoretz's
writing as well as other literary works, endorsement of political candidates, support
for political points of view, and discussion of social and cultural issues such as
racism and poverty. Podhoretz's philosophical shift can in part be traced through the
General Correspondence. Letters related to individual works by him are filed in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Speech">Speeches and Writings File</ref>
series. </p>
<p>Featured in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Subj">Subject File</ref>
is Podhoretz's trip to India, Australia, and Asia in 1973, including a journal
containing sketches of people and places encountered in the various countries he
visited. His trip to Australia in 1982 to promote <title>
<part>The Present Danger</part>
</title> is also well documented. Another file in the series concerns Daniel Patrick
Moynihan's campaign for the Senate from New York in 1976. </p>
<p>The most extensive series is the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Speech">Speeches and Writings File</ref> including interviews, speeches, undergraduate
writings, short stories, articles, and books. Among the undergraduate writings are
Podhoretz's notebooks from a course in nineteenth-century British poetry taught by
Lionel Trilling. These notebooks are annotated by Trilling. Material from Podhoretz's
years at Cambridge includes copies of the English Tripos along with notes, drafts of his
thesis on Benjamin Disraeli, and notes from a class on the English moralists. The
collection also includes three unpublished short stories written when Podhoretz was in
the army. </p>
<p>The Articles subseries in the Speeches and Writings File contains a representative
sampling of Podhoretz's literary, social, and political criticism, including a number of
unpublished pieces. Drafts, galleys, published copies of articles along with
correspondence and research material are often present. Within the Articles file is an
expanded version of Podhoretz's thesis on Disraeli that he attempted to have published
in <title>
<part>Scrutiny</part>
</title> in 1953. Included with the essay is F.R. Leavis's critique of the piece. Among
the other literary essays in the collection are "Edmund Wilson: The Last of the
Patricians," "The Know Nothing Bohemians," "The Adventures of Saul Bellow," "Prurience
Subverted, or the Redemption of Candy," "In Defense of Editing," "Camus and His
Critics," and "F.R. Leavis: A Reevaluation." </p>
<p>Some of Podhoretz's social and political writings include "Masses, Classes, and Social
Criticism," "The New American Majority," and "J'Accuse," along with other articles
expounding Podhoretz's neoconservative point of view on subjects such as defense, the
Middle East, and Vietnam, most of which appeared in national magazines and newspapers. </p>
<p>Material exists in varying degrees to document the creation, production, and reception
of Podhoretz's five published books. In addition to drafts, galleys, and page proofs,
the collection includes correspondence from publishers and readers, book reviews, and
research material. The correspondence and book reviews impart a sense of how Podhoretz's
books were received and how he reacted to the mixed reception he met his works.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, with attachments. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, notes, printed material, and
journal. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Typewritten drafts with handwritten annotations, galleys, page proofs, notes,
research material and correspondence relating to speeches, interviews, books and
other writings by Podhoretz.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Newspaper clippings, printed material, and miscellaneous personal papers. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, notes, memoranda, typewritten drafts with handwritten
annotations, galleys and page proofs of writings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Diary, notebooks, general correspondence, interviews and statements, subject
files and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Robert Porter Patterson (1891-1952) span the years 1909-1956, with the
bulk of the material concentrated between 1930 and 1952. The papers are organized into
eight series: <ref target="correspond">Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="legal">Legal
File</ref>, <ref target="speech">Speech File</ref>, <ref target="miscella">Miscellany</ref>, <ref target="scrap">Scrapbooks</ref>, <ref target="war">Under
Secretary of War Files</ref>, <ref target="utid10001">2023 Addition</ref> and <ref target="classi">Classified</ref>. The <ref target="correspond">Correspondence</ref>
series is further arranged into seven subseries differentiated mostly by chronological
spans as compiled and maintained by Patterson before being received by the Library.
Additional correspondence can be found in the <ref target="utid10001">2023
Addition</ref> series. </p>
<p>The <ref target="legal">Legal File</ref> consists of briefs and memoranda on cases in
which Patterson presided as a judge, correspondence concerning the cases, and notes
taken or collected by him. Patterson served on the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York, 1930-1939, and on the United States Court of Appeals,
Second Circuit, 1939-1940. The case material from his judgeships is filed alphabetically
according to the type of case and therein alphabetically by name. The collection also
contains a file of legal note by Patterson on a variety of subjects. These notes, along
with Patterson's law school notebooks, illustrate the intensity of preparation and the
care that went into his study of the law. In the <ref target="legal">Legal File</ref> as
well is an index to Patterson's legal cases from 1930 to 1939 and memoranda concerning
his legal cases from 1939 to 1940.</p>
<p>The <ref target="speech">Speech File</ref>, <ref target="scrap">Scrapbooks</ref>, <ref target="miscella">Miscellany</ref>, and <ref target="war">Under Secretary of War
Files</ref> are primarily concerned with Patterson's career as a government official.
Also present are materials relating to his estate and to Margaret Patterson's donation
of the collection to the Library.</p>
<p>The <ref target="utid10001">2023 Addition</ref> series consists of outgoing
correspondence documenting Patterson's professional activities in the latter years of
his career, and speeches and statements given during and after his tenure as secretary
of war. </p>
<p>Patterson's career covered a wide variety of interests and activities. His early years,
1891 to 1930, are represented by general correspondence covering the years, 1919-1927,
his law school notebooks, 1912-1915, and a diary, 1925. There is no personal material
prior to 1919 and none between 1927 and 1930. The only other pre-1930 material is
correspondence and other material concerning the Harvard Law School Association that was
given to Patterson during his presidency of the organization, 1937-1949.</p>
<p>The files for the years 1930-1940 are primarily concerned with legal matters and
Patterson's judicial career. The only personal material from the period is
correspondence pertaining principally to New York city and state politics.</p>
<p>The period 1940-1947, when Patterson served in the War Department, is well documented in
the collection. As assistant secretary, then under secretary of war, 1940-1945,
Patterson's primary responsibility was procurement and supply. Subjects covered in the
correspondence, memoranda, and reports for the period include civilian versus military
control of the wartime economy, military strategy, projected problems of the postwar
world, and the difficulties involved in regulating and controlling a wartime economy. Of
special interest is a file on wartime cabinet meetings that Patterson attended as a
representative of the War Department.</p>
<p>Patterson's tenure as secretary of war, 1945-1947, is also well documented. Photocopies
of his appointment books record in detail his daily activities for the period. Important
subjects include cabinet meetings, the postwar settlement in Europe, switching from a
wartime economy to a peacetime economy, the demobilization of the American military, and
the projected merger of two cabinet departments into the Department of Defense.
Patterson was an ardent believer in universal military training. Files on the issue can
be found throughout the correspondence and the reports of the 1940s.</p>
<p>After his resignation as secretary of war in 1947, Patterson formed the legal firm of
Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler. Topics from the period include, the Marshall Plan,
the United Nations, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and the embryonic European
Common Market. Patterson served actively on such organizations as the American
Association for the United Nations, the American Committee on United Europe, the
Atlantic Union Committee, the United States Committee for a United Nations Genocide
Convention, the Committee on the Permanent Court of Arbitration, and the United States
Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government (1947-1953, the
first Hoover Commission). Also covered is Patterson's chairmanship of the Long Island
Rail Road Commission and his chairmanship of the American Bar Association Commission on
Organized Crime. Of interest as well is a file concerning Francis Joseph Cardinal
Spellman and the war claims of the Vatican in the late 1940s. Patterson was a strong
supporter of civil rights as evidenced by the file on Freedom House and correspondence
with Walter Francis White, executive secretary of the NAACP.</p>
<p>Correspondents in the collection include Henry Harley Arnold, Thurman Wesley Arnold,
Bernard M. Baruch, Francis Biddle, Chester Bowles, Nicholas Murray Butler, James F.
Byrnes, Benjamin N. Cardozo, Bennett Champ Clark, Mark W. Clark, Lucius D. Clay, James
Bryant Conant, Homer S. Cummings, Elmer Holmes Davis, Thomas E. Dewey, James Harold
Doolittle, Paul H. Douglas, Hugh Aloysius Drum, David Dubinsky, Allen Dulles, Dwight D.
Eisenhower, James A. Farley, James Forrestal, Felix Frankfurter, Philip L. Graham, Erwin
N. Griswold, Ernest Gruening, Augustus Noble Hand, Learned Hand, Alger Hiss, Anna
Rosenberg Hoffman, Herbert Hoover, Charles Evans Hughes, Philip C. Jessup, Jesse H.
Jones, Louis Arthur Johnson, Lyndon B. Johnson, Estes Kefauver, Ernest Joseph King,
Julius Klein, Alfred A. Knopf, William S. Knudsen, James McCauley Landis, Herbert H.
Lehman, David Eli Lilienthal, Robert A. Lovett, W. G. McAdoo, Douglas MacArthur, Patton
Pat McCarran, J. Howard McGrath, George C. Marshall, Sherman Minton, Robert Moses,
Donald Marr Nelson, Louis Nizer, William O'Dwyer, George S. Patton (1885-1945), Philip
B. Perlman, Howard C. Peterson, Roscoe Pound, Owen J. Roberts, Franklin D. Roosevelt,
Kenneth C. Royall, Samuel I. Rosenman, Leverett Saltonstall, Arthur M. Schlesinger
(1917-2007), Alexander P. de Seversky, Robert E. Sherwood, Spyros Panagiotes Skouras, H.
Alexander Smith, Lawrence E. Spivak, Brehon Burke Somervell, Francis Spellman, Henry L
Stimson, Herbert Bayard Swope, Stuart Symington, Harry S. Truman, Millard E. Tydings,
Arthur T. Vanderbilt, Tracy S. Voorhees, Robert F. Wagner (1877-1953), Walter Francis
White, and Charles Edward Wilson.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, financial data, memoranda, reports, and printed
matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, memoranda, reports, and some printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, memoranda, reports, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, memoranda, reports, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent, memoranda, reports, and a manuscript. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, memoranda, reports, and some printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Briefs, notes, correspondence concerning legal cases, reports, memoranda,
opinions, notebooks, and a docket book. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Speeches and radio broadcasts. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Reports, a manuscript, notes, correspondence of Margaret Patterson, guest books, a
journal, awards, financial statements, year books, biographical material,
clippings, appointment books, and a diary. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Clippings and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Subject files. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Bound volumes of outgoing correspondence, documenting Patterson's professional
activities in the latter years of his career, and speeches and statements given
during and after his tenure as secretary of war.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, and notes. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Barry Commoner (1917-2012 ) span the years 1915-2009, with the bulk of the
material dating from 1940 to 1990. The collection documents Commoner's career as a
biologist, ecologist, writer, and environmental activist. The papers are organized into
seven series: <ref target="personfile">Personal File</ref>, <ref target="speech">Speeches and Writings File</ref>, <ref target="xx01">Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="sf">Subject File</ref>, <ref target="organ">Organizations File</ref>, with a
<ref target="addit">1990 Addition</ref> and a <ref target="ad2">2019 Addition</ref>.
Researchers should keep in mind that the additions are sizeable with many repetitions of
file names and folder headings from the original accession. </p>
<p>Commoner, one of the founders of the environmental movement and a political activist,
was a professor of plant physiology and botany for many years at Washington University
in St. Louis, Missouri. He researched and published extensively on the tobacco mosaic
virus (for which he received the 1953 Newcomb Cleveland Prize) and the role of free
radicals. In addition to his purely scientific publications, Commoner wrote books on
environmentalism and the social aspects of science for the general public. Indeed,
providing scientific knowledge to the general public was the core of his political
activism. </p>
<p>Commoner’s political activism began with opposition to aboveground nuclear weapons
testing and the danger of radioactive fallout. In 1957, in collaboration with Linus
Pauling, Commoner wrote and distributed a letter calling for an end to nuclear testing.
Signed by thousands of scientists, it was presented to the president of the United
States and to the United Nations. In 1958 Commoner helped found the Greater St. Louis
Committee for Nuclear Information (CNI). The Baby Tooth Survey, conducted by CNI with
Commoner as one of the leaders, collected over two hundred thousand baby teeth to
measure the rising levels of radioactive strontium-90 in children’s bodies, the result
of fallout that had spread across the country from nuclear weapons testing in Nevada.
The Baby Tooth Survey attracted wide public attention, generating opposition to the
nuclear tests and influencing the signing of the 1963 Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Commoner
considered this the first victory of the environmental movement. </p>
<p>The core of Commoner’s philosophy of environmental activism was already at the heart of
the Baby Tooth Survey: a belief that scientists have a moral obligation to explain
science to the general public so the public, not just scientists and politicians, can
make informed decisions about science policy. He called this the “science information
movement.” The other cornerstone of his environmental thinking was his conviction that
unless the means of production, especially energy production, changed, environmental
degradation could not be stemmed, thus requiring political solutions. With the goal of
establishing a new, progressive, environmentally-engaged political party, Commoner ran
as the presidential Nominee of the Citizens Party in 1980. </p>
<p>The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of
each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within
the container list. </p>
<p>The <ref target="personfile">Personal File</ref> primarily consists of a general
correspondence file and telephone logs along with agendas, appointment books, diaries,
and notebooks. </p>
<p>The <ref target="speech">Speeches and Writings</ref> File includes drafts and published
copies of his scientific writings, drafts and reviews of his books intended for the
general public, and items documenting speaking engagements.</p>
<p>The <ref target="xx01">Correspondence</ref> series consists of professional
correspondence, received and sent, and includes some drafts of outgoing correspondence. </p>
<p>The <ref target="sf">Subject File</ref> contains material identified by topic, personal
name, material type, or name of organization.</p>
<p>The <ref target="organ">Organizations File</ref> includes only those organizations that
Commoner either founded, had leadership positions in, or was otherwise heavily involved
with. </p>
<p>The <ref target="addit">1990 Addition</ref> is arranged into six subseries: General
Correspondence, Speeches and Writings, Subject File, Research File, Photographs and
Slides, and Miscellany.</p>
<p>The <ref target="ad2">2019 Addition</ref> contains material received in 2011 and 2014.
This addition is arranged into four subseries and an oversize: a Clippings File,
Research File, Speeches and Writings, and Subject File.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Personal File is primarily comprised of a general correspondence file and
telephone logs along with other material documenting Commoner’s activities and
appointments. The telephone logs include notes about the content of conversations
or messages. The general correspondence is the bulk of the series. For Commoner's
professional correspondence, consult the Correspondence series.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, telephone logs, agendas, appointment books,
diaries, itineraries, and notebooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Speeches and Writings File includes drafts and published copies of his
scientific writings, drafts and reviews of his books intended for the general
public, items documenting speaking engagements in the chronological file, and
related correspondence and production material for publication projects. The book
file includes drafts for his bestselling books <title>
<part>The Closing Circle</part>
</title> (1971), <title>
<part>Making Peace with the Planet </part>
</title> (1990), <title>
<part>The Poverty of Power </part>
</title> (1976), and <title>
<part>Science and Survival</part>
</title> (1966). The files for his scientific articles include research notes,
draft writings, and published copies. Both the 1990 Addition and the 2019 Addition
have a Speeches and Writings subseries containing related material. </p>
<p>Material types include draft writings, published articles, book reviews,
correspondence, production material, and reports.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Professional correspondence, received and sent, including some drafts of outgoing
correspondence.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence with occasional attachments of printed
matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject File contains material identified by topic, personal name, material
type, or name of organization. (Note that select organization files are in the
Organizations series.) Major topics include biology and botany, civil defense,
ecology, environmental pollution, energy, genetics, Italy’s dioxin accident at
Seveso, nuclear technologies, peaceful uses of atomic energy, population growth,
radiation and radioactive fallout, and the Vietnam War. Margaret Mead, Ralph
Nader, Linus Pauling, and Albert Szent-Gyorgi have files in this series. Among the
many organizations represented are the United States Office of Naval Research and
the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, reports, printed matter, news clippings,
research notes, files of published scientific articles, and research
notebooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Organizations that Commoner either founded, had leadership positions in, or was
heavily involved with. This series also includes material from his faculty years
at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, reports, committee papers, speeches and
events material, financial records, and other related material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The files primarily pertain to the AAAS committees in which Commoner was most
active: the Committee on the Social Aspects of Science, the Committee on
Science in the Promotion of Human Welfare, and the Committee on Environmental
Alterations. These particular AAAS committees worked to engage scientists in
public policy issues such as radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons testing,
air quality, and energy consumption. Also present are files on annual meetings,
the board of directors, budgets, and AAAS publications. Prominent
correspondents include Chauncey Leake, Margaret Mead, Ward Pigman, and Dael
Wolfle. More files pertaining to the AAAS are in both the 1990 and 2019
Additions.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, draft writings, committee reports and
publications, financial records, minutes of meetings, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Commoner was the founder and director of the Center for the Biology of Natural
Systems (CBNS), an environmental health sciences research center created in
1966 and based at Washington University, where Commoner was a faculty member.
CBNS moved to Queens College, City University of New York in 1981. Queens
College changed its name to the Barry Commoner Center for Health and the
Environment in 2015. More files pertaining to CBNS are in both the 1990 and
2019 Additions.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, committee and task force records, grant
and financial material, research reports, and speeches and writings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>After the passage of the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in 1963, the Committee for
Nuclear Information expanded its mission to include other environmental policy
issues and changed its name to the Committee for Environmental Information.
Commoner continued in a leadership position. The file includes material on
nuclear testing and the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, and their publications <title>
<part>C.E. Eye</part>
</title>, <title>
<part>Environment</part>
</title>, and <title>
<part>Scientist and Citizen.</part>
</title>
</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, committee and board of directors
records, financial records, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Organized in 1958 by a group of scientists, including Commoner, and concerned
citizens in St. Louis, Missouri, who believed the public should have accurate
information about nuclear energy and radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons
testing. Material from the Baby Tooth Survey and the biological effects of
radioactive fallout is included here. The organization was one of many
committees around the country whose shared name was the Committee for Nuclear
Information (CNI). More files pertaining to this organization and the
publication <title>
<part>Nuclear Information</part>
</title> are in the 2019 Addition.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, financial records, grant proposals,
minutes of meetings, press releases, printed material, and testimonies.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Founded in 1963 by Commoner and others as a coordinating body for twenty-three
regional Committees for Nuclear/Environmental Information. Over time, the
affiliates ceased operating and SIPI inherited the mission of delivering
accurate scientific information to the public on a wide range of scientific
issues affecting public policy. More files pertaining to SIPI are in the 2019
Addition.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, newsletters, press releases, meeting
agendas and minutes, and financial material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Items from Commoner's faculty membership at the university with a focus on the
activities of the botany and other science departments. </p>
<p>Material types include corrrespondence, reports, grants, financial material,
course outlines and papers, and faculty and university communications.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The 1990 Addition is arranged into seven subseries: General Correspondence,
Speeches and Writings, Subject File, Research File, Photographs and Slides,
Miscellany and Oversize. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Articles and papers, a book file, speeches and related printed material, and an
untitled manuscript.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject file includes material on a variety of scientic and environmental
topics, as well as other topics such as patents, travel, grant applications,
and files on organizations such as the American Association for the Advancement
of Science (AAAS) and the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems (CBNS).</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, printed matter, committee papers, and
other miscellaneous papers.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Charts, graphs, computer printouts, and other research data.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Photographs, slides, and transparencies. Broken glass slides are
restricted.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Awards and certificates, clippings, physiology notes, telephone logs, printed
matter, and other miscellaneous items. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Computer printouts and demographic data from Commoner's research file and a set
of transparencies from the photographs and slides file.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The 2019 Addition contains material received in 2011 and 2014. This addition is
arranged into four subseries and oversize. Material from organizations represented
in the Organizations File of the original collection is placed in the Subject
File. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Newspaper and magazine clippings about Commoner from a wide array of
publications. Clippings were removed from binders, kept in original order, and
generally photocopied for preservation. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Notebooks, notes, and drafts of scientific research projects and studies by
Commoner.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Speeches and Writings subseries includes book drafts, a chronological file
of published articles, speeches, testimonies, and related material. The
chronological file reveals Commoner's shifting interests over time and includes
a mix of writings on scientific research, public policy, and political issues.
The book drafts and reviews of Commoner's books include <title>
<part>Air Pollution</part>
</title>, <title>
<part>Making Peace with the Planet</part>
</title>, and <title>
<part>The Poverty of Power. </part>
</title> The speaking engagements file contains correspondence, publicity,
itineraries, travel arrangements, and sometimes speech texts or notes and is
chronologically arranged. The speech, conference papers, and testimonies file
is also arranged chronologically but only contains the written texts.</p>
<p>Material types include drafts and published writings, speech texts, related
correspondence and printed matter, itineraries, and travel material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject File holds organization files, biographical material, including
items from Commoner's military service, a file on Linus Pauling and their work
together opposing nuclear weapons testing, documents from Commoner's consultant
work concerning the dioxin accident in Seveso, Italy, photographs and portraits
of Commoner, and other topical material. The organizations represented in the
Subject File that were central to Commoner's career include the American
