comedian Dick Gregory’s book, <title>
<part>From the Back of the Bus</part>
</title> (1962). Additional material relating to this project can be found in the
Alphabetical File series. Another group of writings contains material he wrote for
International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) corporate events. Orben’s
articles and essays about the writing, effective delivery, and use of humor in
speeches, as well as his speeches and speech material about humor in the
presidency are also included in this series. An unpublished memoir offers Orben’s
account of events in his life until the end of his time in the Gerald R. Ford
administration. Additional jokes that he sent to individuals and publications,
particularly topical material written in the 1990s, are located in the
Alphabetical File series under the name of the person or publication. </p>
<p>Material types include jokes, articles, books, book drafts, periodicals, a memoir,
notes, interview transcripts, speeches, and scripts.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>A small Miscellany series contains additional material documenting Orben's life
and career including press clippings about or mentioning him and photographs
depicting his work with President Gerald R. Ford. A scrapbook contains Orben's
earliest published writings, most of which relate to magic.</p>
<p>Material types include card files, calendars, photographs, press clippings, lists,
passports, a scrapbook, and video files from an award ceremony.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Card files of jokes, card files of addresses, photographs, a proclamation, and a
scrapbook.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of John A. Casazza (1924-2019) span the years 1938-2018, with the bulk of
the material dating from 1970 to 2012. The collection documents Casazza’s career in
the electric power industry as an engineer, educator, and author. The papers are in
English. The collection is organized into five series: <ref target="spwr">Speeches
and Writings File</ref>, <ref target="subjfile">Subject File</ref>, <ref target="coursefile">Course Materials</ref>, <ref target="misc">Miscellany</ref>,
and <ref target="digital">Digital File.</ref>
</p>
<p>The collection documents Casazza’s long career as an electrical engineer and business
executive at Public Service Electric and Gas Company. His papers also include
material related to his consulting firm, Casazza, Schultz &amp; Associates, his
teaching efforts with the American Education Institute, his advocacy work with Power
Engineers Supporting Truth, and the writing of his books and other publications.
Much of Casazza's work was published under the name Jack Casazza. As Casazza
believed engineers and their employers have a moral responsibility to provide a
service to society instead of prioritizing commercial interests, the papers
frequently explore ethical issues within the electric power industry. While he
advocated for engineers to have a greater role in setting electric power policy,
Casazza also worked to improve the technical competence of existing government
officials through educational programs.</p>
<p>The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description
of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions
within the container list.</p>
<p>The <ref target="spwr">Speeches and Writings File</ref> series includes book drafts,
articles, reports, unpublished memoirs, and talks written by Casazza.</p>
<p>The <ref target="subjfile">Subject File</ref> series contains files on a variety of
topics and issues related to the electric power industry. </p>
<p>The <ref target="coursefile">Course Materials</ref> series documents educational
programs offered by Casazza, Schultz &amp; Associates and the American Education
Institute.</p>
<p>The <ref target="misc">Miscellany</ref> series includes correspondence, photographs,
and other miscellaneous material pertaining to Casazza’s life and career.</p>
<p>The <ref target="digital">Digital File</ref> series contains the contents of floppy
disks and CDs created and used by Casazza and overlaps with material from the other
series.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Speeches and Writings File series includes book drafts, articles,
reports, unpublished memoirs, and talks written by Casazza. The series
contains drafts of several books by Casazza, including the first edition of <title>
<part>Understanding Electric Power Systems</part>
</title>. Research materials, correspondence, reviews, and copies of figures
and illustrations are also present for some of his books. The chronological
file in this series contains copies of Casazza’s professional articles,
conference talks, reports, lectures, and expert testimonies given before the
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and various congressional committees.
Casazza collected these materials in a set of twelve binders, assigned each
binder a number (i.e. “Book I”), and created separate indexes for the
contents of each binder. The container list maintains his original
organization of these materials. A complete index of all twelve “Books” is
included at the end of the chronological file. Additional articles and
reports not part of the chronological file are listed individually in the
container list. Some articles explore Casazza’s personal views on topics
like race relations and religion. The series also contains copies of
Casazza’s unpublished memoirs and a collection of writings he identified as
his most important works. This series also includes a selection of writings
by others that feature Casazza's annotations. For the most heavily annotated
books, the entire book was retained. In other cases, only the relevant pages
were photocopied. Also present is a draft of former Federal Power Commission
chairman Joseph C. Swidler’s autobiography. After Swidler's death, an edited
version of this autobiography was published as <title>
<part>Power and the Public Interest: The Memoirs of Joseph C.
Swidler</part>
</title>.</p>
<p> Material types include book drafts, articles, reports, correspondence,
notes, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject File series contains files on a variety of topics and issues
related to the electric power industry. Topics include transmission
capacity, federal energy legislation, major electric power failures, and the
environmental impact of utility companies. The files on national power
surveys document the Federal Power Commission's 1964 survey and Casazza’s
advocacy for an updated survey during the early 2000s. Also of interest are
the files on the Northeast blackout of 2003. Casazza formed Power Engineers
Supporting Truth (PEST) with Frank Delea, George C. Loehr, and Raymond
Maliszewski in response to this event. PEST criticized the federal
government’s investigation of the blackout, expressed concern about the
impact of government deregulation on the North American electric power
system, and looked to prevent future power failures from occurring. A small
portion of the Subject File documents Casazza’s interest in connections
between science and religion.</p>
<p> Material types include reports, articles, correspondence, printed matter,
notes, and clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Course Materials series documents educational programs offered by
Casazza, Schultz &amp; Associates and the American Education Institute. Some
programs were aimed at experienced engineers as continuing education
opportunities. Others were intended for non-engineers involved in setting
electric power policy, such as officials from the Federal Energy Regulatory
Commission and the Department of Defense. Course topics include transmission
system planning and design, pricing of transmission services, causes and
effects of electric power failures, electric system security, and the
history of the electric power industry. </p>
<p>Material types include lecture notes, course schedules, correspondence,
course evaluations, and transparencies.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Miscellany series includes correspondence, photographs, and other
miscellaneous material pertaining to Casazza’s life and career. Much of the
correspondence is related to Casazza’s interest in improving the technical
competence of government officials and his concerns about the future of the
engineering profession. Congratulatory letters on various professional
accomplishments and a small amount of personal correspondence are also
included. The photographs and clippings primarily document Casazza’s
projects in the electric power industry. Also present are several portraits
of Casazza.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, photographs, clippings, notes, a
family history of the Casazza and Russo families, an oral history interview,
copies of a patent, and résumés and other biographical material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Digital File series contains the contents of floppy disks and CDs created
and used by Casazza and overlaps with material from the other series. The
series documents his professional activities with Power Engineers Supporting
Truth, the American Education Insitute, and the Institute of Electrical and
Electronics Engineers. Also included are copies of various book drafts,
speeches and slide presentations, articles, and reports written by Casazza.
Major topics include electric power failures (especially the Northeast
blackout of 2003), electric power deregulation, and labor and personnel
issues affecting the electrical engineering profession. </p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, meeting minutes, PowerPoint
presentations, book drafts, articles, and reports.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Isabella Karle and Jerome Karle span the years 1912-2012, with the bulk
of the material dating from 1948 to 2008. The collection documents the Karles’
sixty-five year careers as physical chemists in the field of x-ray crystallography,
most of which was spent at the Laboratory for the Structure of Matter at the Naval
Research Laboratory (NRL) in Washington, DC. The papers are primarily in English,
with Polish and some German, Russian, Spanish, and Chinese. The papers are organized
into four series: <ref target="ik">Isabella Karle Papers</ref>, <ref target="jk">Jerome Karle Papers</ref>, <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref>,
and <ref target="oversize">Oversize</ref>.</p>
<p>The collection focuses almost entirely on the Karles’ professional careers with
little documentation of their personal lives. With the exception of the files in the
<ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series, Isabella and Jerome
maintained separate files which are arranged into distinct series, the <ref target="ik">Isabella Karle Papers</ref> and the <ref target="jk">Jerome Karle
Papers</ref>. Both of their papers reflect the development and use of methods
for crystal structure analysis with Jerome’s work skewing more toward theoretical
investigations and Isabella’s work involving the development and execution of
specific processes to analyze crystal structures, most of which were based on
Jerome’s theories and calculations. Furthermore, Isabella’s papers focus mostly on
her work within the laboratory, while Jerome’s reflect his wider involvement in the
field as an administrator and participant in a variety of professional organizations
and institutions. Though their working relationship is rarely evidenced in the
files, it is explored through oral history interviews and other biographical
materials throughout the collection. There is no documentation in the collection of
their involvement with the Manhattan Project or other aspects of their career
outside the NRL.</p>
<p>The <ref target="ik">Isabella Karle Papers</ref> series documents Karle’s scientific
contributions to the field of x-ray crystallography and chiefly includes research
and writing files produced at NRL, mostly between 1960 and 2008.</p>
<p>The <ref target="jk">Jerome Karle Papers</ref> document Karle’s contributions to the
field of crystallography, his administrative career at NRL, and involvement in
numerous scientific organizations, mostly between 1948 and 2008.</p>
<p>The <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series contains materials
related to projects, writings, speeches, and presentations on which Isabella and
Jerome participated together, the bulk of which span from 1950 to 2009.</p>
<p>The remaining series contains <ref target="oversize">Oversize</ref> files.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Isabella Karle Papers series documents Karle’s scientific contributions
to the field of x-ray crystallography and chiefly includes research and
writing files produced at NRL, mostly between 1960 and 2008. Her papers
include articles, correspondence, awards, performance appraisals,
biographical sketches, oral history transcripts, professional membership
files, and presentations given at scientific and academic conferences. The
bulk of Isabella Karle’s series is represented by her <ref target="ikresearch">Research File</ref>, which contains a significant
volume of raw crystallographic data, notes, figures and illustrations of
molecular structures, and correspondence with scientific collaborators at a
variety of national and international institutions. Aside from a small
number of biographical sketches and oral history transcripts, there are no
files that document Karle’s childhood, personal and family life, education,
or her work on the Manhattan Project.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Personal File subseries contains materials that provide a broad
overview of Isabella Karle’s career, mostly between 1970 and 2008. Files
include awards and nominations, résumés, oral history transcripts,
biographical sketches, and photographs. Of particular interest are
Karle’s performance reviews and project reports from NRL that provide
succinct overviews of her research, publications, speaking engagements,
and other professional activities. Other materials document her
involvement in various scientific societies including the National
Academy of Sciences, the American Philosophical Society, and the
American Crystallographic Association. Additional biographical materials
related to Karle can be found in the <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series and include awards, clippings, and oral
history interviews.</p>
<p>Material types include résumés, awards, certificates, oral history
transcripts, biographical sketches, business cards, photographs,
correspondence, memoranda, reports, applications, clippings, notes,
calendars, and schedules. Some visual materials are in digital
formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Correspondence subseries comprises professional correspondence
received by Isabella Karle, mostly spanning from 1965 to 2000. The bulk
of the subseries contains incoming letters from colleagues, publishers,
and other scientists in her field. Topics documented include her
research interests, status of projects and publications, involvement in
professional organizations, arrangements for speaking engagements,
biographical sketches, and referee comments by and for Karle. The
subseries is not comprehensive, and most correspondence related to
specific research, writings, speeches, and subjects can be found within
files maintained according to topic throughout the series. Most letters
addressed to both Isabella and Jerome can be found in the <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series.</p>
<p>Material types include letters, email printouts, memoranda, invitations,
and attachments including writings, programs, and itineraries.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Speeches and Writings subseries comprises files related to articles,
reports, speeches, lectures, and book chapters written by Isabella
Karle, mostly from 1960 to 2003. The files contain drafts, working
files, figures, illustrations, research data, notes, abstracts, and
correspondence. Frequent collaborators represented in the subseries
include Darshan Ranganathan, Subramania Ranganathan, Padmanabhan
Balaram, and Bernhard Witkop. The bulk of the speeches and writings
correspond to the molecular structure analyses contained in Karle’s <ref target="ikresearch">Research File</ref>. Published structures of
these complex organic and inorganic substances include steroids,
alkaloids, toxins, ionophores, and, especially, peptides, and relate to
such varied topics as the transport of ions, protection against
radiation damage, energetic and propellant materials, antimalarials,
antibiotics, non-addicting analgesics, shock, neurotoxins, explosives,
and nitrogen compounds. Also present in the subseries are Isabella’s
lecture files from a variety of x-ray crystallography study institutes,
many of which include lectures she presented with Jerome Karle. For
additional materials from these study institutes, as well as writings
and speeches written in collaboration with Jerome, see the <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series. Additional
writings, speeches, and related materials are interspersed throughout
the <ref target="ikresearch">Research File</ref> and <ref target="iksubject">Subject File</ref>. </p>
<p>Material types include articles, notes, research, data, figures,
illustrations, correspondence, conference programs, abstracts, speeches,
travel files, photographs, and bibliographies. Some textual and visual
materials are in digital formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject File subseries comprises files from a variety of Karle’s
professional efforts, and include name files, travel files, grant files,
and slides. Name files contain correspondence, draft publications,
notes, clippings, photographs, and crystallographic data related to
specific projects undertaken by Karle and the identified individual.
Travel files largely consist of Defense Department memoranda that detail
Karle’s attendance at conferences, meetings, award ceremonies, and
lecture engagements. Grant files include applications, progress reports,
and correspondence related to the National Institutes of Health-funded
“X-Ray Diffraction Studies of Oligopeptides” project from 1981 to 2008.
The subseries also contains referee comments and recommendations by
Karle. Of particular interest are the recommendations Karle wrote for
her daughters Louise Karle Hanson and Jean Karle Dean, both of whom
pursued careers in the field of chemistry. The associated correspondence
in these files contains some of the only references in the collection to
Jerome and Isabella Karle’s family life. Slides, arranged by subject,
likely relate to speeches, lectures, and presentations though are not
identified as such.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, publications, notes, clippings,
slides, photographs, research data, memoranda, applications, reports,
letters of recommendation, and travel files. Some textual materials are
in digital formats</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Research File subseries represents the bulk of the materials found in
the Isabella Karle Papers and chiefly comprises Karle’s extensive x-ray
crystallography research data, mostly from 1960 to 2006. Given the
technical nature of her research the subseries is largely arranged as
received with the original file names retained in order to preserve
context. An alternate alphabetical arrangement of the subseries can be
found at <ref href="https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.ms021006.apx">
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.ms021006.apx</ref>. Molecular
structures represented include Leu-enkephalin, valinomycin, lysozyme,
antamanide, batrachotoxinin A, and synthetic analogs of antamanide,
cycloamanide, hexapeptides, and depsipeptides. The Research File also
includes publications, draft writings, correspondence, lecture notes,
slides, and other materials related to the collected raw data. Project
and funding reports related to Isabella’s research can be found in
Jerome Karle’s NRL files within the <ref target="jkorganizations">Organizations and Institutions</ref> subseries.</p>
<p>Material types include crystallographic data printouts, photographs,
negatives, slides, diffractograms, notes, correspondence, reports,
memoranda, lectures, figures, illustrations, writings, and clippings.
Some articles, crystallographic data, figures, and illustrations are in
digital formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Jerome Karle Papers document Karle’s contributions to the field of
crystallography, his administrative career at NRL, and involvement in
numerous scientific organizations, mostly between 1948 and 2008. The series
features writings, speeches, correspondence, and subject files focusing on
his research in structural chemistry, highlighting his work in crystal
structure determination and the development of various diffraction
techniques. It also comprises files pertaining to his roles in developing
national and international science policy within the National Academy of
Sciences, International Union of Crystallography, and American Academy of
Crystallography.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Personal File subseries contains materials that are primarily
biographical and provide an overview of Jerome Karle’s life and career.
Files include biographical sketches, awards, résumés, photographs, and
clippings. The subseries documents Karle’s winning of the Nobel Prize in
chemistry in 1985 (shared with Herbert A. Hauptman), including his
subsequent involvement at various events as a Nobel laureate. Lectures
presented at meetings of Nobel laureates in Lindau, Germany, are filed
within the <ref target="jkspeeches">Speeches and Writings</ref>
subseries. Additional biographical materials related to Karle can be
found in the <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series
and include awards, clippings, and oral history interviews.</p>
<p>Material types include résumés, awards, certificates, clippings, business
cards, calendars, photographs, bibliographies, and correspondence.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Correspondence subseries comprises professional correspondence
received by Karle, the bulk of which spans from 1965 to 2000. Although
some outgoing letters are included, the subseries largely consists of
letters sent to Karle by colleagues, scientists, and admirers of his
work, especially after he won the Nobel Prize. Topics include
solicitation for comments on articles, vacancy announcements,
arrangements for speaking engagements and conference appearances,
reprint requests, and letters from individuals seeking his autograph or
advice. Additional correspondence related to the Nobel Prize can be
found in the <ref target="jkpersonal">Personal File</ref>. The bulk of
the correspondence in this subseries is of a general nature. Letters and
memoranda related to Karle’s career at NRL and within professional
organizations are filed in relevant folders in the <ref target="jkorganizations">Organizations and Institutions</ref>
subseries, and correspondence tied to specific projects or topics can be
found within associated materials in the Subject File. Most letters
addressed to both Isabella and Jerome can be found in the <ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series.</p>
<p>Material types include letters, email printouts, memoranda, invitations,
and greeting cards.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Speeches and Writings subseries comprises files related to articles,
lectures, abstracts, reports, and a monograph written by Karle focusing
on a range of topics relevant to his crystallography research. The bulk
of the materials span from 1950 to 2000. In addition to published and
unpublished writings, the files contain drafts, working files,
correspondence, research, and other background material. Topics explored
focus mostly on x-ray diffraction, gas electron diffraction, electron
diffraction, anomalous dispersion, and quantum mechanics. Some writings
focus on the analysis of crystal and molecular structure of specific
compounds. Frequent collaborators represented in the subseries include
Herbert A. Hauptman, Lou Massa, Lulu Huang, Richard Gilardi, John
Konnert, Wayne Hendrickson, and Judith Flippen-Anderson. Speech files
mostly include lectures presented at conferences, symposia, and
workshops. Lectures related to classes taught by Karle at the University
of Maryland can be found in the <ref target="jkorganizations">Organizations and Institutions</ref> subseries. Writings and
speeches prepared in collaboration with Isabella Karle are within the
<ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series.</p>
<p>Material types include articles, abstracts, figures, illustrations,
slides, correspondence, reports, presentations, testimonies, and
speeches. Some textual and visual materials are in digital formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Organizations and Institutions subseries documents Karle’s
professional memberships, appointments, involvement in numerous
crystallography organizations, and his career as an administrator at
NRL, mostly from his appointment as chief scientist within the
Laboratory for the Structure of Matter in 1968 through his retirement in
2009. The NRL materials include program reviews, progress reports,
proposals, and performance evaluations. The subseries focuses mostly on
Karle’s role as administrator at NRL, with research conducted under the
auspices of the laboratory filed elsewhere throughout the series where
appropriate. Karle held various leadership positions in many national
and international crystallography organizations, most notably the
International Union of Crystallographers, the American Crystallographic
Association, and the United States of America Committee for
Crystallography. The bulk of the files in this subseries details his
roles within these organizations in the 1970s and 1980s. Karle was also
active in general science organizations, most notably the National
Academy of Sciences, the files of which focus mostly on his involvement
on the Committee on Human Rights, 1991-1997, and as chair of the
chemistry section, 1988-1991. Other notable organizations where he was
involved on a wider level in affecting national science policy include
the International Council of Scientific Unions, the National Research
Council, and the National Science Foundation. The subseries also details
his involvement on boards and committees at his various alma maters
including City College of New York, the University of Michigan, and
Abraham Lincoln High School in New York City. There are no files from
his time as a student at these institutions. Files related to his
involvement with the NATO Advanced Study Institute can be found in the
<ref target="collaborations">Collaborations</ref> series.</p>
<p>Material types include meeting minutes, agendas, notes, correspondence,
proposals, conference programs, performance evaluations, itineraries,
personnel actions, reports, newsletters, financial documents, ballots,
press releases, and presentations. Some textual materials are in digital
formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Subject File primarily documents Karle’s research activities and
interests throughout his career, with an emphasis on his collaborative
working relationships at the NRL. The largest group of files in the
series are related to Steve Brenner, research chemist at NRL from 1962
to 2007, who collaborated with Karle on computer operations and
calculations. The files contain crystallographic data printouts along
with notes by Karle. Received in containers labeled “Steve Brenner
apps,” the files were arranged chronologically in the order they were
received. The folder dates were maintained in order to provide context,
especially given their specificity. Researchers should be aware that the
actual dates of materials within each folder may vary. A significant
research file mostly from the 1950s and early 1960s was also maintained
as received. These materials comprise notes, writings, equations, data,
and likely relate to Karle’s collaboration with Herbert A. Hauptman on
the topic of phase determination. Other significant collaborations in
the subseries include Karle’s work with Lulu Huang and Lou Massa on the
subject of quantum crystallography in the late 1990s and early 2000s.
Specific topics throughout the subseries include anomalous dispersion,
electron diffraction, various computational chemistry programs, and
projects associated with the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
The subseries also includes Karle’s recommendation letters and referee
comments. </p>
<p>Material types include reports, slides, clippings, notes, correspondence,
writings, schedules, laboratory notebooks, articles, pamphlets, and
photographs. Some textual materials are in digital formats.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Collaborations series contains materials related to projects, writings,
speeches, and presentations on which Isabella and Jerome participated
together, the bulk of which span from 1950 to 2009. The series contains many
files related to their involvement as instructors with the International
School of Crystallography and NATO Advanced Study Institute from the 1960s
through the 1980s. Biographical materials that provide insight into their
working relationship include oral history interview transcripts, clippings,
and interviews. Other notable topics and material types include C₂Cl₆
research, travel engagements, retirement information, correspondence, and
awards.</p>
<p>Material types include awards, transcripts, clippings, photographs,
correspondence, articles, presentations, speeches, lectures, notes, and
schedules.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Material types include crystallographic data printouts, figures,
illustrations, posters, note cards, glass slides, and blueprints.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Ara Mesrobian (1924-2019) span the years 1876-2011, with the bulk of
the material dating from 1941 to 1994. The collection documents Mesrobian’s deep
interest in rail travel and provides insight into mid-twentieth century rail travel,
the operations of railway historical societies, and railfan subculture in the United
States.</p>
<p>The collection is primarily comprised of Mesrobian’s correspondence files from 1950
to 2011 and documents travel logistics, railway historical society events and
activities, descriptions of trains, railways, and other transportation, and personal
and business matters. The correspondence is filed in reverse chronological order
within the folders. There is no correspondence from 1962. Mesrobian’s collections of
railroad dining car menus, railroad, trolley, and streetcar tickets and ticket
books, and other related ephemera also make up a significant portion of the
collection. These materials are primarily from the United States and Canada, with a
limited amount from Mesrobian’s European and Asian travels. There is also a
significant amount of material related to railway historical society meetings and
fan trips, including memorabilia associated with the last streetcar to travel over
the original electric streetcar system in Washington, D.C. in 1962.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Arthur J. Finkelstein span the years 1960-2019, with the bulk of the
material dating from 1970 to 1989. The collection documents Finkelstein's work as a
pollster and Republican political consultant. The papers are arranged into five series:
<ref target="consult">Consultant File,</ref>
<ref target="alpha">Alphabetical File,</ref>
<ref target="travel">Travel and Itineraries File,</ref>
<ref target="personal">Personal File</ref> and <ref target="oversize">Oversize</ref>. </p>
<p>After founding his political consulting company AJF &amp; Associates, Finkelstein played
a major part in the wave of Republican victories and the rise of the New Right during
the 1970s and 1980s. The collection focuses almost entirely on his professional career
and highlights the evolution of campaigns, fundraising, and messaging in this era. The
<ref target="consult">Consultant File</ref> in particular demonstrates these changes
as it showcases Finkelstein’s hands-on role as a campaign manager or consultant for a
number of races. However, as Finkelstein’s involvement varied from race to race, not
every campaign has extensive documentation. </p>
<p>The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of
each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within
the container list.</p>
<p>The <ref target="consult">Consultant File</ref> documents the mostly political work of
Arthur J. Finkelstein, containing memoranda, polls, and other material related to
various campaigns or organizations.</p>
<p>The <ref target="alpha">Alphabetical File</ref> contains a mix of Finkelstein's working
files, correspondence, and a variety of topics primarily concerned with Finkelstein's
professional life.</p>
<p>The <ref target="travel">Travel and Itineraries File</ref> contains Finkelstein's
scheduling books, detailing trips and meetings.</p>
<p>The <ref target="personal">Personal File</ref> contains a small collection of various
material concerning Finkelstein's college years and family.</p>
<p>
<ref target="personal">Oversize</ref> contains Rolodex cards, a scrapbook page, and a
campaign poster.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Consultant File documents the mostly political work of Arthur J. Finkelstein,
containing memorandum, polls, and other material related to various campaigns or
organizations. Specifically, the series contains material primarily from AJF &amp;
Associates, the polling and consulting company founded by Finkelstein. The firm
specialized in political consulting for Republican candidates, and Finkelstein’s
polling, coupled with direct mail for campaign fundraising and the use of
independent expenditures, helped lead to a wave of Republican victories in the
1980s. The work for these campaigns could range from a simple poll to complete
campaign management, where Finkelstein consulted on the crafting of oft-negative
television and radio advertisements, direct mail letters, and other general
advisement. Consequently, the amount of material in this series can vary from
client to client. Some of the most noteworthy clients represented in this series
are: James Lane Buckley, Alphonse D’Amato, Jesse Helms, Judy Koehler, Ronald S.
Lauder, Don Nickles, Connie Mack III, and Denny Smith. Alongside individual
candidates, Finkelstein played important roles in political action committees,
such as the National Conservative Political Action Committee and the National
Congressional Club. Later in his career, he helped consult for campaigns overseas,
the most notable featured in this series being the National Citizen’s Coalition in
Canada and the Likud party in Israel, where he managed the campaigns for Prime
Ministers Benjamin Netanyahu and Ariel Sharon. Also represented in this series is
the influence Finkelstein exercised in shaping state politics in New York,
specifically in Long Island.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, memoranda, polls, notes, and news
clippings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>The Alphabetical File contains a mix of Finkelstein's working files,
correspondence, and a variety of topics primarily concerned with his professional
life. The series is an expansion of a file arrangement managed by Finkelstein,
though it is unclear whether these files were kept for AJF &amp; Associates or
personal use. Some noteworthy contents of this series feature material related to
his board membership to the American Conservative Union and the libertarian
consumer advocacy group Consumer Alert, AJF &amp; Associates proposals, and the
response by Finkelstein and friends to an article published by <title>
<part>Boston Magazine</part>
</title> that publicly outed him as gay. Notable correspondents and gathered
subject material in this series includes John Terry Dolan, Joan Ferdinand, Jeane
J. Kirkpatrick, Gerald "Gerry" Nicholls, and Roger Stone, . Also included are
speeches, interviews, and articles written by Finkelstein.</p>
<p> Material types include correspondence, news clippings, articles, and message
books. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>The Travel and Itineraries File contains Finkelstein's scheduling books, detailing
trips and meetings. </p>
<p>Material types include schedule books and itineraries.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>The Personal File contains a small collection of material concerning Finkelstein's
college years and family. The most notable portion of this series includes
writings, notes, and clippings from Finkelstein's time as an undergraduate at
Queen's College, New York. The writings are of particular interest, containing
poems and letters written by him and a classmate which reveal a brief glimpse as
to how Finkelstein viewed himself at that time. Also included are papers related
to his family. </p>
<p>Material types include notes, letters, correspondence, articles, and news
clippings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>Material includes Rolodex cards, a scrapbook page, and a campaign poster.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The Presidential and Inaugural Collection spans the years 1835-2021, with the bulk of
the material dating from 1944 to 2021. The collection primarily documents
presidential inaugurations and the events that have historically surrounded them,
including balls and dinners, but the collection is not inclusive of every
presidential inauguration. The collection includes commemorative presidential
inauguration buttons, cutouts of candidates' faces, COVID-19 face masks from the
2021 inauguration, a Metrorail pass, programs, and tickets, as well as invitations
to balls, lunches, and other official events staged by the Joint Congressional
Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies. The Washington Assemblies file includes
invitations to balls celebrating George Washington's birthday. </p>
<p>The Kathleen D. Harney files pertain to her time serving as chief of the White House
Press Releases Office, during four presidential administrations between 1944 and
1967. Harney worked in the White House library where she was in charge of press
release files, and organized and maintained presidential statements. Her files
contain Christmas cards, commemorative programs, correspondence, invitations,
photographs, and other ephemera.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Thomas Lowe Hughes (1925-) span the dates 1918-2018, with the bulk of
the material dating from 1961 to 1991. The collection documents Hughes's career in
United States politics and foreign policy, especially as an aide to United States
politicians, Chester Bowles and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, as director of the
Department of State's Bureau of Intelligence and Research, and, later, as the
president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. The collection is
organized into eight series: <ref target="Congress">United States Congress </ref>,
<ref target="State">Department of State</ref>, <ref target="Carnegie">Carnegie
Endowment for International Peace</ref>, <ref target="Correspondence">General
Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="Speeches">Speeches and Writings</ref>, <ref target="Boards">Boards and Associations </ref>, <ref target="Personal">Personal
File</ref>, and <ref target="Classified">National Security Classified
Information</ref>.</p>
<p>The collection documents Hughes's interest and work in federal politics and foreign
policy, much of which was informed by his early involvement with and leadership in
the Student Federalists movement as a student at Carleton College and his travels
throughout Europe as a Rhodes scholar in the immediate postwar period. His papers
comprehensively cover the trajectory of his career in American foreign policy,
beginning in the United States Congress as an administrative assistant to Chester
Bowles and as legislative counsel to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, then moving into
various leadership roles in the Department of State and, finally, the Carnegie
Endowment for International Peace. Hughes's professional contacts, associations, and
affiliations, many of which Hughes worked to foster and maintain for the duration of
his career and beyond, feature prominently through correspondence and meeting notes,
filed across several series and found throughout the collection.</p>
<p>The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description
of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions
within the container list.</p>
<p>The <ref target="Congress">United States Congress</ref> series contains materials
documenting Hughes's early career working as legislative counsel to Senator Hubert
H. Humphrey (1955-1958) and his work as an administrative assistant to Congressman
Chester Bowles (1959-1960), as well as his continued professional and personal
associations with both throughout his career. </p>
<p>The <ref target="State">Department of State</ref> series contains material
documenting Hughes's positions with the Bureau of Intelligence and Research (INR)
and the United States Embassy, London.</p>
<p>The <ref target="Carnegie">Carnegie Endowment for International Peace</ref> series
spans the years 1948-2008, with the bulk of the material reflecting Hughes’s tenure
as the organization’s president between 1971 and 1991. This series primarily
contains records of major projects, events, and functions the endowment undertook
under Hughes's tutelage. </p>
<p>The <ref target="Correspondence">General Correspondence</ref> series was maintained
as received and is arranged into three groupings: Alphabetical file, Chronological
file, and Special signatures. The series primarily documents Hughes’s professional
career in the Department of State and Carnegie Endowment for International Peace,
with the majority reflecting Hughes’s years at the Carnegie Endowment. </p>
<p>The <ref target="Speeches">Speeches and Writings</ref> series contains transcripts of
speeches Hughes gave at a variety of professional and personal engagements,
articles, and an extensive collection of notes pertaining to speech and article
ideas, meetings, and other professional matters. </p>
<p>The <ref target="Boards">Boards and Associations</ref> series documents Hughes’s
involvement with various international affairs think tanks and nongovernmental
organizations.</p>
<p>The <ref target="Personal">Personal File</ref> contains material related to Hughes’s
education, military service, and endeavors outside of his later professional
career.</p>
<p>The remaining series contains <ref target="Classified">National Security Classified
Information</ref> associated with Hughes's tenure with the Department of State
and United States Congress as an aide to Hubert Humphrey and Chester Bowles.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The United States Congress series contains materials documenting Hughes's
early career working as legislative counsel to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey
(1955-1958) and his work as an administrative assistant to Congressman
Chester Bowles (1959-1960), as well as his continued professional and
personal associations with both throughout his career. The series also
contains a limited amount of material documenting Hughes’s association with
Vice President Walter F. Mondale. The Chester Bowles material documents
Hughes’s work for Bowles's congressional office and campaigns, including
correspondence from constituents, drafts of books and articles Hughes edited
for Bowles, files documenting bills Bowles worked on, as well as his
platforms and policies. Bowles’s participation in John F. Kennedy’s 1960
presidential campaign and subsequent appointment to Kennedy’s administration
as undersecretary of state is well represented through copies of letters to
Kennedy. Replies from Kennedy are present to a lesser degree. Also featured
is material relating to Bowles's two appointments as United States
ambassador to India, including drafts of his book, <emph render="italic">Ambassador's Report</emph>, and correspondence to Hughes from his
second tenure as ambassador. The Hubert H. Humphrey material documents
Hughes’s work with Humphrey as well as his continued association until
Humphrey’s death in 1978 and Hughes’s involvement with Humphrey’s legacy
after his death. Materials cover Humphrey’s policies in the Senate, his
electoral campaigns, the inner workings of his Senate office, and, to a
limited degree, his vice presidency. The Walter F. Mondale material is
limited and consists of correspondence between Mondale and Hughes and
ephemera related to Mondale.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, memoranda, notes, ephemera, writings,
drafts, and clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Department of State series contains material documenting Hughes's
positions with the Bureau of Intelligence and Research (INR) and the United
States Embassy, London. The material ranging from 1961 to 1969 covers
Hughes’s time as the deputy director, then director of INR and includes
meeting notes, correspondence, briefings, and reports relating to the Cuban
Missile Crisis, the Vietnam War, and other issues relating to the Cold War.
Travel files document a 1963 trip Hughes took to Germany and England in
conjunction with John F. Kennedy’s European tour and a 1964 trip to India
and Pakistan resulting in a comprehensive debriefing on the Indian
subcontinent. Files also include material on departmental politics and
business, Senate hearings, and special study groups. The chronological files
of George C. Denney within the series document Denney’s time as deputy
director of INR (1963-1974), and cover many of the same topics. Material
also includes notes and articles written and collected by Hughes after his
tenure at INR that primarily reflect on INR’s role in world events. The
London Embassy files document Hughes’s professional activities as minister
and deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in London, England,
from 1969 to1970. During this time, Hughes served as the second in command
to Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg. These materials include correspondence,
speeches, schedules and guest lists for embassy events, notes, printed
matter, and clippings.</p>
<p> Material types include correspondence, speeches, memoranda, notes, reports,
briefings, itineraries, and clippings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace series spans the years
1948-2008, with the bulk of the material reflecting Hughes’s tenure as the
organization’s president between 1971-1991. This series primarily contains
records of major projects, events, and functions the endowment undertook
under Hughes's tutelage. Major topics include the Arms Control Association,
Future of Arms Control panel, Face-to-Face communication program events, the
Mid-Atlantic Club, Board of Trustees meetings, and publication of <emph render="italic">Foreign Policy</emph> magazine. The bulk of the series
is formed by a subject file containing Hughes’s files regarding staff,
projects, contractors, and organizations with which the endowment regularly
collaborated. Many files contain Hughes’s notes and correspondence with
individuals regarding project ideas, statuses, and outcomes. Conferences and
meetings on the topics of foreign policy, nuclear arms, and United
States-Soviet relations, either sponsored by the endowment or attended by
Hughes, also feature prominently in the subject file and throughout the
series. Also of particular note are the files documenting the Board of
Trustees meetings. These files include planning materials for the
endowment’s biannual board meetings, meeting minutes, reports of the
president, and documents reflecting an extensive program review in 1987.
Also included are letters sent to the board regarding Alger Hiss’s position
as president of the organization in the wake of his accusation of espionage
in 1948. </p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, notes, reports, and printed matter.
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The General Correspondence series was maintained as received and is arranged
into three groupings: Alphabetical file, Chronological file, and Special
signatures. The series primarily documents Hughes’s professional career in
the Department of State and Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, with
the majority reflecting Hughes’s years at the Carnegie Endowment and his
contacts with diplomats and dignitaries. Topics across the series largely
relate to business matters and include interoffice memos and routine
outgoing correspondence. Files regarding named correspondents in the
Alphabetical and Special signatures groupings often include contextual and
analytical notes supplied by Hughes and, at times, associated clippings,
printed matter, and other ephemera. Researchers should note that extensive
personal correspondence chronicling Hughes’s undergraduate and graduate
education and extracurricular activities is located in the <ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="Personal">Personal
File</ref>.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>The Speeches and Writing series contains transcripts of speeches Hughes gave
at a variety of professional and personal engagements, articles, and an
extensive collection of notes pertaining to speech and article ideas,
meetings, and other professional matters. The speeches in this series span
the years 1954-2007 and represent engagements in which Hughes participated
while working for the Department of State's Bureau of Intelligence and
Research and for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace as president
and president emeritus. The majority of the speeches are arranged
chronologically, with some arranged topically for specific functions where
Hughes spoke regularly, namely Mid-Atlantic Club meetings, Carnegie
Endowment Board of Trustees meetings, and gatherings of the Oxford-Cambridge
Association. The writings in this series are largely article adaptations of
Hughes’s speeches published in <emph render="italic">Foreign Affairs</emph>
magazine. Also included is material chronicling a preface Hughes wrote for
the Bureau of Intelligence and Research’s Vietnam study after it was
declassified in 2004. The notes in this series are extensive and cover a
wide variety of topics ranging from personal and professional meetings, to
impressions of projects, colleagues, and current events, and ideas for
article and speech content. Hughes's notes are filed across the collection
in multiple series. Other series with significant notes include the <ref target="State">Department of State</ref>, Bureau of Intelligence and
Research file and <ref target="Carnegie">Carnegie Endowment for Intentional
Peace</ref> Subject file. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Boards and Associations series documents Hughes’s involvement with
various international affairs think tanks and nongovernmental organizations.
Hughes served on the boards of several institutions that aimed to conduct
foreign policy research and to strengthen diplomatic relations between the
United States and its Western allies. Several of these boards and
associations specifically focus on United States-German relations. Major
topics include the global economy, German reunification, international
security and defense, the recruitment and selection of new board members,
fundraising and grants, and logistics for meetings, conferences, and
lectures.</p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, meeting minutes, notes, reports,
conference programs, and clippings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The Personal File contains material related to Hughes’s education, military
service, and endeavors outside of his later professional career.
Correspondence written and received by Hughes while an undergraduate at
Carleton College (1943-1947), a Rhodes Scholar at Balliol College,
University of Oxford (1947-1949), law student at Yale Law School
(1949-1952), and lieutenant in the Air Force (1953-1954) comprises the
majority of the series. Major topics include Hughes’s involvement with the
Student Federalists movement, especially as national president from 1944 to
1945, travels around Europe in the postwar period, work with the Foundation
for World Government in ʻEn ha-Shofeṭ, Israel, in the summer of 1950, and
early work as a law student with the Senate Subcommittee on Labor and Labor
Management Relations in the summer of 1951. Letters across the series
feature Hughes's parents, Evan Raymond Hughes and Alice Lowe Hughes,
friends, and contacts from the Student Federalists movement. The
correspondence in this series was maintained as received and is organized by
institution with which Hughes was affiliated or location at which he resided
at a given time. Researchers should note that many topics and
correspondents, namely contacts associated with the Student Federalists
movement, are spread across the series. Researchers should also consult
the<ref target="Correspondence"> General Correspondence</ref> file, as
relevant correspondence from Hughes’s pre-career years is included, though
to a limited degree. </p>
<p>Material types include correspondence, photographs, military papers, and
printed material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>Material types include correspondence, memoranda, notes, and briefings
primarily from Thomas Hughes’ tenure at the Department of State.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Ann Cottrell Free (1916-2004) span the years 1854-2018, with the bulk of
the material dating from 1935 to 2000. The collection documents Free’s personal life and
professional career as a journalist, author, environmentalist, and animal welfare
advocate. The papers are primarily in English, with French, Spanish, and Chinese. The
collection is organized into eight series: <ref target="personal">Personal File</ref>,
<ref target="correspondence">Correspondence</ref>, <ref target="writings">Speeches
and Writings</ref>, <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref>, <ref target="photographs">Photographs</ref>, <ref target="notebooks">Notebooks and
Diaries</ref>, <ref target="classified">National Security Classified
Information</ref>, and <ref target="oversize">Oversize</ref>.</p>
<p>The collection focuses on both Free’s personal life and professional career. The bulk of
the collection is arranged by subject and reflects file groupings and folder titles
created and maintained by Free. As a result, the collection is highly interconnected
with related topical files found in multiple locations within and across series. Prior
to donation to the Library of Congress, Free’s daughter, Elissa Blake Free, also
arranged some of the material, sometimes including personal notes to provide greater
context to the files. Some personalized or unconventional folder headings were placed in
quotation marks to reflect Free’s original terminology and language used throughout the
collection. The collection reflects the many topics Free was passionate about and
explored in her writing throughout her life. Prominent topics include animal welfare,
the environment, nature, civil rights, the plight of refugees, and the empowerment of
women. </p>
<p>The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of
each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within
the container list.</p>
<p>The <ref target="personal">Personal File</ref> series primarily contains biographical
material that provide an overview of Free’s life and career.</p>
<p>The <ref target="correspondence">Correspondence</ref> series comprises personal and
professional correspondence from Free’s family, friends, and colleagues, the bulk of
which spans from 1937 to 1997.</p>
<p>The <ref target="writings">Speeches and Writings</ref> series comprises articles, books,
short stories, speeches, and essays written by Free.</p>
<p>The <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref> series largely consists of working and
background files that document the breadth of topics Free wrote about throughout her
career.</p>
<p>The <ref target="photographs">Photographs</ref> series comprises prints, negatives, and
scrapbooks that mostly document Free, her family, her friends, and her travels in the
late 1940s.</p>
<p>The <ref target="notebooks">Notebooks and Diaries</ref> series contains Free’s notebooks
and diaries spanning from her college years in the late 1930s until her death in
2004.</p>
<p>The remaining series contain <ref target="oversize">Oversize</ref> and <ref target="classified">National Security Classified Information</ref> material.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The <ref target="personal">Personal File</ref> series primarily contains
biographical material that provides an overview of Free’s life and career. This is
largely reflected in transcripts of detailed oral history interviews with Free
regarding her animal advocacy efforts, experiences as a female journalist in the
1940s, and work in China with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation
Administration. Other biographical material includes awards, biographical
sketches, articles about Free, résumés, and files related to her birth, marriage,
and death. Of particular interest in the series is a file of notes and
correspondence related to sessions with psychologist Elaine W. Cotlove in which
Free discusses and analyzes her romantic relationships with women in the 1930s and
1940s. The series also contains material related to Free's family, mostly the
papers of her mother, Emily Blake Cottrell, including correspondence, notebooks,
and diaries. Free’s correspondence with her mother, however, is maintained
primarily in the <ref target="correspondence">Correspondence</ref> series. While
the series contains biographical and autobiographical material, similar files can
be found throughout other series in the collection, mostly in Free's writings,
diaries, and notebooks.</p>
<p>Material types include résumés, transcripts, awards, certificates, clippings,
business cards, correspondence, recipes, and notes. Some textual material is in
digital format. The file structure of the digital content maintained as
received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The <ref target="correspondence">Correspondence</ref> series comprises personal
and professional correspondence from Free's family, friends, and colleagues, the
bulk of which spans from 1937 to 1997. The correspondence is wide-ranging,
touching on many aspects of Free’s life and career. Details of her travels in the
1940s are reflected within the series in letters to Emily Blake Cottrell and John
Oudine, in a subject file on India, and in a compilation of letters to and from
her travel companion, Verna Mae Feuerhelm Cody. Other files of note include
letters related to Free’s romantic relationships with Margaret Johnson, Claude
James, and Isabelle Ziegler. A file of “early job letters” reflects Free’s
experiences with sexism in the journalism profession from the 1930s to 1950s. The
series does not represent the entirety of correspondence in the collection as
letters are filed throughout other series. Researchers are encouraged to consult
the <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref> series for correspondence related to
specific subjects.</p>
<p>Material types include letters, memoranda, invitations, greeting cards, telegrams,
faxes, postcards, photographs, and writings.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The <ref target="writings">Speeches and Writings</ref> series comprises articles,
books, short stories, poems, speeches, and essays written by Free. The bulk of the
writings spans from 1942 to 1999. In addition to published and unpublished
writings, the files contain drafts, working files, and background on Free’s
publishing company, Flying Fox Press. Files are mostly arranged by type of
writing, with the exception of a group of files Free arranged by subject that
include a largely unorganized mix of articles, drafts, notes, and fragments.
Additional files containing both published and unpublished writings, namely Free’s
writings on the Animal Welfare Act, Rachel Carson, China, the Marshall Plan,
Albert Schweitzer, and Eleanor Roosevelt, can be found in the <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref>. Notable unpublished manuscripts in this
series mostly focus on animal welfare topics. Free’s unpublished manuscript about
her experiences in China in the 1940s and her biography of Rachel Carson can be
found in the <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref>. Some writings arranged by
subject also include photographs, most notably the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps
and Women's Royal Navy Service files.</p>
<p>Material types include articles, poems, essays, books, speeches, short stories,
outlines, notes, clippings, drafts, correspondence, photographs, and
advertisements. Some textual and visual material and images are in digital
formats. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The bulk of the collection, the <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref> series
largely consists of working and background files that document the breadth of
topics Free wrote about throughout her career. Most of the files in the series
relate to animals and animal welfare issues including humane societies, animal
legislation, laboratory animals, farm animals, pets, wildlife, ethics, and
specifically the relationships between humans and animals. Other significant files
focus on topics Free revisited throughout her life and wrote about in detail.
These include extensive files on famine and politics in post war China, Eleanor
Roosevelt and her relationship with the female press corps, the “reverence for
life” philosophy of Albert Schweitzer, and Rachel Carson and her impact on
environmental activism. Many of these files contain writings, correspondence,
notes, speeches, diaries, photographs, and research files. The series also
documents Free’s involvement with the Albert Schweitzer Fellowship, Mrs.
Roosevelt’s Press Conference Association, National Press Club (previously the
Washington Press Club), Rachel Carson Council, Society of Woman Geographers, and
many local and national humane societies and animal welfare associations. Other
noteworthy individuals documented within the series include Elisabeth De Croÿ,
Zhou Enlai, Ellen Glasgow, Temple Grandin, Lister Hill, Mary Hornaday, Ruby Black,
Edouard Nies-Berger, Malvina Stephenson, Christine Stevens, and Ernest P. Walker. </p>
<p>Material types include clippings, notes, correspondence, writings, printed matter,
and photographs.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The <ref target="photographs">Photographs</ref> series comprises prints,
negatives, and scrapbooks that mostly document Free, her family, her friends, and
travels in the late 1940s. The photographs represent a mix of professional
portraits and snapshots. The travel photographs are extensive and document Free’s
travels with Verna Mae Feuerhelm Cody in 1946 and 1947 throughout Asia, Europe,
and the Middle East. Of note from this trip are many photographs from India taken
around the time the Indian Independence Act went into effect in 1947. A detailed
itinerary of this trip can be found in the "Around the world with Ann and Verna"
file in the <ref target="subject">Subject File</ref> series. Other photographs
documenting Free’s travels include those related to her position with the United
Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in China and work in Europe
reporting on the Marshall Plan. The oral history photographs include noteworthy
images handpicked by the donor to accompany transcripts found in the <ref target="personal">Personal File</ref> series. Researchers should be aware that
photographs exist in other series within the collection and were retained within
those files to maintain appropriate context. </p>
<p>Material types include prints, negatives, and scrapbooks.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>This series contains Free’s notebooks and diaries spanning from the early 1930s
until her death in 2004. Some notebooks are labeled according to topic, but most
are chronological, documenting both professional and personal aspects of her life.
In most cases, there is little distinction between the personal and professional,
with many notebooks featuring notes on articles, drafts, interviews, and research
as well as more domestic matters including appointments, grocery shopping, and
house maintenance. Noteworthy diaries include those reflecting her time in China,
India, and Europe in the 1940s. Also of note are notebooks related to Rachel
Carson and a group of notebooks surrounding the birth of her daughter, Elissa
Blake Free, in 1955. </p>
<p>Material types include notebooks, diaries, journals, daybooks, and note cards.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>The <ref target="classified">National Security Classified Information</ref> series
contains one incomplete report prepared for the Secretary of State for Public
Affairs providing an analysis of stereotyped concepts of the United States
perpetuated in the Soviet Union and neighboring countries.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Material types include posters, photographs, blueprints, notes, newsletters,
buttons, a travel satchel, a diploma, a menu, and an award.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Joseph Taggart McNarney (1893-1972) span the years 1917 to 1957, with
the bulk of material dating between 1944 and 1947. The collection primarily consists
of office logbooks with summaries of McNarney's daily meetings including attendees,
topics, and decisions. The logbooks document his time as deputy supreme allied
commander of the Mediterranean Theatre (October 1944 to September 1945) and as
commanding general, United States Forces, European Theater, and military governor of
the American-occupied zone in Germany (November 1945 to March 1947). Also included
are a 1941 diary and family photographs. </p>
<p>The collection provides insight into the American entry into World War II and the
last months of World War II in Europe as well as the immediate postwar period. The
1941 diary documents McNarney's daily activities as chief of staff of the United
States Army Special Observer Group in London. Topics include his role in planning
for the eventuality of the United States entering the war, British use of land-lease
supplies, a trip to Moscow to assess Soviet military viability, and involvement in
negotiations over the allocation of United States military aircraft. Entries in the
logbooks cover discussions and planning for Allied offenses in northern Italy in the
spring of 1945 and the responses to the capitulation of German forces in Italy.
McNarney's logs from the postwar period include discussions of demobilization of
United States forces, staffing issues, denazification policies, food rationing, and
treatment of displaced persons. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of Edwin Swillinger span the years 1945 to 2021, with the bulk of the
material dating from 1945 to 1954. The collection documents Swillinger's service as
a medic in the United States Army during the Allied occupation of Japan following
World War II. The collection consists primarily of photographs and military
ephemera, such as camp newsletters, meal tickets, and Selective Service orders,
taken from a scrapbook kept by Swillinger to document his military service and that
of his twin brother, Richard Swillinger. Photographs are mainly candid and depict
primarily military personnel and installations in the United States and Japan,
including images of Nagasaki, Japan, in 1946 showing the aftereffects of the atomic
bomb on the landscape. Material not part of the scrapbook consists of photocopies of
letters written by Swillinger to his then-girlfriend Rose Marie Hartman, and a 1947
English translation of a 1945 report by Japanese doctors into the effects of
radiation on the population of Nagasaki.</p>
<p>Material removed from the scrapbook has been photocopied to promote ease of access
and preservation of the originals. Researchers are asked to use the photocopies in
lieu of the originals, where available.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>Henry Harley Arnold (1886-1950)</part>
</persname> span the years 1903 to 1967, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the
years of World War II (1940-1946). The collection is large and contains material on
almost all aspects of Arnold's adult life. The most comprehensive documentation,
however, covers Arnold's tenure as chief of the <corpname>
<part>United States Army Air Corps</part>
</corpname> (1938-1942), chief of the <corpname>
<part>army air forces</part>
</corpname> (1941-1942), and commanding general of the <corpname>
<part>army air forces</part>
</corpname> (1942-1946). These changes in nomenclature reflect the growth of the
military air arm from a small auxiliary of the <corpname>
<part>army</part>
</corpname> in the 1930s to a massive semi-autonomous armed service in World War II
which became formally independent of the <corpname>
<part>Army</part>
</corpname> in 1947. Arnold, one of the nation's earliest military pilots, built what
became the modern <corpname>
<part>United States Air Force,</part>
</corpname> and his papers are a documentation of that creation.</p>
<p>The papers are divided into a number of series and subseries. Several of the subseries
contain detailed indexes which were prepared contemporaneously by Arnold's military
staff or later by personal assistants either to Arnold or his wife, Eleanor Pool Arnold,
after he left active service. In some cases, documents on the same or similar subjects
are found in different subseries. When Arnold's papers arrived at <corpname>
<part>Library of Congress,</part>
</corpname> large sections came in an arrangement devised by Arnold and his staff during
the creation and use of the papers. It was judged best not to modify Arnold's
arrangement because it reflected Arnold's use of the papers and because several of these
sections came with detailed indexes providing excellent research access to this
material.</p>
<p>The <ref target="family" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Family Papers </ref>
series, 1922-1955, consists largely of correspondence between Arnold and his family
during the 1930s and 1940s. Most of this correspondence deals with family affairs along
with some family business activities.</p>
<p>The <ref target="journals" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Journals and Notebooks
</ref> series, 1908-1946, includes a few journals that go back to Arnold's earliest
flying days and the <corpname>
<part>army air corps.</part>
</corpname> Of significant interest are Arnold's notebooks from World War II when he
took part in several of the major wartime conferences of the Allied leadership. Arnold
kept notes on those meetings in small pocket diaries. These notes were later
transcribed, and Arnold often interspersed with the typed transcriptions documents
relating to the events noted in the journals. Arnold's notes include both substantive
remarks about the issues discussed as well as observations about the principal figures
at the conferences and physical aspects of the trip. Among the key wartime conferences
recorded in Arnold's journals are those of <persname>
<part>Roosevelt</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Churchill</part>
</persname> at <corpname>
<part>Placentia Bay in 1941,</part>
</corpname> the <corpname>
<part>1943 Cairo conferences</part>
</corpname> with <persname>
<part>Roosevelt</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Churchill,</part>
</persname> the <corpname>
<part>Teheran conference</part>
</corpname> with <persname>
<part>Stalin,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Churchill</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Roosevelt,</part>
</persname> and the <corpname>
<part>1944 Roosevelt-Churchill conference at Quebec.</part>
</corpname> Also present are journals Arnold kept for wartime inspection trips to <geogname>
<part>Great Britain,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>China,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>North Africa</part>
</geogname> and the <geogname>
<part>Pacific</part>
</geogname> theater.</p>
<p>The <ref target="corr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Correspondence </ref> series,
1907-1967, is divided into several subseries. The <ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Chronological </ref> subseries consists largely of military
correspondence, reports, memoranda, and other official documents. Among its earliest
items are the 1911 reports of then Second Lieutenant Arnold on his training as a pilot
by the <corpname>
<part>Wright brothers aviation company.</part>
</corpname> Also present are copies of letters from <persname>
<part>Wilbur and Orville Wright</part>
</persname> to Arnold in which the <famname>
<part>Wrights</part>
</famname> answer Arnold's technical questions about the aircraft the brothers were
building for the <corpname>
<part>army.</part>
</corpname> By 1939 Arnold was a brigadier general in charge of America's growing but
still small <corpname>
<part>army air corps.</part>
</corpname> His files for 1939 and 1940 are filled with reports by American military
observers in Europe about the rapid evolution of German, French, and British aircraft
and air warfare tactics under the pressure of combat. As one report noted, European
fighter aircraft in 1940 were routinely equipped with guns whose firepower was several
times that of existing American fighters. Under Arnold's command, America's military air
arm quickly caught up with and then surpassed in lethality those of other nations.
Present in Arnold's 1945 file is an 8 August 1945 report to him on the dropping of the
atomic bomb that begins “ <geogname>
<part>Hiroshima</part>
</geogname> is no more.”</p>
<p>The <ref target="congrat" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Congratulatory and
Condolence Letters </ref> subseries comprises files generally in chronological order
for major events in Arnold's life.</p>
<p>The <ref target="genl" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> General Correspondence </ref>
subseries is further divided into two parts. The first is an alphabetical file
consisting largely of correspondence and other documents of a military or semiofficial
nature from Arnold's World War II years, although correspondence about personal matters
is also found. The second part of this subseries, a Serial file, 1946-1950, consists of
files numbered 1 through 714. Access to these numbered files is provided by an index
which lists personal names or private institutions with a designation of the numbered
file in which relevant material can be found. The material in these files is a mixture
of correspondence and other documents dealing with Arnold's professional and personal
activities after his retirement.</p>
<p>The <ref target="pers" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Personal Correspondence
</ref> subseries includes material from the early 1930s and the period from 1943 to
1950. The material for 1930-1934 is largely professional correspondence dealing with
aviation and <corpname>
<part>army air corps</part>
</corpname> activities. The files for 1943-1950 consists largely of documents dealing
with Arnold's purchase and maintenance of a residential property in <geogname>
<part>Sonoma, California,</part>
</geogname> to which he retired after his World War II duties.</p>
<p>The <ref target="mil" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Military File </ref> series is
the largest in the collection and is extremely rich with material on all aspects of
American military air activity in World War II: mobilization, organization, supply,
weaponry, training, personnel, strategy, command, intelligence, and technology. Only the
official records of the <corpname>
<part>army air force</part>
</corpname> exceed in abundance the resources offered by the Arnold papers for the study
of American air warfare in World War II. Much of the material in the Military File
series consists of copies of official records which can be found at the <corpname>
<part>National Archives.</part>
</corpname> What gives this collection research interest is that it consists of copies
of those documents that Arnold or his staff regarded as of sufficient significance to
cull from the flood of paper that passed through his office during World War II.</p>
<p>In the <ref target="mil" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Military File, </ref> the
first subseries, entitled the <ref target="decimal" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Decimal File, </ref> 1940-1945, consists of military documents, messages,
correspondence, memoranda, and reports filed in accordance with a decimal filing system
(similar to the Dewey decimal system) used by the <corpname>
<part>army</part>
</corpname> during World War II. Access to the material in these files in best sought by
use of two card-file indexes. The first index is alphabetical by the name of an
individual connected to the documents. The index gives the decimal files in which
documents by or about that person can be found. The second index is alphabetical by
subject, institution, or organization. The indexes are detailed, with the name index
taking up containers 39-46 and the subject index containers 47-60. In addition to the
decimal designation, some of the decimal files also have subject matter titles which
have been included in the container listing of the Arnold Papers.</p>
<p>The <ref target="message" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Message File </ref>
subseries consists of incoming and outgoing official cables and other messages between
Arnold's headquarters and other offices during World War II. Most messages are filed
alphabetically by subject, office, or the name of a frequent correspondent, <persname>
<part>Dwight Eisenhower,</part>
</persname> for example. This subseries also contains a chronological file of Arnold's
incoming and outgoing messages filed under his name.</p>
<p>The <ref target="official" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Official File </ref>
subseries includes military reports, memoranda, correspondence, and other documents
designated by files numbered 1-287 and 516-540. Files 1-210 have subject matter titles
in alphabetical order while files numbered 211-287 have geographic area titles in
alphabetical order along with a few files for non-geographic military commands, ferrying
