command, for example. Files numbered 516-540 contain a variety of reports, logs, and
extensive documentation deriving from the investigation of the <geogname>
<part>Pearl Harbor</part>
</geogname> attack and the role of the <corpname>
<part>army air force</part>
</corpname> in that disaster. Indexes are available for both of these numbered
sequences. Files numbered 288-515 are not extant in the Arnold Papers.</p>
<p>The <ref target="reports" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Reports </ref> subseries,
1913-1949, consists of official military reports related to air warfare topics. Some of
the reports are printed or near-print reports while others are in manuscript form.
General reports largely concern the overall status of American military air power.
Specialized reports relate to a variety of topics, such as atomic energy, analytic
studies of American air warfare campaigns during World War II, and estimates of German
war potential.</p>
<p>The <ref target="subj" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Subject File </ref>
subseries, 1917-1950, deals with a wide variety of official, professional, and private
matters, treating such diverse topics as “Elks in <geogname>
<part>Mexico,</part>
</geogname>” regarding the <corpname>
<part>fraternal order of Elks,</part>
</corpname> military aircraft production, 1938-1945, and the <corpname>
<part>1941 Argentia conference</part>
</corpname> of Allied leaders in <geogname>
<part>Newfoundland.</part>
</geogname> Most of the files deal with important military affairs during World War
II.</p>
<p>The <ref target="milmisc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Miscellany </ref>
subseries, 1934-1951, of the Military File series also contains a variety of files,
including a chronological file of <corpname>
<part>army air force</part>
</corpname> air adjutant general memoranda and messages; a chronological mail log for
Arnold's office listing “to,” “from,” and the subject of correspondence; a chronological
file of Arnold's military correspondence spanning 1934-1945, the bulk of which is
concentrated during World War II and deals with a wide variety of military topics; and
an extensive chronological log of incoming telephone calls, often with notes on the
subject of the call. In addition to the telephone logs, this subseries also includes a
number of transcripts of telephone conversations between Arnold and members of his staff
with other officials. Files of official war communiques publicly released by military
offices relate to the course of the war effort. A Personal File index for files numbered
1-50 is included but only files numbered 34-40 and 42 are present in the collection.</p>
<p>The <ref target="postmil" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Postmilitary File, </ref>
1946-1949, contains Arnold's extensive correspondence after his retirement. The
correspondence is divided into two sets, “A” and “B,” and is filed alphabetically.
Indexes are provided for both sets. This series also contains subject matter files on
the B-36 bomber, atomic testing, and congressional hearings on aviation policy.</p>
<p>The <ref target="speeches" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Speeches and Writings
</ref> series, 1923-1955, includes Arnold's extensive speeches and writings, most of
which relate to aviation and military matters. Arnold had a clear sense that he was
taking part in the creation of a powerful American air arm, and many of his speeches and
essays reflect his sensibility about the history-making character of the events he was
discussing. Also in this series are files related to his 1949 book <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Global Mission,</part>
</title> his memoir of the <corpname>
<part>army</part>
</corpname> air force in World War II.</p>
<p>Among the <ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Miscellany </ref>
series, 1903-1963, are photographs, financial papers, and biographical material, printed
material, and other items that further reflect Arnold's historical sensitivity,
especially the material he collected about the early years of American military
aviation. Included are photographs, lists and biographies of early pilots,
contemporaneous print and near-print accounts of important events in military aviation
history, and extensive scrapbooks.</p>
<p>The <ref target="jocham" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Jo Chamberlin File </ref>,
1941-1989, consists of scrapbooks containing memoranda, reports, speeches, military
papers, printed matter, and other miscellaneous material reflecting Chamberlin's
assignment to the Office of Information Services, Army Air Forces, and as an aide to
Arnold. Included are drafts of reports to the secretary of war by the commanding
general, Army Air Forces, with annotations by Arnold, speeches drafted by Chamberlin for
Arnold, reports from the Aleutian Island Campaign, information regarding 'foo-fighters,'
and writings on Chamberlin's trip to Germany in the waning days of World War II.</p>
<p>The <ref target="class" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Classified </ref> series
consists of security classified items removed from the collection. Removal sheets for
all such material can be found in the files from which the items were removed. When any
item in this series is declassified, it is restored to its original file. Classified
items are not included on the microfilm edition of the Arnold Papers prepared in
1995.</p>
</scopecontent>

clippings.</p>

Arnold's trips and conferences. </p>
</scopecontent>

public, including incoming and outgoing letters and related material such as
reports, flight records, commendations, and printed matter pertaining to
Arnold's professional and personal interests.</p>

promotions, and Arnold's death. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

professional activities and letters sent and received by his wife, Eleanor Pool
Arnold.</p>

matter documenting Arnold's military career.</p>
</scopecontent>

<p>Chiefly incoming and outgoing cables and related material, such as reports,
logs, and lists pertaining to military matters. </p>
</scopecontent>

clippings, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>

including administrative, technical, and intelligence.</p>
</scopecontent>

</scopecontent>

communiques, and lists.</p>
</scopecontent>

other papers documenting Arnold's interests and activities after his
retirement.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">

Arnold's memoirs, <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Global Mission,</part>
</title> and related material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, financial papers, biographical information,
photographs, personnel records, scrapbooks, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Card file describing mail received by Arnold.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Scrapbooks compiled by Jo Chamberlin, containing memoranda, reports, speeches,
military papers, printed matter, and other material.</p>
</scopecontent>

</scopecontent>

</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>Joshua Lockwood Logan (1908-1988)</part>
</persname> span the years
1723-1992, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the period 1940-1980. The
collection documents Logan's career as a director, producer, and author of
stage and film productions. Included are family papers, correspondence,
business papers, financial papers, production records, writings, and
scrapbooks.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="family" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Family Papers
</ref>
series contains correspondence between Logan and his family, primarily his
mother,
<persname>
<part>Sue Nabors Noble,</part>
</persname> his wife,
<persname>
<part>Nedda Harrigan Logan,</part>
</persname> and his stepsister,
<persname>
<part>Lois Noble Smith.</part>
</persname> Logan's early years are
reflected in his school and military papers. A group of files labeled
“mental health” document his struggle with manic depression and his
involvement with
<persname>
<part>Merrill Moore,</part>
</persname> a noted psychiatrist. A small
genealogical section contains photocopied records of the
<famname>
<part>Lee,</part>
</famname>

<famname>
<part>Lockwood,</part>
</famname> and
<famname>
<part>Logan</part>
</famname> families as well as a few original eighteenth
and nineteenth century letters and documents.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="gencorr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
General
Correspondence
</ref> series in the collection contains letters from Logan's
friends, colleagues, and the general public. Notable are
<persname>
<part>Zinn Arthur,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Irving Berlin,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Bennett Cerf,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Oscar Hammerstein,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Leland Hayward,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>William Inge,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Mary Martin,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>James A. Michener,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Jo Mielziner,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Richard Rodgers,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Rosalind Russell,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>James Stewart,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Emlyn Williams.</part>
</persname> Additional correspondence from
individuals can be located in the
<ref target="production" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Production
File
</ref> under the shows with which they were associated. For example,
letters from
<persname>
<part>Mary Martin</part>
</persname> appear with material on
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>South Pacific</part>
</title> and the production of
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Miss Moffat</part>
</title> in 1974.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="business" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Business
Papers
</ref> reflect Logan's multifaceted involvement in the theater world as
well as his personal business matters. Correspondence with agents includes
management of Logan's career in addition to employment inquiries from authors
and actors. The financial papers include Logan's investments in theater
productions and the stock market. Correspondence with Logan's entertainment
lawyers in the legal section contains much information on the preparation of
his shows, as do the interoffice memoranda and office diaries. The projects
section contains idea files and material related to the many properties on
which Logan held or negotiated an option but never actually mounted. Shows
staged with his active participation are represented with various materials in
the
<ref target="production" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Production
File.
</ref>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="production" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Production
File
</ref> consists of papers relating to the preparation and management of
shows in which Logan was personally connected as director, producer, author, or
actor. Also included are productions for which Logan was hired but from which
he resigned before the show opened. In cases where Logan was involved in both
the stage and screen version of a work, separate files have been maintained.
Subjects relate to casting, financial management, legal matters, derivative
productions such as touring companies and amateur performances, publicity,
research, reviews, and tickets, including benefit shows. The working papers
sections contain correspondence and notes on rehearsals, performance quality,
plot development, script revisions, costumes, set design, location
arrangements, equipment, and editing. The amount of material on each show
varies greatly. Some productions, such as
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>South Pacific,</part>
</title> are well documented, while
others, such as
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>By Jupiter,</part>
</title> have very little information.
Related material can be found in the
<ref target="business" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Business
Papers
</ref> under legal papers, interoffice memoranda, and office diaries. The

<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany
</ref> series
contains scrapbooks for most of the major shows with which Logan was
associated.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="writings" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Writings
File,
</ref> arranged alphabetically by author, includes scripts submitted to
Logan for his consideration or advice. The scripts listed under Logan's name
are those in which he was actively engaged in writing or revising. Logan's
writings also include articles, books, poetry, short stories, song lyrics, and
speeches. Related material, such as contracts, correspondence, outlines, notes,
publicity, reviews, and royalty statements, accompany Logan's drafts.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany
</ref>
series primarily contains newspaper and magazine clippings about Logan and his
family. Pamphlets relating to
<persname>
<part>Konstantin Stanislavsky</part>
</persname> are filed with autographs
and printed material. Other material includes awards, certificates, memoranda,
scrapbooks for many of Logan's best-known productions, and a scrapbook
containing original artwork from Logan's military school days.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Biographical data, genealogies, correspondence among family
members, diaries, medical and mental health papers, and military records. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters to and from friends and business associates of Joshua and
Nedda Logan. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, financial data, interoffice memoranda, legal
papers, office diaries, and notes. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Blueprints, correspondence, financial data, legal papers,
memoranda, newspaper clippings, notes, and printed material relating to
productions with which Logan was associated. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Contracts, correspondence, drafts, newspaper clippings, notes,
outlines, royalty statements, and typescripts pertaining to the writings of
Joshua Logan and others. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Autographs, awards, certificates, newspaper clippings, notes, and
printed material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Oversize items consisting mostly of awards, certificates,
blueprints, scrapbooks, production budget sheets, and printed material. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>Elmer Gertz (1906-2000)</part>
</persname> span the years 1789-1997,
with the majority of the papers concentrated from 1926 to 1988. The bulk of the
papers documents Gertz's career as a lawyer, author, and manuscript collector.
The collection consists of eight series:
<ref target="fampap" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Family
Papers,
</ref>

<ref target="gencorr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
General
Correspondence,
</ref>

<ref target="legal" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Legal
File,
</ref>

<ref target="subj" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Subject
File,
</ref>

<ref target="sandw" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Speeches and
Writings File,
</ref>

<ref target="misc" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany,
</ref>

<ref target="add" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Addition,
</ref>
and
<ref target="oversize" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Oversize.
</ref>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="fampap" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Family
Papers
</ref> series, 1926-1991, consists primarily of letters between Gertz and
family members concerning personal matters. Gertz's letters to his children,
<persname>
<part>Theodore G. Gertz</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Margery A. Hechtman,</part>
</persname> often summarize his
professional and personal activities, providing a glimpse of the attorney's
busy schedule.</p>
<p>The papers in the
<ref target="gencorr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
General
Correspondence
</ref> series, 1925-1991, also chronicle Gertz's varied
interests. Incoming and outgoing correspondence relates to personal and
professional matters, including various commissions and organizations with
which Gertz was associated. A few of the notable correspondents in this series
are
<persname>
<part>Louis Adamic,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Richard J. Daley,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Paul Howard Douglas,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Albert Einstein,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Eli E. Fink,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Arthur J. Goldberg,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Carey McWilliams,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Leo Calvin Rosten,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Carl Sandburg,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>George Sylvester Viereck.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="legal" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Legal
File,
</ref> 1905-1992, constituting over half of the collection, documents
Gertz's lengthy and prominent legal career. Papers in the series are divided
into two subseries:
<ref target="personal" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Personal
</ref> and
<ref target="prof" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Professional.
</ref> The
<ref target="personal" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Personal
</ref> subseries, 1950-1988, pertains to cases in which
Gertz was a litigant. The private lawsuit which brought Gertz national
attention was <emph render="italic">Gertz v. Robert Welch, Inc.,</emph> a
precedent-setting case which changed libel laws throughout the nation. The
<geogname>
<part>Chicago</part>
</geogname> attorney sued the publishers of a
<corpname>
<part>John Birch Society</part>
</corpname> publication for reporting that
Gertz was involved in a Communist plot to discredit the
<corpname>
<part>Chicago Police Department.</part>
</corpname> The
<corpname>
<part>United States Supreme Court</part>
</corpname> ruled that Gertz, as a
private individual, did not have to prove “actual malice” to
receive compensatory damages.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="prof" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Professional
</ref> subseries, 1905-1992, consists of correspondence
and memoranda, chiefly between Gertz and clients, lawyers, and judges, as well
as extensive legal files including opinions, orders, briefs, writs, motions,
petitions, exhibits, and transcripts. Both case files and client files reflect
the wide range of cases handled by Gertz, particularly those involving libel,
obscenity, capital punishment, and copyright issues. One of Gertz's clients was
novelist
<persname>
<part>Henry Miller,</part>
</persname> who challenged charges that his work
was obscene. Gertz fought successfully in Illinois against censorship of the
writer's book
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Tropic of Cancer.</part>
</title>
</p>
<p>Another of Gertz’s clients, Nathan Freudenthal Leopold, was
convicted with Richard Loeb of murdering fourteen-year-old Bobby Franks in a
sensational trial that captivated the nation in 1924. Gertz later helped
Leopold obtain a parole after thirty-four years in prison. Correspondence
relating to Leopold's release is located in the early correspondence files of
<emph render="italic">Leopold v. Levin</emph>, Leopold's suit seeking
compensation from Meyer Levin, whose book and film,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Compulsion,</part>
</title> were based on the murder and subsequent trial.
Background files for the Levin case also contain court documents and other
material relating to Leopold's murder trial, <emph render="italic">Illinois v.
Leopold.</emph>
</p>
<p>Gertz was also one of a team of lawyers representing Jack Ruby, who
was convicted of killing Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President John F.
Kennedy, in November 1963. Gertz joined the defense team in December 1964 and
assisted with Ruby's appeal which succeeded in getting his death sentence set
aside. Several items in the <emph render="italic">Ruby v. Texas</emph> case
file are worthy of mention: Ruby's letter to his brother Earl, located in the
folder "Miscellaneous, 1964-70, undated"; Ruby's note to Gertz of 9 September
1965, located in the folder "Correspondence, Aug.-Sept. 1965"; and a reporter's
note to Gertz describing his visit with Ruby shortly before Ruby's death,
located in the folder "Correspondence, Mar.-Aug. 1967, undated" Additional
material pertaining to Ruby may be found in the Speeches and Writings File
relating to Gertz’s book
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Moment of Madness: The People vs. Jack Ruby.</part>
</title>
</p>
<p>Papers in the
<ref target="subj" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Subject
File
</ref> series, 1894, 1903-1990, illustrate Gertz's diverse interests and
activities. This series chronicles his service with committees and
organizations and documents his duties as a delegate and committee chair of the

<geogname>
<part>Illinois</part>
</geogname> constitutional convention, 1969-1970; his
work with the
<corpname>
<part>Chicago Bar Association,</part>
</corpname> 1977-1985 and the
<corpname>
<part>Illinois Coalition Against the Death Penalty,</part>
</corpname>
1977-1985; and his membership on the
<corpname>
<part>Chicago Citizens Commission to Study the Disorders of
Convention Week</part>
</corpname> (1968 Democratic national convention). Also
reflected in the series is Gertz's interest in various historical and literary
figures:
<persname>
<part>James Baldwin,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Clarence Darrow,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Frank Harris,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>John F. Kennedy,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Henry Miller,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Carl Sandburg,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Harry S. Truman,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Bernard Shaw.</part>
</persname> Other topics prominently featured
include censorship, housing, obscenity, and the death penalty. There is some
overlap between this series and the
<ref target="gencorr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
General
Correspondence
</ref> series, and many of the same individuals appear in both
series. Also included are legal papers relating to Gertz's consultations in his
later years.</p>
<p> The
<ref target="sandw" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Speeches and
Writings File,
</ref> 1888-1990, document Gertz’s activities as a prolific
writer and speaker interested not only in legal matters but in literary
subjects as well. Some of his most voluminous papers relate to two of his
books,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Frank Harris: A Study in Black and White</part>
</title> and
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Odyssey of a Barbarian: The Biography of George Sylvester
Viereck.</part>
</title> Gertz corresponded with both Harris and Viereck and
accumulated a large amount of research material pertaining to each, including
some of their original manuscripts, numerous autograph letters, and notes from
prominent literary figures. The Viereck research material includes one reel of
microfilm of original material not in the collection, letters and messages of
Sigmund Freud to Viereck. Other books by Gertz include
<title localtype="simple">
<part>A Handful of Clients,</part>
</title> a description of some of the
attorney's more interesting clients, and
<title localtype="simple">
<part>To Life,</part>
</title> an account of his personal and professional life.
</p>
<p>The
<ref target="misc" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany
</ref> series, 1789, 1860-1991, consists chiefly of
manuscripts and printed matter collected by Gertz, which complement material in
the
<ref target="sandw" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
Speeches and
Writings File
</ref> and pertain to his general research interests. Also
included in the series are papers relating to his academic career and his
awards and honors.</p>
<p> The
<ref target="add" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Addition
</ref> series
supplements previous installments of the Gertz Papers and span the years
1921-1997, with the bulk concentrated from 1989-1996. The Addition includes
correspondence, memoranda, family papers, legal files, subject files, and
writings. The subject file, comprising almost half of the addition, reflects
Gertz’s affiliation with organizations such as the Blind Service
Association, the Caxton Club, and the Decalogue Society of Lawyers. Also
documented in the subject file is Gertz’s interest in writers Frank
Harris and George Sylvester Viereck and the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
The writings file in the Addition relates primarily to <emph render="italic">Gertz v. Robert Welch, Inc.</emph> and the revised 1990 edition
of Gertz’s memoir
<title localtype="simple">
<part>To Life.</part>
</title> This file also includes a number of articles and
book reviews that Gertz wrote for
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Real Crime Book Digest.</part>
</title>
</p>
<p>Among the most prominent and frequent correspondents are
<persname>
<part>George Anastaplo,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Allen Crandall,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Paul Crump,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Richard M. Daley,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Lord Alfred Bruce Douglas,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Otto Eisenschiml,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Wayne B. Giampietro,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Frank Harris,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Samuel G. Herman,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>John F. Kennedy,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Nathan Leopold,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Gene Lovitz,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Russ Meyer,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Henry Miller,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Hesketh Pearson,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Muriel Peters,</part>
</persname>

<persname>
<part>Peter Pollack,</part>
</persname>

<persname>

</persname>

</persname>

<persname>
<part>Edward P. Schwartz,</part>
</persname>

<persname>

</persname>

<persname>
<part>Kate Stephens,</part>
</persname>

<persname>

</persname>

<persname>
<part>George Sylvester Viereck,</part>
</persname>

<persname>

</persname> and
<persname>

</persname>
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence between Gertz and family members with attachments
and enclosures. Other papers include estate papers, invitations, notes,
genealogical material, writings, newspaper clippings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence and memoranda, including attachments, between Gertz
and friends, acquaintances, clients, and the public relating to his personal
and professional activities. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, briefs, orders, opinions, motions,
reports, financial papers, statements, background information, and printed
matter pertaining to legal cases in which Gertz was a litigant. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, orders, opinions, briefs, writs,
motions, petitions, financial papers, exhibits, depositions, transcripts,
reports, notes, interviews, architectural plans and specifications, contracts,
statements, writings, printed matter, and background information relating to
Gertz's professional activities and interests. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes of meetings,
invitations, speeches, statements, writings, resolutions, background
information, financial and legal papers, notes, newspaper clippings, and
printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, speeches, research material,
announcements and programs, newspaper clippings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, handwritten drafts and typescripts of
books, articles, reviews, research material, interviews, pamphlets, prefaces to
books, poetry, notes, outlines, newspaper clippings, and printed matter.
Includes one reel of microfilm* of Sigmund Freud-George Sylvester Viereck
correspondence, the originals of which are not in the collection.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, calendars, original manuscripts and
printed matter collected by Gertz, financial papers, academic papers,
biographical material, newspaper clippings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, family papers, legal files, subject
files, speech material, articles, book reviews, background information,
photographs, newspaper clippings, and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Oversize material consisting of broadsides, a scrapbook, and copies of design plans.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>Archibald MacLeish</part>
</persname> cover the period from 1907 to 1981, with the bulk of the material dated
between 1925 and 1970. Although MacLeish gave most of his literary manuscripts to <corpname>
<part>Yale University,</part>
</corpname> the <corpname>
<part>Library of Congress's</part>
</corpname> collection is particularly rich in its assemblage of correspondence
reflecting MacLeish's relationships with personal friends, literary colleagues, and
government associates and in its holdings of MacLeish's notebooks containing the origins
of some of his greatest poems. The papers also include notes, worksheets, and manuscript
drafts which detail the development of several of MacLeish's plays as well as document
the political and moral convictions which motivated the many speeches and radio
broadcasts he made both before and during World War II. Notes and manuscripts also exist
for a series of classroom lectures on the form and condition of modern poetry conducted
by MacLeish while serving as Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at <corpname>
<part>Harvard University</part>
</corpname> from 1949 to 1962.</p>
<p>Few items remain for the period prior to 1923 when MacLeish left the <geogname>
<part>Boston</part>
</geogname> law firm where he was employed to live in <geogname>
<part>Europe,</part>
</geogname> devoting his time to reading, travel, and writing poetry. The earliest
material in the <ref target="corr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref>
series is that between MacLeish and his father, <persname>
<part>Andrew,</part>
</persname> while MacLeish was a student at <corpname>
<part>Hotchkiss School</part>
</corpname> and <corpname>
<part>Yale University.</part>
</corpname> There are also several letters from MacLeish's brother, <persname>
<part>Kenneth,</part>
</persname> whose death in action during World War I greatly affected the poet. Of
additional interest are letters from personal friends, such as <persname>
<part>Robert Newton Linscott,</part>
</persname> editor at <corpname>
<part>Houghton Mifflin Company,</part>
</corpname> and <persname>
<part>Charles Rumford Walker,</part>
</persname> which reflect some of the personal and artistic struggles MacLeish
encountered during his years abroad.</p>
<p>MacLeish was one of a number of American literary expatriates living in <geogname>
<part>Europe</part>
</geogname> between the wars, enjoying the advantages of a favorable monetary exchange
rate and the camaraderie of sympathetic fellow artists and writers. Many of the
friendships which MacLeish made during the 1920's continued through later years, and the
<ref target="corr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref> series
contains substantive letters from <persname>
<part>Kay Boyle,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Ernest Hemingway,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Gerald and Sara Murphy,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Ezra Pound.</part>
</persname> Incoming letters are also included in the <ref target="subj" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Subject File</ref> from those who, along with MacLeish, advocated
the release of <persname>
<part>Pound</part>
</persname> from <corpname>
<part>St. Elizabeth's Hospital,</part>
</corpname> the mental institution in <geogname>
<part>Washington, D.C.,</part>
</geogname> where the poet had been confined after he was declared incompetent to stand
trial for treason at the end of World War II. Other writers, artists, and scholars with
whom MacLeish corresponded include <persname>
<part>Julian P. Boyd,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Ciardi,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James Bryant Conant,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Mary and Padraic Colum,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Malcolm Cowley,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Dos Passos,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Roy Harris,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Thomas Mann,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Lewis Mumford,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harold George Nicolson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Saint-John Perse,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Carl Sandburg,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Robert E. Sherwood,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Stephen Spender,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Steinbeck,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Allen Tate,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Louis Untermeyer,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Mark Van Doren,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Alexander Woollcott.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>During the 1930's MacLeish became increasingly politicized and was outspoken in support
of an American commitment to protect the liberal democratic principles which he felt
were being threatened by the rise of fascism in <geogname>
<part>Europe.</part>
</geogname> Several of his verse plays for radio, such as <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Air Raid</part>
</title> (1938), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The American Story</part>
</title> (1944), and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Fall of the City</part>
</title> (1937), illustrate these national or democratic themes. Material for these
dramatic voice productions is contained in the <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File</ref> series.</p>
<p>MacLeish more fully explicated his political philosophy in a series of prose pieces
written for various journals and magazines throughout the 1930s and 1940s as well as in
the many radio broadcasts and speeches he made during the same period. Notes and
manuscript drafts for the writings are contained in the <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File,</ref> while similar documents for the broadcasts
and speeches are located in the <ref target="speech" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Speeches and Lectures File.</ref> The latter series also contains copies and drafts
for speeches which MacLeish prepared for <persname>
<part>Franklin D. Roosevelt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Edward R. Stettinius,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harry S. Truman,</part>
</persname> and other government officials.</p>
<p>From 1929 to 1938 MacLeish worked as a writer and editor for <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Fortune</part>
</title> magazine, accepting the position from <persname>
<part>Henry Robinson Luce</part>
</persname> on the understanding that his commitment to the new publishing venture would
be limited to the extent that, having earned enough money to satisfy his needs, MacLeish
could return whenever he wished to his newly-purchased farm in <geogname>
<part>Conway, Massachusetts,</part>
</geogname> to work on his own writing. The <ref target="corr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref> series contains a separate file for <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Fortune</part>
</title> magazine and MacLeish's correspondence with <persname>
<part>Henry Robinson Luce.</part>
</persname> Other colleagues and friends from the field of publishing with whom MacLeish
corresponded include <persname>
<part>Bruce Bliven,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Cass Canfield,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Russell Wheeler Davenport,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Charles H. Duell,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Clifton Fadiman,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Farrar,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Ralph Ingersoll,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Freda Kirchwey,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Robert A. Lovett,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Eugene Meyer,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Charles A. Pearce,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Selden Rodman,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Edward Weeks.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>In 1939, <persname>
<part>President Franklin D. Roosevelt</part>
</persname> persuaded a reluctant MacLeish to accept what proved to be a controversial
appointment as the ninth Librarian of Congress. MacLeish implemented a thorough
reorganization of the <corpname>
<part>Library's</part>
</corpname> administrative offices, published the <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Quarterly Journal of the Library of Congress,</part>
</title> and established the Library's series of poetry readings. Because of his
managerial skills and political involvement, MacLeish was also asked to serve,
concurrent with his Library position, as director of the <corpname>
<part>Office of Facts and Figures</part>
</corpname> and assistant director of the <corpname>
<part>Office of War Information</part>
</corpname> from 1941 to 1944. In 1944, after his resignation from the <corpname>
<part>Library,</part>
</corpname> MacLeish was appointed assistant secretary of state for cultural affairs, in
which capacity he helped plan the establishment of the <corpname>
<part>United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.</part>
</corpname> Although the <ref target="subj" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Subject
File</ref> contains headings for these government agencies, none of the files
contains extensive amounts of material. Official documents produced by MacLeish in his
capacity as public servant are more likely to be represented in the central files or
archival records of the respective federal agency.</p>
<p>The <ref target="corr" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Correspondence</ref> series
contains correspondence and copies of memoranda with many of MacLeish's associates, as
well as with public figures, both in and out of government, whom MacLeish came to know
during the war years. Correspondents of interest include <persname>
<part>Dean Acheson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Francis Biddle,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>McGeorge Bundy,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James Francis Byrnes,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Benjamin V. Cohen,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>William J. Donovan,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>J. C. Dunn,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Stephen T. Early,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Luther Harris Evans,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>A. H. Feller,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Felix Frankfurter,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Joseph C. Grew,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Haldore E. Hanson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harry Lloyd Hopkins,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Cordell Hull,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harold L. Ickes,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>R. Keith Kane,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Robert E. Kintner,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Muna Lee,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John Jay McCloy,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>David C. Mearns,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Henry Morgenthau,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Eleanor Roosevelt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Franklin D. Roosevelt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Samuel Irving Rosenman,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Edward R. Stettinius,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Adlai E. Stevenson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Henry Lewis Stimson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Arthur Sweetser,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Charles A. Thomson,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harry S. Truman,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Henry Agard Wallace,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James P. Warburg,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Sumner Welles.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File</ref> contains an
extensive set of notes for a series of classroom lectures which MacLeish delivered at <corpname>
<part>Harvard University</part>
</corpname> from 1949 to 1962. The purpose of these lectures was to provide a
theoretical and historical framework within which a student could analyze the structure
of modern poetry. MacLeish emphasized the influence of certain poets as pivotal to the
development of modern poetry, and the notes he kept are quite thorough, providing
insight into his teaching techniques.</p>
<p>With time afforded him after his retirement from public service, MacLeish published
several books of poetry, produced dramatic pieces for various media, and wrote prose
works, including social and political commentary. The <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File</ref> contains correspondence and manuscript
material for collections of poems such as <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Actfive</part>
</title> (1948) and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>New and Collected Poems, 1917-1976</part>
</title> (1976). Although files related to the individual poems listed in this series
include some worthwhile records, many contain material of little value, in some cases
nothing more than copies of poems typewritten by MacLeish.</p>
<p>MacLeish continued to produce verse plays for stage, radio, and television, and the <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File</ref> contains important
material relating to these dramatic productions. Manuscript drafts and worksheets are
contained in the collection for MacLeish's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>J.B.</part>
</title> (1958). Similar material, including correspondence, is also included for other
dramas such as <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>An Evening's Journey to Conway, Massachusetts</part>
</title> (1967), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Great American Fourth of July Parade</part>
</title> (1975), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Herakles</part>
</title> (1967), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Scratch</part>
</title> (1971), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>This Music Crept By Me Upon the Waters</part>
</title> (1953), and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Trojan Horse</part>
</title> (1952). The disorganized state of many of the manuscripts and worksheets
contained throughout the collection is the result of MacLeish's work habits. Describing
the state of disarray of a draft for one of his plays, MacLeish wrote that it “can't be
put together because I work like the crab retreating ten steps to go forward two and
thus getting nowhere.” <ref target="no.1" show="new" actuate="onrequest">(1)</ref>
</p>
<p>The greatest literary treasure of the collection is a set of notebooks kept by MacLeish
from 1919 through the 1940s located in the <ref target="lit" show="new" actuate="onrequest">Literary File.</ref> Containing drafts of much of his poetry and
prose, the notebooks help trace the creation and development of some of MacLeish's
finest work. They also include notes about his travels and readings and his reflections
about other writers and their conversations on literature.</p>
<p>A notebook kept by MacLeish in <geogname>
<part>Paris</part>
</geogname> for the years 1924-25 contains drafts and trial lines for poems later
published in <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Streets in the Moon</part>
</title> (1926), including <title localtype="simple" render="doublequote">
<part>Ars Poetica,</part>
</title> and a partial version of the verse play, <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Pot of Earth</part>
</title> (1925). Additional works by MacLeish represented in other notebooks include
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Happy Marriage</part>
</title> (1924), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Hamlet of A. MacLeish</part>
</title> (1928), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>New Found Land</part>
</title> (1930), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Conquistador</part>
</title> (1932), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Frescoes for Mr. Rockefeller's City</part>
</title> (1933), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Panic</part>
</title> (1935), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Public Speech</part>
</title> (1936), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>The Fall of the City</part>
</title> (1937), <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>America Was Promises</part>
</title> (1939), and <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Actfive</part>
</title> (1948).</p>
<p id="no.1">(1) <ref target="jbdrafts" show="new" actuate="onrequest">
<emph render="italic">J.B.</emph> drafts and worksheets, Box 27</ref>
</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, memoranda, telegrams, postcards, and
miscellaneous enclosures. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Handwritten and typewritten drafts, correspondence, trial lines, printed copies,
notes and worksheets, outlines, notebooks, proofs, and miscellaneous items
relating to plays, poetry, prose pieces, screenplays and scripts, and books. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Handwritten and typewritten drafts, correspondence, trial lines, printed copies,
notes and worksheets, outlines, proofs, and miscellaneous items relating to
classroom lectures, interviews, and radio and television broadcasts.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes of meetings, printed matter, and
miscellaneous items.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Printed matter, manuscript drafts, correspondence, miscellaneous personal records,
and notes.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Diary, notebooks, correspondence, a playscript, interview transcript, and printed
matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of
<persname>
<part>Julius Robert Oppenheimer (1904-1967)</part>
</persname> span the
years 1921 to 1980 with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period
1947-1967, the years during which Oppenheimer was director of the
<corpname>
<part>Institute for Advanced Study</part>
</corpname> in
<geogname>
<part>Princeton, New Jersey.</part>
</geogname> The collection comprises
Oppenheimer's personal papers and relates only incidentally to his directorship
of the institute. The papers consist chiefly of correspondence,
<ref target="desk" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
desk books,
</ref>
printed copies of Oppenheimer's lectures, statements, and scientific notes,
supplemented by memoranda, inventories, photographs, and newspaper
clippings.</p>
<p>There was no major rearrangement of these papers; Oppenheimer's own
filing arrangement and cross-reference system were used wherever possible. He
once described the papers as a “hideously complete archive,” and they
document the many facets of his career. The collection includes material on
theoretical physics, the development of the atomic bomb, the relationship
between government and science, the organization of research on atomic energy,
control of atomic energy and its role in international affairs, security in
scientific fields, secrecy, loyalty, disarmament, the education of scientists
and international intellectual exchange, the moral responsibility of the
scientist, the relationship between science and culture, and the public
understanding of science.</p>
<p>Material in the collection prior to 1941 comprises two small groups of
scientific papers consisting chiefly of reprints of Oppenheimer's
<ref target="earlsci" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
early
scientific writings
</ref> with galley proofs, holograph manuscripts by
associates, and miscellaneous notes. Correspondence containing scientific
calculations was written by such prominent physicists as
<persname>
<part>Hans A. Bethe,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Shuichi Kusaka,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Wolfgang Pauli,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Julian Schwinger,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Edward Teller.</part>
</persname> Oppenheimer's writings for the
early years, during which he established his reputation as a theoretical
physicist, is filed in the first section of the
<ref target="speech" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Speech,
Lecture, and Writing File.
</ref> An annotated list of these early writings is
also included.</p>
<p>Documentation of Oppenheimer's wartime contributions, including his
organization and direction of the
<corpname>
<part>Los Alamos project,</part>
</corpname> is centered in the
<ref target="gencase" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
General Case
File
</ref> and the
<ref target="govt" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Government
File
</ref> and includes material from such figures as
<persname>
<part>Hans A. Bethe,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Raymond T. Birge,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Vannevar Bush,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Arthur H. Compton,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>James B. Conant,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Leslie R. Groves,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Ernest O. Lawrence,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John H. Manley,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Franklin D. Roosevelt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Robert Serber,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>John Wheeler.</part>
</persname> In the
<ref target="govtsup" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Government
File Supplement
</ref> is formerly classified material transferred to the
Library from the
<corpname>
<part>Atomic Energy Commission</part>
</corpname> chiefly concerning the
technical and administrative problems of atomic development from 1941 to 1953.
Scattered throughout the collection are letters of reminiscence and
Oppenheimer's comments on histories of the
<corpname>
<part> Los Alamos project</part>
</corpname> which reflect the spirit and
friendships developed during that period. </p>
<p>At the end of World War II, during Oppenheimer's activities as one of
the chief governmental advisers on atomic questions, he served on almost every
committee, both civilian and military, that dealt with the problems of atomic
energy. There is a considerable amount of correspondence documenting these
activities, but little material pertaining to his chairmanship of the
<corpname>
<part>Atomic Energy Commission's General Advisory
Committee</part>
</corpname> and the
<corpname>
<part>Committee on Atomic Energy of the Research and Development
Board.</part>
</corpname> The gap in this documentation is covered in part by lists and
correspondence in the
<ref target="security" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Security Case
File.
</ref> The
<ref target="memfile" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Membership
File
</ref> contains references to activities of such scientific organizations
as the
<corpname>
<part>Federation of American Scientists,</part>
</corpname> the
<corpname>
<part>National Academy of Sciences,</part>
</corpname> and various
associations of atomic scientists. These files also contain information on
other professional organizations, including the
<title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists,</part>
</title> and the
reevaluation by universities of the growing role of science and government
within their own operations.</p>
<p>The control of atomic energy and its role in international affairs is
a major theme in these papers. Closely associated with these subjects is
<persname>
<part>Niels Bohr,</part>
</persname> a Danish physicist, whose letters and
memoranda to
<persname>
<part>Felix Frankfurter</part>
</persname> filed under
<persname>
<part>Frankfurter's</part>
</persname> name in the
<ref target="gencase" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
General Case
File
</ref> relate to the idea of an open world patterned after the community of
scientists. This correspondence, given to Oppenheimer by
<persname>
<part>Frankfurter,</part>
</persname> is supplemented by the many letters
exchanged between Oppenheimer and
<persname>
<part>Bohr,</part>
</persname> numerous notes, manuscript drafts, and
biographical data amassed by Oppenheimer for his lectures on “
<persname>
<part>Neils Bohr</part>
</persname> and His Time.”</p>
<p>Oppenheimer's hearing before the
<corpname>
<part>Personnel Security Board</part>
</corpname> of the
<corpname>
<part>Atomic Energy Commission</part>
</corpname> drew worldwide attention
and is documented in extraordinary detail. The
<ref target="security" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Security Case
File
</ref> includes numerous drafts of biographical and autobiographical
statements prepared by Oppenheimer and his wife,
<persname>
<part>Katherine,</part>
</persname> for his defense. There are a few notes
taken during the hearings as well as correspondence with his lawyers,
<persname>
<part>Herbert Marks</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Lloyd K. Garrison.</part>
</persname> Much of the correspondence,
including letters from many prominent people, and various published articles
reflect public attitudes. The documentation also includes voluminous newspaper
clippings and printed transcripts of the proceedings.</p>
<p>Although there is no official material for Oppenheimer's directorship
of the
<corpname>
<part>Institute for Advanced Study,</part>
</corpname> the
<ref target="persfile" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Personal
File
</ref> contains related items on his appointment and resignation and the
various literary, historical, and legal studies conducted during his tenure.
Letters in the
<ref target="gencase" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
General Case
File
</ref> between Oppenheimer and
<persname>
<part>Julian Boyd,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Harold Cherniss,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Herbert Feis,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>George Kennan</part>
</persname> delineate relationships within the
academic community, and Oppenheimer's correspondence with his secretaries from
1948 to 1966 provides further insight on both the man and the institute.</p>
<p>Following the revocation of his security clearance in 1954,
Oppenheimer traveled widely and lectured on physics and the interrelationship
of science and culture. The
<ref target="speech" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Speech,
Lecture, and Writing File
</ref> reflects this activity with notes, drafts, and
printed copies of his talks and an index of titles and places of delivery. The
papers also document Oppenheimer's participation in the
<corpname>
<part>Seven Springs Farm Conference</part>
</corpname> held at
<geogname>
<part>Mt. Kisco, New York,</part>
</geogname> in 1963. </p>
<p>Oppenheimer planned to write a history of theoretical physics in the
twentieth century, whose leading practitioners were virtually all among his
principal correspondents. Prominent scientists not previously mentioned include

<persname>
<part>Felix Bloch,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Max Born,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Robert F. Christy,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>John D. Cockcroft,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Paul A. M. Dirac,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Enrico Fermi,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>T. D. (Tsung Dao) Lee,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Abraham Pais,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>R. E. Peierls,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Linus Pauling,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Emilio Segrè,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Leo Szilard,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Yang Chen Ning,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Hideki Yukawa.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The arts and humanities are also well represented in the collection.
The
<ref target="gencase" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
General Case
File
</ref> contains folders of material from such persons as
<persname>
<part>Pablo Casals,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>T. S. Eliot,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Wallace K. Harrison,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Julian Huxley,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Archibald MacLeish,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Nicolas Nabokov,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Eleanor Roosevelt,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Bertrand Russell,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Albert Schweitzer,</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Norman Thomas.</part>
</persname> The
<ref target="memfile" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Membership
File,
</ref> particularly for the
<corpname>
<part>Twentieth Century Fund</part>
</corpname> and
<corpname>
<part>UNESCO,</part>
</corpname> reflects some of the international issues
in the humanities with which Oppenheimer was involved.</p>
<p>
<ref target="add" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Addition I
</ref> primarily contains a small group of originals and copies of
correspondence from Oppenheimer to family, friends, and professional colleagues. There
are also miscellaneous files composed of printed and near-print matter, photographs,
writings by others, and one reel of negative microfilm containing “A History of the
<corpname>
<part>Institute for Advanced Study,</part>
</corpname> 1930-1950,” written by
<persname>
<part>Beatrice M. Stern</part>
</persname> in 1964.</p>
<p>
<ref show="replace" actuate="onrequest" target="addii">
Addition II
</ref> contains inventories of classified documents from the Department
of the Navy, U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, Department of State, and the Research and
Development Board. It also contains miscellaneous correspondence received from the
general public.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Appointment books with a few annotations and miscellaneous notes.
</p>
</scopecontent>

unpublished manuscripts received, secretary's notes, clippings, photographs,
reports, and printed matter. </p>

secretary's notes, clippings, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>

secretary's notes, clippings, minutes, and printed material. </p>
</scopecontent>

<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, unpublished
manuscripts received, and clippings, chiefly from autograph seekers or
admirers. </p>
</scopecontent>

notices, travel vouchers, receipts for classified documents, and inventories
relating to projects or agencies. </p>
</scopecontent>
