<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, drafts, notes, press
releases, clippings, and printed matter relating to security hearings. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, awards, honors,
bibliographical and biographical material, financial papers, physics papers,
and testimonies. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Reprints, galley proofs, and one draft. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Drafts, notes, galley proofs, requests to reprint or quote,
correspondence, clippings, printed matter, and an index. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Printed matter, photographs, and an incomplete card index of
Oppenheimer's memberships.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received and copies of letters sent, memoranda, manuscript
and near-print research reports, and scientific photographs. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Originals and copies of letters sent. Arranged alphabetically by
name of recipient. Also miscellaneous files containing printed and near-print
matter, photographs, writings by others, and a microfilm copy of a history of
the Institute for Advanced Study. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>Incoming correspondence received from the general public and inventories of
classified documents.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Classified government documents consisting mostly of
correspondence and reports. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Classified government documents consisting of memoranda and a
report. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Restricted government documents consisting of correspondence. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The records of
<corpname>
<part>Alex. Brown &amp; Sons</part>
</corpname> span the years 1796-1908,
with the bulk of the material dating from 1796 to 1884. Included are business
records of successor companies, subsidiaries, and allied business. The records
document the commercial and financial activities of
<persname>
<part>Alexander Brown,</part>
</persname> his sons, and their successors,
showing the development of their banking house in conjunction with extensive
import-export operations, the building of ships and worldwide trade activities,
and the building of the
<corpname>
<part>Baltimore &amp; Ohio Railroad.</part>
</corpname> They also reflect
the company's change from a mercantile to an international banking house having
connections with
<corpname>
<part>Brown, Shipley &amp; Company</part>
</corpname> of
<geogname>
<part>Liverpool,</part>
</geogname> and with
<corpname>
<part>Brown Brothers &amp; Company,</part>
</corpname> of
<geogname>
<part>New York,</part>
</geogname>

<geogname>
<part>Philadelphia,</part>
</geogname> and
<geogname>
<part>Baltimore.</part>
</geogname> The records are organized into the
following series:
<ref target="copy" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Lettercopy
Books,
</ref>

<ref target="press" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Letterpress
Books,
</ref>

<ref target="daybooks" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Daybooks,
</ref>

<ref target="cash" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Cashbooks,
</ref>

<ref target="ledger" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Ledgers,
</ref>

<ref target="sledger" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Sterling
Ledgers,
</ref>

<ref target="ledgersb" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Ledger Sight
Bills,
</ref>

<ref target="jrnls" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Journals,
</ref>

<ref target="sales" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Sales Books,
</ref>

<ref target="waste" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Waste Books,
</ref>

<ref target="accts" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Accounts
Current,
</ref>

<ref target="blotters" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Blotters,
</ref>
and
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany.
</ref>
</p>
<p>The firm of Alex. Brown &amp; Sons was founded by
<persname>
<part>Alexander Brown,</part>
</persname> an Irish immigrant who came to
<geogname>
<part>Baltimore</part>
</geogname> in 1797 and engaged in the mercantile
business as an importer of Irish linen. The records are largely confined to the
operations of the firm's outlets in
<geogname>
<part>Baltimore,</part>
</geogname> which served as the American
headquarters for the firm's chain of offices from 1800 to 1840. Lettercopy and
letterpress books generally provide a continuous, daily record of the branch's
outgoing correspondence with other offices in the organization and with the
branch's out-of-town customers from 1800 to 1879. </p>
<p>Letterbooks, in the collection contain detailed information concerning political, civil,
and military affairs affecting the firm. The <ref target="copy" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Lettercopy Books
</ref> series, consisting of letters sent,
includes records of the <corpname>
<part>Falls and Brown Company,</part>
</corpname> 1803-1804, and of
Campbell McIlvaine &amp; Company, 1830-1837. The <ref target="press" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Letterpress Books
</ref> series is organized into three subseries.
<ref target="seta" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Set A
</ref> includes records
similar to those in the Lettercopy Books series and is distinguished from them chiefly
by the copying method. <ref target="setb" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Set B
</ref>
is comprised of letterpress copies of letters sent to <corpname>
<part>Brown Shipley &amp;
Company,</part>
</corpname>
<geogname>
<part>London, England.</part>
</geogname> The letterpress copies in <ref target="setc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Set C
</ref> are of letters sent to <corpname>
<part>Brown
Brothers &amp; Company,</part>
</corpname>
<geogname>
<part>Boston,</part>
</geogname>
<geogname>
<part>New York,</part>
</geogname> and <geogname>
<part>Philadelphia</part>
</geogname> offices.</p>
<p>The collection also includes financial records in a variety of
formats.
<ref target="daybooks" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Daybooks
</ref> are
daily journals of business transactions in the order of their occurrence.
<ref target="cash" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Cashbooks
</ref> record
money received and paid out, showing date of transaction, name of customer or
client, description of the transaction, and amounts received and expended.
<ref target="ledger" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Ledgers
</ref>
contain postings to accounts receivable and accounts payable; they include
ledgers of
<corpname>
<part>Falls &amp; Brown,</part>
</corpname>

<geogname>
<part>Baltimore,</part>
</geogname> 1796-1810.
<ref target="sledger" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Sterling
Ledgers
</ref> contain postings to accounts receivable and accounts payable of
Alex. Brown &amp; Sons sterling operations.
<ref target="ledgersb" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Ledger Sight
Bills
</ref> contain a record of journal postings by bill number. Journals
contain daily entries from daybooks and blotters.
<ref target="sales" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Sales Books
</ref>
appear to be logs of customer sales.
<ref target="waste" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Waste Books
</ref> are
daily journals of business transactions in the order of their occurrence; one
book is from
<persname>
<part>Stewart Brown,</part>
</persname>

<geogname>
<part>Philadelphia,</part>
</geogname> and
<corpname>
<part>Falls &amp; Brown,</part>
</corpname>

<geogname>
<part>Baltimore.</part>
</geogname>

<ref target="accts" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Accounts
Current
</ref> appear to be summaries of accounts receivable and accounts
payable. Account entries include account name, transaction date, and
description. Blotters are daily journals of business transactions.</p>
<p>The
<ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
Miscellany
</ref>
series includes journals and ledgers of the
<corpname>
<part>Union Railroad Company</part>
</corpname> sinking fund, credit rating
and statements books, minute books of the
<corpname>
<part>Aransas Pass Harbor Company</part>
</corpname> of which
<corpname>
<part>Brown and Sons Company</part>
</corpname> was a bondholder and
trustee, and of the
<corpname>
<part>Female Orphan Asylum,</part>
</corpname>

<geogname>
<part>Baltimore.</part>
</geogname> Also in the series is a book containing
signatures of persons authorized to conduct business with
<corpname>
<part>Brown &amp; Sons Company.</part>
</corpname>
</p>
<p>The collection also includes records of other
<famname>
<part>Brown family</part>
</famname> firms, such as the firms of
<persname>
<part>Stewart Brown,</part>
</persname> of
<geogname>
<part>Philadelphia,</part>
</geogname> an older brother of
<persname>
<part>Alexander Brown,</part>
</persname> 22 April 1796- 30 May 1797; and
of
<persname>
<part>Moore Falls</part>
</persname> and
<persname>
<part>Stewart Brown</part>
</persname> of the firm of
<corpname>
<part>Falls &amp; Brown,</part>
</corpname> of
<geogname>
<part>Baltimore,</part>
</geogname> 1797-1810. These records are not
necessarily noted specifically in the descriptions below</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Copies of letters sent. Some volumes contain an alphabetical index
of correspondents. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letterpress copies of letters sent. Some volumes contain an
alphabetical index of correspondents.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letterpress copies of letters sent to Brown Shipley &amp; Co.,
London, England. Some volumes contain an alphabetical index of
correspondents.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letterpress copies of letters sent to Brown Brothers &amp; Co.,
Boston, Mass., New York, N.Y., and Philadelphia, Pa., offices. Some volumes
contain an alphabetical index of correspondents.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Daily journals of business transactions in the order of their
occurrence showing store location, date of transaction, folio number, name of
customer or client, nature of transaction, description of merchandise,
quantities, and amounts received and expended.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Record of money received and paid out showing date of transaction,
name of customer or client, transaction description, and amounts received and
expended.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Volumes contain postings to accounts receivable and accounts
payable. Account entries include account name, transaction date, description of
transaction, folio number, and amounts credited and debited. Some volumes
contain alphabetical indexes of account, customer, and client names.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Volumes are labeled "supplementary sterling ledgers" and appear to
contain postings to accounts receivable and accounts payable of Alex. Brown
&amp; Sons sterling operations. Entries include account name, transaction date,
description of transaction, folio number, and amounts credited and debited.
Some volumes contain alphabetical indexes of account, customer, and client
names.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Contains a record of journal postings by bill number. Entries
include transaction date, bill number, date paid, amount paid, and folio
number.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Volumes contain daily entries from daybooks and blotters. Entries
include folio number, date of transaction, transaction description, and amounts
credited or debited.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Volumes appear to be logs of customer sales. Entries include folio
number, date of transaction, name of customer, description of merchandise,
quantities purchased, and amount of money received.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Daily journals of business transactions in the order of their
occurrence. Entries for each transaction include folio number, date, nature of
transaction, name of customer or client, and amounts received and expended.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Volumes appear to be summaries of accounts receivable and accounts
payable. Account entries include account name, transaction date, description of
transaction, and amounts credited and debited. Some volumes contain
alphabetical indexes of account, customer, and client names.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Daily journals of business transactions in the order of their
occurrence showing store location, date of transaction, folio number, name of
customer or client, nature of transaction, description of merchandise,
quantities, and amounts received and expended.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Journals and ledgers for ground rent accounts held by trustees
of the sinking fund of the Union Railroad Co., Baltimore, Md. Volume entries
include date of transaction, account number, description of transaction, and
amounts debited and credited.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Single volume denoting credit worthiness of customers and
clients. Entries show date, customer or client name, and opinion concerning
ability to pay, business practices, and reliability.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letterpress copies of customers' statements of account
containing date, customer name and address, description of merchandise
purchased, quantities, and amounts credited and debited to account. Volume also
contains weekly financial statements of Alex. Brown &amp; Sons sterling
operations and an alphabetical index of customers. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Contains minutes of meetings and copies of resolutions adopted
by the board of trustees of the Aransas Pass Harbor Co., Aransas Pass, Tex., of
which Brown &amp; Sons Co. was a bondholder and trustee. Laid in are
correspondence, resolutions, notes, lists, and agreements concerning
acquisition of Aransas Harbor City &amp; Improvement Co., Aransas Pass,
Tex.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Single volume containing minutes of meetings of the board of
directors of the Female Orphan Asylum, Baltimore, Md. Also included are
financial reports and a newspaper clipping concerning the founding of the
organization.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Contains signatures of persons authorized to conduct business
with Brown &amp; Sons Co. and includes letters of introduction, business cards,
receipts, and signatures cut and pasted from other documents. Items entered
alphabetically by name of customer or client, although some entries are not in
proper order.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The records of the National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA), founded in 1890
by the merger of the National Woman Suffrage Association and the American Woman Suffrage
Association, span the years from 1839 to 1961 but are most numerous for the period
1890-1930. These records document the organization's history and activities, and are
organized into the following series: <ref target="corr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General Correspondence,</ref>
<ref target="subj" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Subject File,</ref> and <ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Miscellany.</ref>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="corr" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">General Correspondence</ref>
series consists of correspondence with individual members and supporters of the
association, and with its officials. The series also incorporates correspondence with
related organizations, and with the Board of Directors, Executive Committee, and other
units of NAWSA. The collection features letters from many of the leaders in the woman's
rights movement, including pioneer figures such as Millicent Garrett Fawcett, Abby
Kelley Foster, Helen H. Gardener, Sarah Moore Grimké, Julia Ward Howe, Florence Kelley,
Mary Ashton Rice Livermore, Lucretia Mott, Anna Howard Shaw, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, and
Emma Willard. More recent leaders are represented by Ida Husted Harper, Mary Garrett
Hay, Belle Case La Follette, E. Sylvia Pankhurst, Maud Wood Park, Mary Gray Peck,
Jeannette Rankin, and Rosika Schwimmer. </p>
<p>Other correspondents include prominent writers, reformers and political leaders such as
Henry Ward Beecher, William Edgar Borah, Witter Bynner, W. H. Channing, Eugene V. Debs,
Albert Einstein, Ralph Waldo Emerson, William Lloyd Garrison, William Dean Howells,
Robert M. La Follette, Ben B. Lindsey, Upton Sinclair, Ainsworth Rand Spofford, Theodore
Tilton, Oswald Garrison Villard, James Wolcott Wadsworth (1877-1952), Theodore Dwight
Weld, and Woodrow Wilson. </p>
<p>The <ref target="subj" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Subject File</ref> includes
biographical information on some of the principal suffrage workers, a collection of
antisuffrage literature, progress reports from state and local suffrage organizations
affiliated with the National American Woman Suffrage Association, records relating to
the work of the Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage, formed by the merger of NAWSA's
Congressional Committee with the National Woman's Party in 1917, and litigation
proceedings resulting from Mrs. Frank Leslie's bequest of one million dollars to the
organization. The subject file includes important material on the official organ of the
association, the <title localtype="simple" render="italic">
<part>Woman's Journal,</part>
</title> 1907-1949. Among the printed items in the <ref target="misc" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">Miscellany</ref> series is a set of indexed scrapbooks prepared
by Ida Porter Boyer which document activities in the woman's rights movement as reported
in the nation's newspapers and periodicals during the years 1893-1912.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters sent and received, with related material such as magazine articles,
newspaper clippings, pamphlets, and other printed matter, photographs, press
releases, receipts, and telegrams. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Minutes, press releases, resolutions, correspondence, subscription lists,
telegrams, printed matter, newsletters, notes, telegrams, and scrapbook pages
relating mainly to state and local suffrage organizations and leaders in the
movement. Includes a large number of published writings and photographs.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Miscellaneous material including reports, speeches, typescripts, photographs,
minutes, newspaper clippings, and pamphlets; scrapbooks compiled by Ida Porter
Boyer; and printed matter.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<head>Scope and Content Note</head>
<p>The papers of <persname>
<part>Donald Thomas Regan (1918- 2003)</part>
</persname> span the years 1919-1993, with the bulk of the collection dating from the
period 1981-1987, the years in which Regan served first as secretary of the treasury and
then <corpname>
<part>White House</part>
</corpname> chief of staff during the presidency of <persname>
<part>Ronald Reagan.</part>
</persname> Regan's career at <corpname>
<part>Merrill Lynch and Company</part>
</corpname> started with a training program following his military service in World War
II and culminated as chief executive officer and chairman of the board. His papers,
focusing mainly on his government service in the Reagan administration, are organized
into three series: <ref target="treas" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Treasury
Department, </ref>
<ref target="white" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> White House, </ref> and a <ref target="person" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Personal File. </ref>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="treas" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Treasury Department </ref>
series contains files from Regan's tenure as secretary of the treasury from January 1981
to January 1985. It is the largest segment of the collection and documents the economic
policies of the Reagan administration. <ref target="chron" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Chronological files </ref> within the series include Regan's
official correspondence and a reading and information file containing material put
together by Regan's executive assistant, <persname>
<part>David L. Chew,</part>
</persname> to brief the secretary on important issues and activities. Another subseries
contains <ref target="memo" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> memoranda </ref>
prepared by various offices in the <corpname>
<part>Treasury Department,</part>
</corpname> including those relating to domestic finance, economic policy, monetary
affairs, and tax policy. A <ref target="speech" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
speeches and engagements </ref> file contains a chronological record of the speaking
engagements, statements, and trips Regan made as secretary. </p>
<p>The <ref target="subj" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> subject file </ref> in the <corpname>
<part>Treasury Department</part>
</corpname> series focuses on the issues, activities, and organization relating to the <corpname>
<part>Treasury Department</part>
</corpname> during Regan's tenure. It includes files on the bureaus comprising the
department, such as the <corpname>
<part>Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms,</part>
</corpname> the <corpname>
<part>Secret Service,</part>
</corpname> and the <corpname>
<part>United States Mint,</part>
</corpname> as well as economic policy-making bodies such as the <corpname>
<part>Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs,</part>
</corpname> the <corpname>
<part>Council of Economic Advisors,</part>
</corpname> the <corpname>
<part>Federal Reserve Board,</part>
</corpname> and the <corpname>
<part>Office of Management and Budget.</part>
</corpname> A file of transition material contains briefing books on economic issues
addressed at the start of the Reagan administration. Additional subjects covered include
the federal budget, financial deregulation, tax cut legislation, and tax reform. Filed
with material on the thrift industry are papers relating to a congressional inquiry into
savings and loan institutions which took place in 1991 when Regan testified regarding
policies and activities during his term as secretary of the treasury.</p>
<p>Individuals whose activities and correspondence are reflected in the <ref target="treas" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Treasury Department </ref> files include
department officials <persname>
<part>Marc Leland,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Ann Dore McLaughlin,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Richard T. McNamar,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Roger W. Mehle,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Beryl W. Sprinkel;</part>
</persname> director of the <corpname>
<part>Office of Management and Budget</part>
</corpname>
<persname>
<part>David Alan Stockman;</part>
</persname> head of the <corpname>
<part>Federal Reserve</part>
</corpname>
<persname>
<part>Paul Volker;</part>
</persname> and Vice President <persname>
<part>George Bush.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>In January 1985, at the start of <persname>
<part>Ronald Reagan's</part>
</persname> second term, Donald Regan and <persname>
<part>James A. Baker</part>
</persname> switched positions, with Baker becoming secretary of the treasury and Regan
taking over as White House chief of staff. Papers in Regan's <ref target="white" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> White House </ref> files relate to his service
until his resignation on 27 February 1987. Regan's management of the day-to-day
operations of the Reagan presidency is documented in the daily schedules of both Regan
and the president and Regan's telephone logs of incoming and outgoing calls. Notes
recording the activities and issues dealt with by the <corpname>
<part> White House,</part>
</corpname> including notes on meetings and conversations, are also among Regan's
files.</p>
<p>A subject file in the <ref target="white" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> White
House </ref> series includes administrative and briefing documents related to Regan's
appointment as chief of staff. One such document is a letter from <persname>
<part>Richard Nixon</part>
</persname> offering his impressions and advice on running the <corpname>
<part>White House.</part>
</corpname> Another subject treated is arms control negotiations with the <geogname>
<part>Soviet Union,</part>
</geogname> including files on summit meetings in <geogname>
<part>Geneva, Switzerland,</part>
</geogname> and <geogname>
<part>Reykjavik, Iceland.</part>
</geogname> Located in files relating to the <geogname>
<part>Soviet Union</part>
</geogname> is an exchange of correspondence between <persname>
<part>Ronald Reagan</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Mikhail Gorbachev</part>
</persname> that occurred in the period between these summit meetings. There is also
material on the Iran-Contra Affair, some of which, along with files for his memoirs, was
subpoenaed during an independent counsel's investigation into the Iran-Contra Affair.
Notations and markers are attached to documents requested and examined in 1992 as part
of this inquiry.</p>
<p>Individuals mentioned in the <ref target="white" show="replace" actuate="onrequest">
White House </ref> series are <persname>
<part>William Casey,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part>Michael Deaver,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part> Robert C. "Bud" McFarlane,</part>
</persname>
<persname>
<part> John M. Poindexter,</part>
</persname> and <persname>
<part>Nancy Reagan.</part>
</persname>
</p>
<p>The <ref target="person" show="replace" actuate="onrequest"> Personal File </ref>
contains material related to Regan's activities outside government before and after his
positions in the Reagan administration, including a few items from his career at <corpname>
<part>Merrill Lynch.</part>
</corpname> These files supplement a larger collection of records, including fifty-six
volumes of desk diaries, schedule books, and calendars dating from 1952 to 1980, which
is located in the <corpname>
<part>Merrill Lynch</part>
</corpname> corporate archives in <geogname>
<part>New York.</part>
</geogname> Other papers from the period prior to Regan's work in <geogname>
<part>Washington</part>
</geogname> include files of political activities and memberships in organizations
ranging from the tournament policy board of the <corpname>
<part>Professional Golfers' Association of America</part>
</corpname> to his chairmanship of the board of trustees of the <corpname>
<part>University of Pennsylvania.</part>
</corpname>
</p>
<p>Files from the period following his departure from government service include speeches
and writings. Files from the preparation of his memoirs <title localtype="simple">
<part>For the Record,</part>
</title> which he wrote with the assistance of <persname>
<part>Charles McCarry,</part>
</persname> include transcripts of tapes which Regan dictated, communications with and
drafts by McCarry, and research files containing such original documents from Regan's <corpname>
<part>Treasury Department</part>
</corpname> and <corpname>
<part>White House</part>
</corpname> periods as a diary of his initial days as secretary of the treasury, his
handwritten account of the assassination attempt on <persname>
<part>President Reagan</part>
</persname> in 1981, as well as notes from that day, material on Reagan's cancer surgery
in 1985, and the <geogname>
<part>Geneva</part>
</geogname> summit meeting. Among the speeches and writings are commentaries, mainly on
financial topics, which Regan presented on television and radio. Papers relating to <persname>
<part>Thomas Dawson,</part>
</persname> Regan's executive assistant at the <corpname>
<part>White House</part>
</corpname> who moved with him to the firm Regan established, <corpname>
<part>Regdon Associates,</part>
</corpname> also appear among Regan's personal files.</p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Official and personal correspondence sent by Regan with attached material, a
reading file of memoranda and notes from Regan's staff with attached related
material, and a file of notes to staff. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Letters received by Regan. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Memoranda received by individuals in the Treasury Department and other
government officials. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Scrapbooks containing correspondence, photographs, clippings, and other
memorabilia from Regan's tenure as secretary of the treasury. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Speeches, statements, testimony, correspondence, and miscellaneous material
relating to speaking engagements, trips, and other official activities
undertaken by Regan. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, briefing books, minutes, transcripts, reports,
schedules, notes, clippings, charts, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, notes, memoranda, schedules, telephone logs, speeches,
invitations, transcripts, clippings, reports, and printed matter. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Correspondence, memoranda, notes, speeches, book manuscripts and related material,
writings, transcripts, and other material covering Regan's activities outside
government service. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent encodinganalog="520">
<p>Government security classified correspondence, memoranda, reports, and notes. </p>
</scopecontent>
<scopecontent>
<p>Top secret government security classified congressional hearing transcript. </p>
</scopecontent>
